PARA.TAB: The Senate met at 2 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to standing order 13, I advise the Senate that the President is temporarily absent. Mr President is attending the state funeral for former President O'Byrne. Pursuant to the standing orders, the Deputy President will take the chair.

PARA.TAB: The DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Crichton-Browne) thereupon took the chair, and read prayers.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Acting Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I inform the Senate that the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Senator Gareth Evans, and the Minister for Trade, Senator Cook, are overseas on government business and will return on 22 November 1993. During Senator Evans's absence I will act as Leader of the Government in the Senate and represent the Prime Minister. I will also take questions relating to the portfolios of foreign affairs and trade. Questions relating to the primary industries and energy portfolio should be addressed to Senator Bolkus. Senator Collins will take questions addressed to the Special Minister of State, including those concerning Mabo issues and legislation. Senator Richardson is attending the funeral of former Senator Justin O'Byrne. Questions relating to his portfolio responsibilities should be addressed to Senator Crowley.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—We are concerned about the absence of three senior ministers during question time. I cannot remember any occasion on which three ministers have been absent from question time. I understand what the Acting Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Robert Ray) said in relation to Senator Richardson, but the Prime Minister is here today, so why have Senator Gareth Evans and Senator Cook had to precede him to Seattle? If Senator Evans, the senior DFAT portfolio minister, is going, one even wonders why Senator Cook has to go at all.
—Why does the junior minister have to go?
—Why does the junior minister have to go? For some years, Senator Evans has been the Minister for Foreign Affairs—
—You have never taken APEC seriously, have you?

—We know that those opposite regard the parliamentary process as being of little consequence. They take that attitude from their leader. Mr Keating's attitude is that this place should not be any more than a rubber stamp. We may not be able to do anything about it, but it is important that we put on the record that we regard it as unsatisfactory that so many senior ministers are absent from question time when there are critically important issues to be dealt with by this parliament. We ask that, in future, the government take into account the fact that the parliament should be entitled to have its ministers answer questions relevant to their portfolios during question time.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Acting Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I should say on behalf of Senator Richardson that he did discuss with me his presence here today. Certainly on our side it was a difficult decision to grant him leave, but he was close to former Senator O'Byrne and I made that decision on his behalf.
—I am not objecting to that.

—I understand that. In terms of the reason for the absence of Senator Evans and Senator Cook, there are preliminary meetings of ministers that precede the APEC meeting, hence the difference in timetable of departure between Senator Evans and Senator Cook and, in turn, the Prime Minister (Mr Keating). These matters are somewhat exacerbated because both ministers are in the Senate; that is the way the responsibilities turned out. It would not be quite so obvious if one minister were in the House of Representatives and one minister were in the Senate.

PARA.TAB: Senator Evans is always conscious of trying to be here in the chamber. He spends a lot of time programming parliamentary sittings and his own trips to make sure that he can be in this parliament. If those opposite compare his track record with those of previous Labor and Liberal foreign ministers, they will find that his attendance in the chamber is far better than that of any of his predecessors.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Acting Leader of the Government in the Senate. Last year the Prime Minister solemnly swore on Lateline not to put up taxes. In the last budget, the now besieged Treasurer promised that his budget strategy would be achieved without resort to any new taxes. Yet only last week the Minister for Finance, Mr Willis, said that the deficit strategy may involve some revenue increases. Four days later the Treasurer disowned the finance minister by saying:

QUESTION.PARA: I am opposed to future tax increases to meet the cost of any new obligations which come up.

Could the minister please tell the Senate whether or not this government is in favour of tax increases and, in the light of the dishonouring of last year's commitments, why should anyone believe any Labor commitments will be honoured?

TALK.START.PARA: —For the record, some of the views attributed to the finance minister were grievously misquoted, which he has also put on the public record. The attitude of this government is that it is very important that our debt reduction program continue. It has been frustrated and substantially affected by the actions of Senator Alston and his colleagues in this chamber, who have absolutely no policy in this regard. They can only bleat on that they would meet any debt reduction strategy through unspecified reductions in expenditure. They will not highlight which areas of expenditure they will reduce because that is far too much hard work. This government made very clear and the Prime Minister made very clear prior to the election our attitude to taxation and the mix of taxation. That was endorsed by the electorate, much to the chagrin of those opposite.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Transport and Communications. I refer to the continuing concern in the Australian maritime community with the standard of certain foreign vessels trading to Australia, particularly when these vessels are allowed to transit the Great Barrier Reef area. What assurance can be given to the high standard Australian shipping industry that federal government action is effective in addressing the problem of substandard ships?

—The range of government initiatives aimed at tackling the problem of substandard ships is having effect in ensuring compliance with international standards and making our concerns known in the international maritime community. However, as I have noted on many occasions publicly, Australia's ability to deal with these issues is tempered by international law. We are playing an effective role in promoting ship safety and proper crewing practices. However, Australia, as a relatively small ship owning nation largely dependent on overseas shipping services, is not well placed to pursue unilateral action.

PARA.TAB: The Ships of shame report by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure provided a major impetus in highlighting the complex problems in regulating international shipping. I have now provided the committee's chairman, Peter Morris, with a further standing reference to inquire on an ongoing basis into developments at the national and international level on issues raised in the report. The aim is for the committee to keep attention focused on improving ship standards and to maintain the momentum of concern for a safer and more responsible shipping industry.

The Australian Maritime Safety Authority is playing a major role in implementing the government's response to the report. Last year AMSA increased its port state control inspections to cover 34 per cent of all foreign ships visiting Australian ports, well ahead of the accepted international inspection target of 25 per cent. Over 70 per cent of ships inspected were found to have had some kind of deficiency, more than half of those involving lifesaving and firefighting equipment vital to the safety of the crews on board those ships. On a number of recent occasions, AMSA has used its detention powers under the Navigation Act to prevent unsafe vessels from leaving port until identified deficiencies were rectified.

In relation to the coastal shipping trade, I have asked the Department of Transport and Communications to review procedures under the ministerial guidelines for issuing coastal trading permits to foreign vessels. This will determine whether applicants should be required to supply more comprehensive information on the condition of the ship. When this review is completed, I will be consulting with interested parties in the industry on any proposed changes.

At the international level, Australia is actively supporting efforts to improve the effectiveness of the International Maritime Organisation. At the IMO meeting in London last month AMSA, as Australia's representative, was re-elected, with an increased vote, as a member of the IMO council. This reflects the recognition of Australia's higher profile in the international maritime community. While substandard ships are in the minority, Australia must continue the high level of ship inspection and support for international action to rid the world of this threat to the well-being of ships' crews and to our environment.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Health. In light of the Prime Minister's unequivocal decision not to take out private health insurance, despite the fact that he can clearly afford it, I ask: will the minister obtain an assurance from the Prime Minister that in the event of his or his family falling ill and requiring hospitalisation, they will share a room with other public patients in a public hospital after being on the requisite waiting list with other uninsured Medicare patients?

—That question from Senator Herron is essentially disgraceful. It presumes that the government would interfere in how a doctor might treat a patient. If Senator Herron's question is that Mr Keating is calling himself public and not accepting the service, then it is quite a disgraceful question. It is certainly disappointing that it comes from Senator Herron because he more than most should know that what a doctor organises by way of treatment for a patient is very much something the doctor has a large say in and it is agreed between a doctor and a patient. I think that question is not worthy of any further comment.

—Mr Deputy President, I ask a supplementary question. Does the minister support Senator Richardson's belief that high income earners, such as the Prime Minister, should take out private health insurance? If she does not, is the Prime Minister not, in Senator Richardson's own words, `elbowing a pensioner out of the public hospital queue'? That is the very opposite of what Senator Crowley just said.

—Firstly, let me make it clear that I did not say those things that Senator Herron ascribes to me. Senator Herron has got that wrong too. What is clear is that we have an excellent health system in this country. Indeed, it is one of the best in the world. That does not mean that there are not problems within our health system that need to be fixed.

PARA.TAB: Minister Richardson is putting together a package of measures to deal with these and other problems. I have not seen that package, nor have any of my colleagues. I believe Senator Richardson has already had some discussions with the relevant caucus committee.

What he will be doing is taking a package of measures to cabinet in the next month. This is the ordinary process to be followed by a minister. It is not a split; it is called the decision making process. That is something that the members of the opposition would not recognise if it slapped them in the face.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I raise a point of order. I asked a very simple question. That is not a response; it is a speech.
—There is no point of order.

—Can the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women comment on the response of the stop violence against women program which she launched last week, and what she thinks can be achieved by this campaign?

—On Monday of last week in Sydney I launched the second stage of the Commonwealth's community education program called stop violence against women. That program has a number of slogans. Firstly, it puts the message into the community that real men do not bash or rape women. I am pleased to say that four significant men have agreed to contribute to that campaign: Darren Mercer, Kieren Perkins, James Blundell and Don Burke. Those men are prepared to join the women of Australia in saying that violence against women is totally unacceptable. I have actually placed on the record, but I am happy to say it again, my appreciation for these men who have said that they are very happy to speak out about violence against women.

PARA.TAB: At this stage non-violent men are joining women in opposing the violent behaviour of some men in our community. I do not believe that this matter can be overlooked; it is a matter of the greatest gravity. It should be appreciated that those men have been prepared to join the government in this campaign.

Women have made it clear to us that one of their main concerns is violence against them and their children in the community. It is also clear that violence exists on a totally unacceptable and, indeed, horrific scale against women throughout Australia, as any number of demonstrations and data reveal.

Part of that stop violence against women campaign consists of this community education program where, as I said, non-violent men have joined women in opposing violence against women. The principal slogans of that campaign are: `Real men don't bash or rape women', `Violent men will lose everything' and `We will not tolerate violence against women'.

As Kieren Perkins said, `We all have a responsibility to stop pretending that this kind of thing does not happen, to stop making excuses for violent men and to start speaking our minds'. As Darren Mercer added, `I appeal to them and to other sportsmen and sportswomen at the launch to use their influence as role models to say to young people it isn't manly or tough to rape or bash women'. I think that is a very important slogan. The sportsmen and sportswomen do have a considerable amount to offer the community. They are models to our young people. I believe the peer pressure that they will offer by saying to violent men in the community that it is totally unacceptable will make this campaign a great step forward in terms of community education and changing attitudes.

As well as the publicity-education campaign, I announced a program of community grants at the launch in Sydney on Monday, in Melbourne on Tuesday and in South Australia on Wednesday. We also have special projects which I have listed here before and I am happy to list them again. They include the assistance that the Office of the Status of Women is providing to the Australian Institute of Judicial Administration for the development of its gender awareness programs. It also consists of assistance we are providing to the Family Court for the training of people in the court to know how best to deal with violence and the assistance we are providing to the Australian Law Reform Commission in its inquiry into equity before the law, particularly the impact of violence.

I do not believe we can speak too strongly against violence against women in the community. I believe this campaign is a very significant second step. It is very impressive that non-violent men are now adding their voice to the voice of women in opposing any violence against women.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Acting Leader of the Government in the Senate. I refer the minister to the revelations about efforts by the Prime Minister to acquire a $30,000 dining table and $24,000 reproduction regency chairs for the Lodge as well as other expensive adornments for the walls of the cabinet room. Do not these revelations suggest that there is now something sadly lacking in the priorities of a Prime Minister who, as Treasurer for 10 years, boasted about his razor gang successes in cutting millions of dollars in expenditure line by line from welfare, education and health programs? I do not endorse the muckraking, but I do question the priorities. Is there not something wrong with the Prime Minister's priorities in these difficult economic times?

—It was not Prime Minister Keating's initiative to purchase a table for the Lodge; that was initiated some time in 1991 by Mr Keating's predecessor's spouse. The funding involved was not taxpayers' money but money raised by the Australiana Fund, essentially through opening the Lodge to visits by members of the public. In any event, no purchase of a table proceeded. The artworks that Parliament House acquires and the overall quantum are a matter for the Presiding Officers to determine. I understand that some $8 million has been spent from 1980 on art works in Parliament House.
—But none of it is good enough for this Prime Minister, is it?

—Certainly none of it adorns my office but that is because I am a cultural philistine, and for no other reason. There is the odd Collingwood photo up in the office, I have to admit. I think we are debating here not the quantum overall but the nature of the purchases—whether we should purchase A or B. The Prime Minister has expressed an opinion on what he believes is appropriate for the cabinet room. It does not really involve, in the overall quantum of art acquisition in this building, increased expenditure; it is whether it goes in one particular area or another. So I say to Senator Kernot that I do not believe that the Prime Minister's suggestion that the Gould prints adorn the cabinet room represents a change in his priorities.

—My question is directed to the Acting Leader of the Government in the Senate. I refer to the United Nations operations in Western Sahara. I ask the minister: has Australia advised the United Nations that it will withdraw its contingent from Minurso in May 1994? Will Australia be making a military contribution to ONUMOZ in Mozambique following the withdrawal of its contingent from Minurso?

—Australia did contribute 45 signallers to the UN mission for the referendum in Western Sahara—the Minurso operation—in September 1991 in support of the UN plan to conduct a referendum in which the question would be posed whether Western Sahara should be independent or part of Morocco. Since then, the parties—Morocco and the Polisario, which is the Western Sahara independence movement—have been unable to come to an agreement on voter registration and eligibility and the referendum has consequently been delayed. There has been some progress towards holding a referendum following the efforts of the Secretary-General to reach a compromise between the parties.

PARA.TAB: The Australian deployment was originally anticipated to be for a period of 35 weeks and was not intended to be open ended. We have subsequently agreed to six-monthly rotations of the contingent because of the delays in the organisation of the referendum. In response to a request from the UN, the Australian contingent with Minurso is currently being rotated for a further six-month deployment but we have advised the UN that this will be the last rotation, and it ends in May 1994. We do remain hopeful that a referendum may take place before May 1994 but progress to date has been slow.

Australia has made no commitment at this point to contribute military personnel to the UN operation in Mozambique. We understand that the military component of the mission is fully subscribed but we hope that it will be possible to make some form of contribution further down the track, subject to availability of resources and keeping in mind that any military contribution would be dependent on our first withdrawing from Minurso.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the minister representing the Minister for Health. I ask in light of some ambiguity in her answer to Senator Herron whether she will specifically answer the very simple question: does she support Senator Richardson that the Prime Minister, in view of his high income, should take out private health cover?

—I have given a very adequate answer on this and that is that the matter for the minister is how to deliver the best health system in this country. He is putting together a package of measures to deal with that and the package will go to cabinet at the right time. When those measures are before cabinet and before the Senate, that sort of discussion can continue. The question that Senator Hill asks is not a matter that is appropriate for me to answer.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs. Is the minister aware of claims by a New South Wales government minister that the Commonwealth has slashed funds for the Adult Migrant English Service? Further, is the minister aware of threats of industrial action by the New South Wales Teachers Federation in protest against the alleged cuts? Are the funds to the New South Wales Adult Migrant English Service to be cut as claimed by the New South Wales minister, and is this proposed strike action in any way justified?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator McKiernan for what is, I believe, a very timely question. It is time that the New South Wales government and the New South Wales Adult Migrant English Service got some pretty basic facts straight and stopped running erroneous scare campaigns in New South Wales about the level of English language services not only in that state but also across the country. It is true that one unfortunate victim of this disinformation campaign is the New South Wales Teachers Federation. As the honourable senator indicated in his question, the federation has already signalled that it is considering industrial action.

PARA.TAB: The history of disinformation on this matter is recent. On 4 November this year, the New South Wales Minister for Industrial Relations and Employment, Kerry Chikarovski, put out a press statement making a somewhat astounding claim that the Commonwealth had cut funding to adult ESL programs in New South Wales by some 20 per cent. She also claimed that that would necessitate a reduction of jobs in the area of some 84 positions. The New South Wales Teachers Federation, ignited by this press statement, issued a press release protesting and signalling industrial action.

The truth, of course, is different. If the minister, Kerry Chikarovski, and the journalists who ran her press release had bothered to check, they would have seen that her claims were wrong. Rather than decrease, Commonwealth expenditure on adult ESL programs for New South Wales residents has substantially increased as a result of 1992-93 budget decisions. ESL funding in New South Wales over the 1992-94 triennium is: 1992, $37.3 million, with $34.5 million coming from my department and $2.8 million coming from DEET; 1993, $43.1 million, with $25.7 million from my department and $17.4 million from DEET; and 1994, $42.1 million, with $20.1 million from Immigration and $22 million from DEET. Of these state figures, Commonwealth funding to the New South Wales Adult Migrant English Service over the 1992-94 triennium is expected to be: in 1992, $31 million; in 1993, $35.6 million; and in 1994, $31 million.

There is a basic misunderstanding in the minister's press release. She neglected to recognise the contribution of the Department of Employment, Education and Training in this overall government program. Her decision to declare 84 positions redundant, when the Commonwealth's commitment to this area has actually increased, is somewhat astounding.

The difficulty I find in this matter is that Mrs Chikarovski acted unilaterally. Negotiations had been continuing; I had been awaiting a reply from her; but the press statement came out regardless of those discussions.

The other surprising aspect is that she put out a press statement at a time when she did not rely on accurate information. She has redressed that to a certain extent in recent days. On 12 November she wrote to me saying:

I am pleased to note that the estimates on which we have been planning may not have been reliable and therefore that it is still possible that sufficient funds may be allocated to NSW AMES to avoid any job losses.

ANSWER.PARA: It is a pity that she did not go to her officers and check that out before she wrote the letter.

PARA.TAB: Discussions will be continuing in the next few days between New South Wales officials and officers from my department. I hope those discussions will end those misconceptions about the Commonwealth's ongoing commitment to adult ESL services.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the minister for his answer and note that the New South Wales minister has indeed corrected herself to a point. I ask the minister whether he has taken any steps to ensure that the New South Wales Teachers Federation is aware of the facts of the situation.
—What is her name?
—Is she part of the uglies faction, Bronwyn?

—A bit of help from my frontbench parliamentary colleague would not go amiss on this matter. Can unwarranted strike activity be avoided over an issue which is really a non-event as a result of a misunderstanding, if not worse?

—I am writing back to the Hon. Kerry Chikarovski and setting the situation straight. That letter, of course, will also go to the New South Wales Teachers Federation; it has already been notified by me of the level of funding. The other strange thing about this is that Chikarovski's letter was written despite the fact that—
—Mrs Chikarovski's letter, if you don't mind.

—Mrs Chikarovski's letter—and I am not so sure whether she is part of Senator Bishop's faction in New South Wales, but I am sure she will appreciate this degree of support from her; she may not reciprocate in the preselection for Mackellar, from my information.

PARA.TAB: But, in any event, that letter was written despite an agreement which Mrs Chadwick, as senior New South Wales education minister, had reached in Perth earlier this year at a meeting chaired by my colleague Mr Beazley, a meeting which I attended and at which a formula was accepted in terms of Commonwealth contribution to funding in this area. Not only are we meeting that formula, we are exceeding it. It is a pity that communications between Mrs Chadwick and Mrs Chikarovski were not better. If they had been, we would not have had this sort of campaign fuelled in the community in New South Wales.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Acting Leader of the Government in the Senate. I refer to clause 170DB of the new Brereton industrial relations bill which states that an employee of five or more years service must be given at least four weeks notice of dismissal, and that an employee of more than one year at least two weeks notice. Why were the two housekeepers at the Lodge given less than 24 hours notice of their dismissal and told that the guards would turn them away if they approached the establishment?

—In terms of what is proposed in future legislation, we will comment on that when that legislation comes before this chamber. But there has been some publicity given to the fact—and it was explored, of course, at length at an estimates committee meeting—that there was not total harmony in terms of the staff at the Lodge; I think one cook and two housekeepers had their services terminated. If they have a grievance as to the particular manner in which that was done, there are plenty of remedies by which they can take that matter up.

—Mr Deputy President, I ask a supplementary question: is it not true that, following their dismissal, these women were intimidated by sections of the Crimes Act being read out to them when they went to the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet to ascertain why they had been sacked? Is not this yet another example of a Prime Minister who considers himself above the law and dismissive of his own legislative responsibilities?

—Mr Deputy President, you will notice how carefully Senator Chapman put that particular question as though implying that the Prime Minister had threatened either of these staff. That certainly is absolutely untrue, and it should be said for the public record that it is untrue that he did so.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education and Training. I ask: when will the government recognise the commonsense of the jobs levy as proposed by the Australian Democrats some 18 months ago? When will the government endorse the jobs levy concept which has already been recognised by the ACTU, the Australian Council of Social Service, the Minister for Finance and even the caucus task force on employment? While we are talking about commonsense, when will the government get serious about its departments buying Australian products and about raising additional money to spend in Australia on Australian products?

—Mr Deputy President, we would certainly raise a lot of money, would we not, if we could tax grandstanding. But I think Senator Bell is well aware of the action taken by the government in terms of commissioning a paper on unemployment, that that is due in not too long a period of time and that cabinet will consider what tax or any other measures are required to support any package that that recommends. I assure Senator Bell he will be fully informed when the government makes that decision.

—My question is addressed to the Acting Leader of the Government in the Senate in his capacity as Minister representing the Prime Minister. My question follows Senator Kernot's question. How can the Prime Minister possibly justify spending up to $100,000 on 15 Gould lithographs simply to satisfy his taste for Australian colonial art, when there are some 3,000 contemporary Australian art works in the Parliament House collection which he could have chosen? Does the Prime Minister believe that $100,000 worth of art work in the cabinet room will provide the necessary inspiration to deal with the massive unemployment crisis facing this country? Would not the $100,000 spent on the art works have been better spent in helping to provide emergency relief for the unemployed in Mr Keating's electorate of Blaxland?

—Mr Deputy President, it seems to me that if we take Senator Kemp's assertions in his question to the logical conclusion, we would go around this building and collect every bit of art work, sell it and put it to other purposes. That is essentially what the thrust of it is.

PARA.TAB: I do not recall—and I do not often follow Senator Kemp's speeches—Senator Kemp saying in this chamber previously that we have spent too much money on art works around Parliament House. He may have said so. I know that he always takes a great interest in these matters because he is only ever interested in incestuous matters to do with the chamber or the parliament. That is his great interest, not the broad issues but always the minuscule, incestuous issues to do with the running of this parliament or this chamber.

As I indicated earlier in answer to Senator Kernot's question, this is not a question about the amount of expenditure that goes on art works in Parliament House but a question about where, in fact, the expenditure goes in terms of choice, be it Gould prints, modern art, sculpture or whatever else is put in this building.

If, in fact, Senator Kemp says there should be no further purchases ever again for this building, let him say so. Let him bind a future government of his party to never purchasing another work of art for this building. That would not surprise anyone. After all, we still have not seen the opposition's arts policy coming out of the last election. Who can forget Senator Michael Baume struggling on Lateline saying, `We have an arts policy, but I haven't been authorised to release it yet'?

TALK.START.PARA: —This bloke's a spiv and you know it.
—Order! Senator Alston, to describe the Prime Minister as a spiv is unparliamentary. I ask that you withdraw it.

—Mr Deputy President, I am interested that you divined immediately that I happened to be referring to the Prime Minister, because I did not mention his name. If it is that obvious to you, I certainly withdraw it.

—Mr Deputy President, I ask a supplementary question. I know that Senator Robert Ray is not a member of Mr Keating's imperial faction in New South Wales, but, as more of a traditional Labor man, a man who has a better sense of Labor's history and traditions, could he just address himself to the question I put to him and leave all the personal abuse aside. Would it not be better for the $100,000 that Mr Keating insisted—
—You slimy hypocrite.
—Order! Senator Faulkner, that was a most unparliamentary expression. I would be grateful if you would withdraw it.
—I withdraw the fact that I called Senator Kemp a slimy hypocrite.
—Order! I do not know, Senator Faulkner, that you add to the decorum of this chamber by repeating that which I asked you to withdraw in the first place.

—It is extraordinary that when one speaks to the modern Labor Party about old Labor traditions one gets that type of abuse, and I predicted that. I ask Senator Robert Ray to address this question specifically. Would not the $100,000 that has been spent on the Gould art works on the instructions of Mr Keating have been better spent on emergency relief for the unemployed in Mr Keating's electorate of Blaxland?

—I make the point that Parliament House continues to purchase art works. If Senator Kemp wants to challenge that, he may. What we have had here today is a continuation of the Chaney line when those over there with very fond memories talk about what they regard as a traditional Labor member of parliament, which I am not; I am quite different from what went in the past, as are most of my colleagues. The traditional Labor member of parliament those opposite used to love was a person who could not read opinion polls, who did not know how to raise money and who could not match them in this chamber or outside. I can tell Senator Kemp that times change and some piece of left-over rubbish from a think-tank is all those opposite have on their side.

—Mr Deputy President, I raise a point of order. I am having trouble directing Senator Ray to the question. I ask him to avoid the personal abuse that those opposite like so much. I asked whether the $100,000 would not have been better spent on emergency relief for the unemployed. Could Senator Ray address himself to that particular question.
—Order! There is no point of order. I have ruled on that.

—My question is directed to the Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services. Is the minister aware of the announcement last week by the Minister for Industrial Relations, Laurie Brereton, and the Minister for Industry, Technology and Regional Development, Alan Griffiths, on the Australian construction industry pre-qualification criteria? If so, can he advise what his department is doing to implement it?

—Obviously, yes, I am aware of this issue, because it is significant in terms of the activities of my department. It builds on the very worthwhile initiatives of 1991 establishing the Construction Industry Development Agency.

PARA.TAB: As Senator Devereux says, my ministerial colleagues announced a proposal for pre-qualification criteria, which were accurately described in the Australian Financial Review as a set of tough standards that are designed to help educate the industry away from the ways that flourished in the dark, dirty and dangerous days of the late 1980s building boom; to establish new ethical and professional norms; and to set in motion a virtuous cycle where industry players try to outdo each other on quality rather than underbid each other on price.

I am also advised that from a broader national perspective these criteria will better enable Australian companies to compete in South-East Asia. The criteria have been developed by the industry for the industry, unlike the confrontationist approach used by the New South Wales and Western Australian governments in implementing the codes of practice in the building industry in those states.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Burke, Dowding, Lawrence governments, was it?

—No, it is actually the incompetence of Senator Panizza's current contemporaries and colleagues that is causing the problem. I thank Senator Panizza for giving me the opportunity to make it clear. I was trying to be more moderate about it, but if the honourable senator wishes to raise this matter, it is Mr Kierath and his incompetence that is the cause of the problem in Western Australia.

PARA.TAB: Over the next 18 months there will be a range of important criteria. In the first instance, the Australian government will be the primary user of the criteria, which will apply to government contracts, including those of government business enterprises. The government is committed to using its purchasing power as an important element in bringing about reform in the construction industry.

Within my own department, Australian Estate Management, which manages the government's investment in real estate, will require contractors who want to tender for AEM contracts valued at more than $5 million to provide the complete range of information specified by the CIDA criteria. Contractors will be invited to tender only if they meet the appropriate standards. Other business units within my portfolio will assist agencies. There will be involvement of Australian Construction Services, Asset Services and others. Through the services they provide to other Commonwealth agencies, they will assist these agencies to assess whether or not contractors meet the appropriate standards.

So it is an initiative by my colleagues which I welcome. There is a role for my department in implementing it on behalf of the Commonwealth. Broadly and nationally, it will continue the increase in productivity and industrial harmony in the important construction industry.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. In light of information released under FOI regarding the Thai mahogany dining room table proposed for the Lodge by the Prime Minister, can the minister explain to the Senate why the Prime Minister sought to mislead the Australian people on the John Laws program when he implied that it was Ms Betteridge who found the table? When will the Prime Minister issue a public apology to Ms Betteridge, whose reputation has been clearly damaged by this Prime Minister's cowardly and desperate attempt to extricate himself from this scandal?

—I am not quite sure which information Senator Hill was referring to, but when the Australiana Council was looking at replacement of a table in the Lodge, it was raised at a meeting at which Mr Keating was present. A number of options were looked at. The natural option was an English Georgian table, which would have been at a very prohibitive price. It was decided in those discussions that Mr Paul Kenny be contacted. But it was also decided that others would also be approached for quotes on the table. So in regard to that, I do not believe that anything the Prime Minister said on the John Laws program was misleading.

PARA.TAB: In relation to the officer of the Prime Minister's department, I do not believe that the Prime Minister would in any way, from any of his statements, owe her an apology. She ceased her employment at her own choice.

TALK.START.PARA: —After a telephone call from the Prime Minister.

—Yes, there was a telephone call from the Prime Minister, something which any minister is entitled to do if not satisfied with all the events that have occurred. I notice that Senator Hill does not add to what was raised at the estimates committee in that regard. That particular officer was regarded highly enough to be offered a job in Canberra with the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet. There were certain circumstances which meant that she could not accept that offer, which everyone accepts. She was then offered alternative employment in Sydney which she did not find attractive and was then offered, as any other officer would be, the option of taking up a voluntary redundancy, which she chose to do.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Science and Small Business. In 1991, the industry department recommended the formation of a national council for the marketing industry and I understand that the minister recently attended the inaugural meeting of the proposed national marketing services council. Is the minister able to provide any information on the outcome of that meeting and how the proposed council will meet government objectives for the development of the marketing industry in Australia?

—I am delighted to have a question today. I have waited for at least one to come up from the other side but this opposition, being about the worst opposition in the history of the Senate, could not even scratch one up. I am delighted that my colleague Senator Chris Evans has asked this question about the establishment of a national marketing services council.

PARA.TAB: Certainly in 1991 my department had issued a report pointing out the need for there to be an Australian marketing industry council. It had been recognised for some time within the industry that we were not achieving what we ought to be able to achieve as far as the marketing industry in Australia is concerned. Of course, as we become internationally more competitive, one area in which we have to lift our game is marketing. We have good design, good science and good management in Australia, but we are not yet to the stage of being internationally competitive on marketing.

As a result of that initiative by the department, the objectives of such a council would be: to provide a focal point for industry and government communications; to play a more influential role in policy formulation affecting industry and its clients; to develop standards, including the establishment of national accreditation for practitioners; to coordinate courses offered throughout Australia; and to enhance the international competitiveness of the industry with the object of pursuing export opportunities.

The marketing industry includes a broad range of industry groups. At the meeting I attended recently they were all represented. It was the first time they had come together. There were representatives from sections of the industry such as industrial packaging and design, market research, management consultancy, direct marketing, public relations, sales promotion, advertising and other related services.

Up until this time, the industry has not thought of itself as a homogeneous group. It has thought of itself as being too competitive amongst its members, not seeing that there were broader issues at stake, not only for them but also for Australian industry.

As a result of the discussions, we are now hopeful that, within the next year or so, an Australian marketing services council will be established and will be able to achieve sound progress in areas of industry cooperation, national education and training, industry performance and representations to the government resulting in appropriate standards and export earnings by industry participants and domestic customers. I believe that this initiative of the industry, with the assistance of my department, is a very worthwhile one and it further enhances Australia's ability to be internationally competitive.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. I refer the minister to reports reaching the Vietnamese community in Australia that Professor Doan Viet Hoat, a well-known and highly respected human rights activist in Vietnam who earlier this year was imprisoned for 15 years for issuing pamphlets advocating greater freedom and democratisation in Vietnam, was late last week moved into solitary confinement in a prison in Ho Chi Minh City, coinciding with the release in Australia of an article which he had recently written in prison for international human rights day. I ask, firstly, will the Australian government seek full details from the Vietnamese government as to the reasons for and the specific conditions of Professor Hoat's solitary confinement? Secondly, will the minister advise the Senate as to the present situation in respect of the proposed Australian human rights delegation to Vietnam which was agreed during Prime Minister Kiet's visit to Australia earlier this year?

—The government is fully aware of the case of Dr Hoat, although we have not received the information presented by Senator Short as to his current whereabouts and state of health. We will seek confirmation and, if this is forthcoming, we will pursue the matter with the Vietnamese authorities. Senator Gareth Evans did so in his discussions with the Vietnamese Prime Minister, Vo Van Kiet, on 27 May this year. The Australian embassy in Hanoi did also in November 1992 and in March this year.

PARA.TAB: I think Senator Short asked about the delegation and the prospects of that. We are in an advanced stage of putting the delegation together. Our feeling is that it should ideally consist of members of this parliament, three; academics with a strong background in human rights and Vietnam, two; Vietnamese Australians of some standing, two. It would be supported by officials from the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade.

There will be further discussions with the Vietnamese foreign ministry this week on the composition, objectives and itinerary of the delegation. It would not be appropriate to release further details of the delegation's composition until we have had the opportunity to discuss these questions with the Vietnamese government.

As to timing, we are aiming for the week beginning 7 March 1993 and we will be doing what we can to ensure that there is no further slippage. However, it must be remembered that the delegation can only travel with the agreement of the Vietnamese authorities. We are nevertheless taking every opportunity to impress on the Vietnamese government the importance with which the delegation is regarded in Australia. We would find it strange if Prime Minister Kiet's personal undertaking were not soon followed up with action to facilitate this visit.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Transport and Communications. One of the greatest impediments to transport efficiency in Australia has been the range of different and often conflicting state regulations on road transport operations. Can the minister advise what progress has been made in developing national uniformity in road transport regulation?

—Honourable senators would be aware that the inconsistencies between state regulations affecting road transport are a direct impediment to the free flow of interstate freight and to the efficiency of road transport operators and vehicle manufacturers. Over the last two years the Commonwealth and the states and territories have been working together to rid Australia of this anachronism.

PARA.TAB: The National Road Transport Commission was established by this government in 1991 to develop proposals for uniform systems of heavy vehicle regulation and registration charges for consideration by Australian governments. A national charging regime has been proposed for implementation in July 1995. The NRTC is now focusing on the development of a comprehensive set of regulations to be progressively incorporated into umbrella legislation. This approach has been adopted so that specific segments of regulation can be applied as they are agreed to. This will give the industry more rapid access to the savings and the greater efficiencies being made available by these new standards.

The Road Transport Reform (Vehicles and Traffic) Bill 1993 has been passed by the Senate and is currently before the House of Representatives. States and territories will be introducing complementary legislation early next year. The first set of regulations to be incorporated into this legislation was last week accepted—or not disapproved—by Australian transport ministers, without a dissenting vote.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I raise a point of order. Is the minister making a ministerial statement, or has he simply lost his nerve and is reading the second answer of the day?
—There is no point of order.

—Mr Deputy President, as I was about to say before I was so rudely interrupted, these heavy vehicle standards establish rules for the design and construction of all vehicles over 4.5 tonnes, regardless of where they were built. The NRTC has estimated that aspects of these regulations—Senator Alston may be interested to hear this—will result in annual savings to the transport industry of in excess of $70 million a year. Regulations on mass and loading, road worthiness, driving hours and traffic are currently being drafted in consultation with interested parties and will be considered by Australian transport ministers over the coming months.

PARA.TAB: It is appropriate that this first set of regulations was agreed to as the road transport industry embarked on its road transport awareness week. The road transport industry is relying heavily on governments to deliver a sensible system of transport regulations which will allow it to get on with its business while ensuring a safe road environment. It is incumbent on all governments to work within the framework being established by the NRTC and to maintain our joint commitment to remove the anomalies of the past.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister representing the Special Minister of State, who I think has been given the task of answering Mabo questions. I ask the minister to explain why the government's draft Mabo legislation, according to page 1 of the Australian of 15 November, will establish a native title tribunal which will not be `bound by technicalities, legal forms and rules of evidence', when Senator Gareth Evans, in answer to a question on 28 October in this place about the application of the normal rules of evidence in state courts considering Mabo issues, said:

QUESTION.PARA: I cannot imagine any context in which it would be necessary to address that issue.

TALK.START.PARA: —I suggest that Senator Panizza—he will not have to wait very long—examine the bill when it is introduced into the Senate. He will then see the correctness of Senator Evans's statement. Senator Panizza, as a Western Australian, would be far better involved in prevailing upon his conservative colleagues in Western Australia to withdraw the totally obnoxious piece of legislation that Western Australia—

PARA.TAB: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —I have just answered it categorically. I have just asserted that Senator Evans's statement is correct.

—Mr Deputy President, I raise a point of order concerning relevance. Could you please instruct the minister to answer the question from Senator Panizza. There was no reference to the Western Australian legislation in the question. The minister is not answering the question. He should either answer it or be asked to sit down.
—Order! I have been listening carefully and thus far I am satisfied that Senator Collins is addressing the question.

—Mr Deputy President, I am sure that as a Western Australian you will be extremely interested to hear my answer. I have just said categorically in response to the question that if Senator Panizza looks at the bill—and I am sure that a copy of it will be available—he will see the correctness of the statement.
—Is that your answer? Ha, ha!
—Perhaps Senator Giggle could restrain himself for a minute. I have just asserted that that bill will demonstrate the correctness of the answer that Senator Evans gave this Senate.

PARA.TAB: The more important question, of course, is where the lines have been drawn in this Mabo debate. The totally obnoxious piece of legislation that has been introduced in Western Australia by the Court government is centred on clause 7 of the bill, which purports to totally extinguish native title rights and replace them with a right of traditional possession.

The bill makes it clear that that right, such as it is, is totally subservient to any other rights that anyone else has in the land. Just in case anyone thinks that that is giving Aboriginal people too much of a fair go, at the end of the division of that bill it is made clear that the Western Australian minister can remove even these rights, such as they are, by simply the publication of a notice. The crucial thing is that, on the public record so far, the Leader of the Opposition, to his credit, the Deputy Leader of the Opposition and the shadow Treasurer have categorically stated their position in opposition to the effect of clause 7 of the Western Australian legislation.

On the other hand, the shadow minister for Mabo, who has had two bob each way in the last 24 hours; the shadow minister for infrastructure; and, of course, most importantly, the shadow leader of the opposition, Senator Bishop, have all lined themselves up on the opposite side of the fence. It is a crucial issue because, for the opposition, the issue of Mabo has become the issue of the leadership of the federal coalition. In the last 24 hours, statements made by Mr Reith—

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I raise a point of order. The minister's comments are not in line with the question. The question was a very specific one about Senator Evans's comments in this chamber. It has nothing to do with the matters that Senator Collins is now discussing. I ask you to rule him out of order.
—I am satisfied that the minister is addressing the question, however discursive that may be.
—I am in fact drawing to the conclusion of my answer. The real difficulty for the coalition is that in the last 24 hours Mr Reith's comments appear to have indicated—

—Mr Deputy President, I raise a point of order. The relevance to the question of the coalition's position simply is not there. The question which was put was about something that Senator Evans had said. Senator Collins has made no attempt to answer it at all, despite asking for questions on Mabo for weeks. He was given the question today. This is his first opportunity to answer such a question. He has finally been given permission by the Prime Minister to answer Mabo questions and he has totally ducked it. He can do that if he wishes, but he then cannot be allowed to answer something that is entirely different. He has no entitlement at all to divert into a frolic on coalition policy. It is totally irrelevant and he ought to be brought to order. Three attempts have been made to bring him back on the issue of relevance.

—Mr Deputy President, on the point of order: the opposition has been pleading with Senator Collins to answer a question, which he is doing, on Mabo. I make this point: Senator Collins has made one or two very mild criticisms of the opposition in his answer. It was only at that point, of course, that Senator Kemp and Senator Hill rose to their feet to object to the answer that Senator Collins was giving. They know that Senator Collins is in order, and I ask you to rule accordingly.
—Order! Senator Collins, in response to the point of order, I believe that I have been generous thus far. It would be helpful if you would be more pertinent in response to the question.

—In respect of the comments that have been made in the last 24 hours by Mr Reith, it appears that the senior leadership group of the coalition is about to be rolled on this question, particularly by the shadow leader of the opposition—

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator Bishop

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I raise a point of order. The minister was clearly flouting your ruling and you were very properly upholding a ruling made by Sir Magnus Cormack in 1973, further upheld by President Sibraa. It said that if a minister chooses to answer a question:

INTERJECT.PARA: . . . the Minister should confine himself to points contained in the question with such explanation only as will render the answer intelligible. In all cases an answer must be relevant to the question.
In other words, Mr Deputy President, would you please rule formally that the minister was out of order so that he will not make the same mistake again.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I am satisfied that I am able to make a determination about this question. Senator Collins, I ask you now to direct your reply to the question that was asked of you.
—This is the last sentence.
—Senator Collins, I invite you not to breach the ruling I have made.

—The fundamental difference, of course, between our respective positions on this issue is that the government's approach is fundamentally fair and the approach of the alternative is fundamentally unfair.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Family Services. My question refers to the Keating government's election commitment to extend sales tax exemption to goods used by child-care services. Can the Minister advise the Senate of the implementation date of the exemption? What steps will be taken to inform eligible services of procedures for claiming the exemption? Which types of services will benefit from this measure?

—The government announced in the election and delivered in the budget an exemption from sales tax of goods used in the provision of child care services. The exemption will apply to a number of Commonwealth and state funded child care service types. They include long day care centres, outside school hours care services, vacation care services, coordination units within family day care and occasional care services. Private child care services will also be eligible for the exemption. This exemption from sales tax will apply to items such as consumables, toys, education materials and so on used by the centre in the delivery of comprehensive child care.

PARA.TAB: I will also have the discretion to allow exemption of similar child care services as long as they meet public guidelines to be agreed with the Assistant Treasurer. The exemption will apply from the date of royal assent to the amendment to the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Act 1992. That bill passed through the House of Representatives in October and is expected to be introduced into the Senate on 22 November this year. Following the passage of this legislation through both houses, my department will write to all eligible centres advising them of the process for claiming the exemption.

There has been a lot of confusion and concern in the electorate; so I am pleased to have the opportunity to clarify that, as soon as the legislation is passed, we will be advising all centres of their eligibility for that exemption and how they can claim it. This is another example of a promise made and a promise kept. This is certainly very much part of the government's commitment to reducing the cost of child care.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Deputy Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Robert Ray), to a question without notice asked by Senator Hill this day, relating to the former fine arts adviser in the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet, Mrs Betteridge.

SPEECH.PARA: Mrs Betteridge has been treated appallingly by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and the Senate should continue to pursue this matter to ensure that she ultimately receives the apology that she deserves. What happened in relation to the Thai mahogany table was that Mrs Betteridge was directed to the Prime Minister's friend Mr Kenny in search of this table. When this became a political embarrassment to the Prime Minister, he decided that the staff member of the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet concerned, Mrs Betteridge, should be the one that took the rap. That is appalling.

PARA.TAB: The Prime Minister went on the John Laws program to dob her in. Through that program, he firstly wanted to make clear to the Australian people that it was Mrs Betteridge who found the table and that he had nothing to do with it. He was specifically asked by John Laws:

SPEECH.PARA: Who found one?
This is referring to the table. The Prime Minister said:
Well, it was found by, I think in the first instance, the person you mentioned, Ms Betteridge.
There was no mention of the Prime Minister's involvement at all. The interview continues:
JL: She found the table to begin with?
PM: Yes.

The second half of the exercise involved the Prime Minister's embarrassment when he was forced to return the table because it was outside the guidelines of the Australiana Fund. Rather than face up to that responsibility himself, it was again Mrs Betteridge who took the blame. John Laws specifically asked:
Why did she then disapprove of it?
Again this is referring to the purchase of this table. The Prime Minister said:
Look, I think this is the revenge of the `hyphenated names'.
The interview further continues:
JL: Why did Margaret Betteridge change her mind?
PM: I think that a bit of peer group pressure probably got to her. That is, some of the other hyphens on the committee suggested it wasn't ideologically pure enough.

The evidence before us now demonstrates that the Prime Minister was deliberately misleading the Australian people in those answers, at a cost to Mrs Betteridge. He had no concern as to her position in this matter whatsoever. I remind honourable senators, to put the matter in context, that the Prime Minister, being unhappy with Mrs Betteridge and wanting to demonstrate that she should take the rap, telephoned her and, to use his words, expressed his disquiet about the serious inaccuracies and reflections on his role in this matter, after which Mrs Betteridge felt that she had no alternative but to accept voluntarily retirement from the department.

PARA.TAB: What has changed is that under FOI a number of documents are now on the public record which were not there at the time of the estimates committee. I refer honourable senators very briefly—I have only a minute—to just a few of those documents. A minute dated 20 November 1992 and signed by Bryan Hoffmann of the Official Establishments Section states:

SPEECH.PARA: He . . .
the Prime Minister—
suggested Paul Kenny would be able to undertake the work using Malaysian mahogany logged under approved contracts.
There was no suggestion that Mrs Betteridge was going out to find the table from Mr Kenny; the Prime Minister suggested it. A minute from Mrs Betteridge dated 24 November 1992 states:
He. . .
the Prime Minister—
suggested that there were two options available to us which were:
(i) to purchase an English Georgian table . . .

(ii) to commission Paul Kenny to reproduce a Georgian dining table, constructed specifically to meet the requirements of The Lodge. He suggested that there was a small quantity of mahogany from Thailand which could be obtained and used. It was agreed that the Fine Arts Adviser would approach Mr Paul Kenny and undertake some preliminary investigation and costing.
This was the Prime Minister directing Mrs Betteridge to go to Mr Kenny. I move to her next minute, dated 14 December 1992, in which she said:
The Prime Minister has previously discussed this matter with him. Mr Kenny has seen the dinning room at The Lodge and is aware of the issues involved.
It continues:
The Prime Minister clearly expressed his preference for having Paul Kenny's involvement and mentioned specifically the style, the timber, and an approximate cost.

The Prime Minister was not only directing the officials to Mr Kenny but referring to the style, the timber and the approximate cost. This is the Prime Minister who went on the John Laws program and said that Mrs Betteridge found the table of her own initiative from the dealer, Mr Kenny. He was deliberately misleading and deliberately suggesting that he had no direct responsibility.

PARA.TAB: In that same minute is the first suggestion, back in December 1992, by Mrs Betteridge that there would be difficulty under the Australiana Fund guidelines in purchasing it.

In all these documents, which are now on the public record and can be perused, the Prime Minister misled the Australian people in that John Laws program. Mrs Betteridge has been severely wronged and is deserving of an apology.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Family Services (Senator Crowley), to a question without notice asked by Senator Childs this day, relating to the program, Stop Violence Against Women.

SPEECH.PARA: I was most interested in the minister's comments about what she believes this program can achieve by way of community education. The minister said that the program puts the message into the community that real men do not bash or rape women. It is a pity that one of her Labor colleagues in the New South Wales parliament does not share her view. I find it somewhat ironic that, on the very day that Senator Crowley has chosen to tell the Senate about this particular program, a Labor state colleague has been reported as saying that `domestic violence hysteria' is equivalent to the witch-hunts of the 17th century or McCarthyism in the United States in the 1950s. He further stated that domestic violence offenders are `decent citizens' who should not be locked up.

PARA.TAB: I hope Senator Crowley will address the issue that that raises and the issue that her colleague has raised in that regard and do something about practising at home what the government is preaching abroad. It should get its own house in order and address the issue of the sorts of attitudes that this New South Wales Labor member has expressed.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp Sen C.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Deputy Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Robert Ray), to a question without notice asked by Senator Kemp this day, relating to lithographs purchased as part of the Parliament House art collection.

SPEECH.PARA: My question to Senator Robert Ray went to the core of what I think is widespread concern in the community about the behaviour of Mr Keating and the way he operates as the Prime Minister of this country. He seems to regard himself, as some of the cartoonists have so aptly described him, as a Sun King acting in a totally imperial way. Clearly, Mr Keating has become a bit worried about some of the criticisms which have been made in the press about his concentration on artwork and the very significant expenditures which have been involved. In a doorstop interview Mr Keating complained that other people in his position—the John Curtins, Ben Chifleys and Robert Menzies—were not subjected to this sort of critique.

PARA.TAB: The point I would make is that the John Curtins, Ben Chifleys, Robert Menzies and Malcolm Frasers simply did not involve themselves in the type of activities that Mr Keating is involving himself in. I cannot believe that Ben Chifley or John Curtin would have been remotely worried about the artwork on the cabinet wall, or would have been the slightest bit concerned about the quality of the dining table at the Lodge, or would have spent hours looking at the quality of lights for the dining room—all at great cost to the taxpayer, I might say.

There is a very great concern in the community—amongst not only people on our side of the parliament but also Labor supporters—that we have a man who sees his role as Prime Minister in rather an imperial way, and as meaning that he can act in an arbitrary way without proper processes. We have seen this in relation to the staffing at the Lodge where four or five members of the Prime Minister's staff have been moved on or dismissed since he came there and, as far as I can see—particularly in the three recent cases which were brought before the estimates committee—all without the reasonable due process that one would expect.

No-one queries the Prime Minister's right to choose whoever he wants to be his personal staff, but no-one has the right not to treat these people fairly and with decency. He should have acted in a way in which most Australians—and one would have thought particularly a Labor Prime Minister who lectures so ceaselessly to the private sector all the time—would have acted in relation to these people who were dismissed. The pattern of behaviour that we are seeing here is causing great concern on the Labor side of the parliament that Mr Keating is not a true Labor man.

The Prime Minister constantly harks back to the true believers, but the true believers would be devastated by the number of unemployed and homeless in this country. That is what the true believers would be concerned about. They would not be worried about Gould prints in the cabinet room, nor would they be worried about whether or not the butler is wearing striped pants when he serves dinner at the Lodge. I do not believe that any Prime Minister in this country would be remotely worried about those things, but not so Mr Keating.

When I asked this question of Senator Ray, I must admit I was a bit concerned, because Senator Robert Ray is well known as a man who does not speak to the Prime Minister and the Prime Minister does not speak to Senator Ray. Therefore, it is probably a bit unfair to press Senator Ray for the Prime Minister's opinion on some issue. But I asked Senator Ray what I thought was a reasonable question: rather than spending an additional $100,000 on Gould prints for Mr Keating's cabinet room, would it not have been better to think how this money could have been better spent? If $100,000 is available to indulge the artistic taste of Mr Keating, maybe $100,000 is available to help with emergency relief for families who find themselves without food, who are homeless and so forth.

It is a question which I believe only the modern Labor Party would have difficulty in answering. If we were to ask any traditional Labor person—and, indeed, any person on this side—where $100,000 would be better spent in this current climate, none of them would have any difficulty whatsoever in answering. But Senator Ray had a major problem in trying to justify the actions of the Prime Minister. (Time expired)

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Science and Small Business and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on the motion, moved by Senator Kemp, that Senator Ray's answer to his question be noted. I think both the question and the five minutes we have heard just now from Senator Kemp indicate just how bereft the opposition is. Today in question time, when one would have thought there would be questions on such major issues as the future of trade in our region with the APEC conference about to take place, economic development in Australia and Mabo—when we have all of that—we had one question right at the end on Mabo and several questions attacking the Prime Minister (Mr Keating).

PARA.TAB: What I am particularly amazed about is Senator Kemp's complaint about the cost of the paintings for the cabinet room. I just want to point out that these paintings are not, of course, for Mr Keating's personal use; they belong to the parliament, to the public. If we are going to be really upset about $100,000 being spent there, how about those opposite standing up and explaining the waste of the $93,000 that Senator Bishop has spent travelling all around Australia campaigning for the leadership of the Liberal Party. She is able to do that under the entitlements which have been made available to all federal members of parliament. But do not tell me she is going around to every one of those Liberal Party meetings talking about her parliamentary duties; she is purely talking about her desire to become leader of the Liberal Party. I have to say to Senator Kemp that that $93,000 could certainly be better spent.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I raise a point of order. I ask you to rule whether that is a reflection on Senator Bishop. Senator Schacht could equally apply that argument to every trip that any one of us takes every week in that in some instances we talk to members of our own party and at the same time we talk to the public generally. Why should the minister be able to reflect upon Senator Bishop in the sense that he, in effect, suggests that there is something improper in that? I put it to you, Mr Deputy President, that he should not be able to get away with that and that you should rule accordingly.

—Mr Deputy President, on the point of order: I made it clear that Senator Bishop was not breaking the rules as they are laid down, but I would point out that most of us travel to and from this parliament to carry out our parliamentary duties. It is quite clear that Senator Bishop is travelling all over Australia and has a bill for a backbencher way beyond that of any other backbencher. Senator Patterson might like to argue—
—Senator Schacht, order!

—So I just say that the point of order which has been raised, suggesting that I am my reflecting on Senator Bishop, is not true at all. I am raising a comparison. People are complaining about $100,000 for paintings for the cabinet room, which belong to the public, and I am just comparing that with public money being spent by Senator Bishop in her role of going around trying to become leader of the Liberal Party.

—Order! Senator Schacht, I believe that a normal and sensible interpretation of your comments is that you are, by inference, casting aspersions on Senator Bishop. It might be more appropriate if you would take a different line of argument from this point on.

—Thank you, Mr Deputy President. I just want to refer to some of Senator Kemp's remarks. He referred to good Labor people—good Labor men, I suppose; he would never use `Labor women', which I think reflects his sexist attitudes. He went on to say that even the true believers would be upset. I have to say that there are still plenty of true believers around in the Labor Party, both within this parliament and within the community.

PARA.TAB: I also want to point out—and this gets to the real nub of the issue—that the opposition still has not psychologically got used to the idea that it lost the last election. That is what really irks those opposite. They attack the Prime Minister because they cannot believe he beat them. That is the problem—

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I rise on a point of order. There is a real issue of relevance here which my colleague Senator Hill raised, and you instructed Senator Schacht to come back to the point. What we were debating is whether Mr Keating should have spent $100,000 on the Gould paintings. If Senator Schacht thinks the Prime Minister should have, he should get up and say so. If Senator Schacht is embarrassed about it, he should say that he should not have. But Senator Schacht should not travel far and wide. What he is saying now has nothing to do with the matters that have been raised.

—Order! I am capable of making a ruling from what I have heard thus far. On the last occasion, I did not rule on relevance; I ruled on another matter. The procedure thus far in this chamber in respect of taking note of answers has been that debate can be wide ranging. I am of the view that Senator Schacht is embracing the general thrust of the matters that have been raised in respect of the question and answer.

—Thank you, Mr Deputy President. Senator Kemp raised the issue of true believers and good Labor people and I am responding to that. I think this is very relevant. The point I want to make is that here today the opposition has not been willing to take on the major issues that are before the Australian people; it has not been willing to take on and debate Mabo.

PARA.TAB: In the last three days the opposition leader announced that all previous statements he has made about Mabo and all discussion papers were—to paraphrase Ronald Ziegler of the President Nixon era—`no longer operative' and that the opposition is now going to start anew. This is despite the fact that during the middle of the year Dr Hewson travelled all around Australia to Aboriginal communities telling them that he supported native title in all its various forms, that he would look after them and that he was understanding.

When it came to the crunch in the last three days, that all went out the window. When he counted up the numbers he found that the Western Australian Liberal Party, the John Howard group and Bronwyn's group—whoever want to put their hands up for Bronwyn—were against him and he realised that he no longer had the support. So he had to junk everything that he had previously said.

That is why we are not getting any debate on Mabo here today. That is why we are not getting any debate or discussion from the opposition on economic issues. One would have thought that one question from the opposition today may have been about APEC, about the NAFTA agreement in America, and the consequences for Australia's economy. This was not likely from this mob. The opposition was back attacking the Prime Minister at a personal level. That is typical of the opposition. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise very briefly to follow up what Senator Schacht had to say about Senator Bishop's $93,000, or whatever, bill for flying around Australia. His words were—and correct me if I am wrong—that she was flying around not talking about anything else but the leadership.
—That's right. She admitted it herself.

—He has just admitted that he said it. The point is that I attended at least four of those talks that she gave around Australia—one in Sydney and three in Perth. I listened to all of those talks and I can say that she never mentioned the leadership. How can Senator Schacht say that this is what she is travelling around Australia to do? She is going around Australia to present our policies.
—Ha, ha!

—Senator Zakharov can laugh as much as she likes, but she should not be so ignorant and listen sometimes. The point is that on the three or four occasions that I heard Senator Bishop speak she did not mention the leadership. She has gone out of her way to say that John Hewson's leadership is intact, and I fully agree with that.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CROWLEY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Family Services and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I seek leave to make some remarks in response to Senator Patterson's comments.

—Mr Deputy President, I raise a point of order. Could you rule whether this is within the half-hour that we are given to move to take note of answers. The matter that Senator Crowley wants to talk about was finished long ago.
