—Order! If leave is granted, the time used by Senator Crowley will come within the 30 minutes. Failing that, Senator Crowley may seek leave at the expiration of the 30 minutes. Senator Crowley is seeking leave to speak now. Is leave granted?

PARA.TAB: Leave not granted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Collins), to a question without notice asked by Senator Panizza this day, relating to native title.

SPEECH.PARA: The question which I asked today of Senator Collins was the first question he has been allowed to answer on Mabo. Of course, we know what happened: he gave a non-answer completely. My question was very specific. I will quote from the Australian of 15 November. There are various dot points, but I will read the one that was part of my question:

PARA.TAB: The new national native title tribunal will not be "bound by technicalities, legal forms and rules of evidence", but parties can summons and cross-examine witnesses.

SPEECH.PARA: For the information of Senator Collins, I point out that I did read the draft legislation on Mabo that Mr Keating—or someone from Mr Keating's office, or somewhere like that—caused to fall off the back of a truck. Senator Collins invited me to wait until the legislation was presented to parliament, but I will take it that the legislation that was dropped off the back of a truck is somewhere near what is going to come.

PARA.TAB: I asked the question on the basis that Senator Gareth Evans, in answer to a question on 28 October about the normal rules of evidence, said:

SPEECH.PARA: I cannot imagine any context in which it would be necessary to address that issue.
In other words, I take it—and I cannot see any reason for reading it any other way—that what he meant was that of course there will be the standard application of normal rules of evidence.

PARA.TAB: Then we had Senator Collins today saying—if the notes that my office wrote down are correct—that of course Senator Evans was correct. They cannot both be correct because they are totally different answers. What the Australian reported, which ties up with the draft legislation anyhow, is totally different from what Senator Evans said. I cannot see that Senator Collins could say either `I did not understand the situation' or `Senator Evans was correct'. Then, of course, he went on, rather than answering it, to try to blaze down the Western Australian situation, but that is a debate for another day.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tell us what your colleagues in Western Australia are saying.

—I am on public record. I fully support the Western Australian line. I have said that many other times. I cannot see how Senator Collins, waiting for a question on Mabo all this time that he was not entrusted with questions—and the Prime Minister obviously entrusted them only to Senator Evans, when he was here—could give such a conflicting answer.

PARA.TAB: Senator Collins absolutely dodged the question. What the Australian said came straight out of the draft legislation. I have the draft legislation; no doubt he has the latest legislation, which will not be much different from the draft that someone dropped off the back of a truck on Friday. I would like a further explanation of the statements he made or of what the Australian had to say, because they are totally conflicting with what Senator Evans said last week.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Transport and Communications)

TALK.START.PARA: —Reference to the Hansard will of course show that I answered the question. Senator Panizza may note when he reads the bill that these processes are going to be carried out by courts. The assumption he has made is that there is going to be a total abandonment of court processes.

PARA.TAB: Without turning this into a prolonged debate, I simply refer Senator Panizza to the operation of, for example, the Northern Territory land rights act, which has operated under this kind of regime for 17 years and has done so very successfully and without any complaints from legal counsel. Those procedures provide flexibility to acknowledge the kind of evidence that has been taken, the circumstances in which it has been taken and the land rights. Of course, it was oversighted by very distinguished judges of the Federal Court. One of the judges, the first in fact, is now a distinguished member of the High Court—the Hon. Justice John Toohey.

I personally attended many hours of hearings of land claims before the Land Commissioner. The commission routinely sat away from a court situation. In fact, I can remember on a number of land rights commission hearings in Kakadu National Park actually standing in the physical vicinity of sacred sites, in the middle of flood plains in Kakadu. I recall one hearing at South Alligator River.

The important thing—and this is what I am saying to Senator Panizza—is that this is nothing radical, unique or new. These opportunities already exist in the court system. Although that additional flexibility is provided for, the fundamental fairness on which the rule of law operates in Australia and on which courts operate in Australia continues to operate under that system. So Senator Panizza has nothing to fear from that process.

I reiterate, because it is relevant, that Senator Panizza, coming from Western Australia, would do far better directing his attention to prevailing upon his Western Australian colleagues to remove from the parliament the totally obnoxious piece of legislation on native title they have introduced. The central clause in that legislation is clause 7, which purports to provide a blanket extinguishment of native title, despite the fact that the High Court has ruled that it is now part of the common law of this country.

I add that that legislation has been assailed by a number of people among whom—I would have thought Senator Panizza would have paid some attention to this—are three distinguished former members of the coalition's front bench. Peter Durack, a former federal Attorney-General, has comprehensively attacked these proposals, as have Fred Chaney and Ian Viner QC, both former ministers for aboriginal affairs.

Mr Viner described the Western Australian legislation as being discriminatory and racially based. But more importantly and correctly, Ian Viner said that the bill will utterly fail to provide the certainty which everybody in Australia is demanding because it does breach the Racial Discrimination Act. There will be legal challenges to it and in the view of this government, and I think most legal commentators in Australia, the legislation will fail.

So not only is the legislation utterly obnoxious and fundamentally unfair, as opposed to the bottom line of the Commonwealth legislation which is fundamentally fair—that is the difference between the two—but also it is going to fail utterly to provide the certainty required, as Ian Viner QC accurately said, because it will be subjected to legal challenge which ultimately, in my view, the view of Ian Viner and the view of this government, will be successful.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise—
—Order! Senator Crane, it has been brought to my attention that the time for consideration of this matter has expired.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CROWLEY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Family Services and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I wish to add to comments that I made in answer to a question from Senator Patterson. From what I was able to hear of the question, there seemed to be a suggestion that perhaps our community education program against domestic violence ought be discredited a little because of the comments of my Labor Party colleague in New South Wales, Mr Nagle MP.

PARA.TAB: If the comments attributed to Mr Nagle in the article in the Sydney Morning Herald are true, they are clear evidence of why we need a community education program directed to changing attitudes. It is with great disappointment and amazement that I read these comments from any politician at all. They seem to suggest that there is still a lot of distance to travel in the community education program about violence. It is totally unacceptable to say that there are any ways in which we could tolerate or allow degrees of violence against women. It is a major problem. It is a crime. It is causing tremendous devastation to individuals and huge costs to society.

If I misunderstood Senator Patterson, then I completely withdraw my earlier comments. I got the impression that she was suggesting that she could disparage the community education program because people still had these attitudes.

TALK.START.PARA: —No!

—I say on the record that it is precisely because of these attitudes that we have such a community education program where more and more non-violent men are speaking out with women against violence against women. I hope Mr Nagle is able to get a copy of that education program and rethink his views.

—by leave—I was not casting aspersions on the minister's program. I was saying that it is ironical that, on the very day that she launched the next stage of the policy and program, one of her own Labor colleagues made such an outrageous statement. She said she hoped he had got the message. Maybe she should give him the message by sending him what she has just said. Then he will get the message loudly and clearly about what we all think of what he said.
—by leave—I want to make some brief remarks about the comments made by Senator Collins in replying to a question asked earlier by Senator Panizza and to support my colleague Senator Panizza.

PARA.TAB: What we saw from Senator Collins was the typical abuse of question time by ministers who sit on the other side of the chamber. Senator Collins could quite easily have given the answer during question time. Instead he chose to show his own set of biases and attack the Western Australian Premier and the Western Australian legislation. That was completely wrong in terms of the procedures of this parliament and that was eventually brought to Senator Collins's notice.

All that Senator Collins did today was to waste the time of this chamber. He would not give a full and proper answer to the question asked by Senator Panizza, which forced Senator Panizza to move that the Senate take note of the answer. As soon as question time was over and the proceedings were no longer being broadcast, Senator Collins came back into the chamber and answered the question. I think that reflects very badly on the way most ministers in this place behave.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It is with deep regret that I inform the Senate of the death, on 10 November 1993, of a former President of the Senate, the Hon. Justin Hilary O'Byrne AO, senator for the state of Tasmania from 1946 to 1981. As a state funeral is being held in Tasmania this afternoon, I understand that it would accord with the wishes of the Senate if a motion of condolence for the deceased was debated at 8 o'clock this evening. I thank the Senate.
—Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Diesel Fuel Rebate Scheme
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned shows:

We the undersigned citizens respectfully submit that the Government's proposal to charge users of off-road diesel fuel a tax equal to one per cent of the amount rebated to them through the Diesel Fuel Rebate Scheme under the Diesel Fuel (Excise Duty Rebate) Administration Charge Bill 1993 and the Diesel Fuel (Customs Duty Rebate) Administration Charge Bill 1993 be abandoned. The Petitioners note particularly that:

1.Users of off-road diesel fuel currently receive a full or partial rebate of fuel excise paid in recognition that they should not have to contribute to road funding and maintenance in the same manner as on-road users of diesel fuel;
2.We object to being forced to pay fuel excise on diesel fuel and then being charged a tax, which the Government is calling an `administration fee', to have that money returned to us as a rebate;
3.This tax sets a dangerous precedent and could lead to governments charging similar taxes on rebates, such as those for personal income tax.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senator Brownhill (from 67 citizens), Senator Sandy Macdonald (from 40 citizens), Senator Ian Macdonald (from 152 citizens) and Senator Tambling (from 19 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Petrol Excise
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia opposes the increase in excise of 7 cents per litre on leaded petrol and 5 cents per litre on unleaded petrol resulting from the Budget. This rise in petrol tax:
1.discriminates against low income families and those living in rural areas
2.increases business costs and will cause further unemployment
3.adds further to the price of an already heavily taxed product
4.breaks Mr Keating's election promise not to put up tax.
And your petitioners therefore pray that the Senate oppose these increases in petrol excise.

PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senator Ian Macdonald (from 120 citizens), Senator Minchin (from 136 citizens) and Senator Tierney (from 625 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Rejection of Increase in Leaded Petrol Tax

PARA.TAB: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
We the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully submit that:
The 1993 Federal Budget announced by the Keating Labor Government to increase the excise on leaded fuel by 10 cents per litre.

PETITION.PARA: is a selective, discriminatory tax on owners of older cars;
discriminates against poorer people and country people who own most of these older cars;
will make it more difficult for people to save to purchase newer, more fuel efficient, less-polluting vehicles;
is therefore counter-productive to reducing lead pollution in the air.

PARA.TAB: Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Senate will reject this increase in fuel excise and that the Senate will urge the Government to take initiatives to reduce the cost of manufacturing cars in Australia, thereby making new cars cheaper to buy.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senator Hill (from 47 citizens) and Senator Minchin (from 140 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Higher Education Contribution Scheme
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Senators assembled in Parliament:

PARA.TAB: This petition of citizens and residents of Australia draws to the attention of the Senate our opposition to specific changes proposed to the Higher Education Funding Act 1988 and associated subordinate legislation in the 1993-94 Federal Budget introduced by the Treasurer in the House of Representatives on Tuesday 17 August 1993.
Specifically, we the undersigned oppose:
(i)proposed measures whereby students taking more than an extra semester to complete their first undergraduate degree accumulate debts at standard HECS rate x 1.5%;
(ii)proposed measures whereby students enrolling in second undergraduate degrees accumulate debts at standard HECS rate x 2; and
(iii)proposed measures whereby the rates of prepayment increase from 2, 3 and 4 per cent of taxable income up to 3, 4 and 5 per cent for the three thresholds respectively.
We strongly urge the Senate to either reject these measures, or to refer them to a Select Committee for further consideration.

PETITION.TITLE: Unrealised Capital Gains and Losses
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

The Petition of the undersigned shows: That the laws passed in December 1992 counting unrealised capital gains on shares held by pensioners as income for the purposes of the social security income test are unfair, illogical and discriminatory, and should be repealed as soon as is practicable.

Your Petitioners ask that the Senate should: (1) note that the Liberal and National Parties now oppose the laws after voting for them in December; (2) condemn the government for persisting with the laws; and (3) take whatever steps are necessary to achieve the repeal of the laws mentioned above.

PETITION.TITLE: HMAS Huon
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned shows:

PETITION.PARA: We the undersigned citizens respectfully submit that the Keating Government's decision to close down HMAS Huon is clearly and demonstrably wrong and should be reversed having regard to:

PARA.TAB: (a)The fact that HMAS Huon has been part of the Royal Australian Navy in Tasmania for over 80 years;
(b)It has continually demonstrated itself to be a most efficient shore-based designated Naval facility and Headquarters for the Royal Australian Navy in Tasmania;

(c)Its closure will place at risk the immediate future in Tasmania of 25 permanent Royal Australian Navy personnel, 108 active Reservists and 40 inactive Reservists and in addition will deprive the Naval Reserve Cadets of their Tasmanian Divisional Headquarters; and, the fact that only a miserable $250,000 will be allegedly saved out of the National Defence budget of over $9 billion,

PETITION.PARA: and therefore call upon the Keating Government to immediately reverse the decision to close HMAS Huon and to give a commitment that it will continue to be the Headquarters of the Royal Australian Navy in Tasmania.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Wine Wholesale Sales Tax
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in parliament assembled. We the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully submit that:

PARA.TAB: The 1993 Federal Budget announcement by the Keating Labor Government to increase wholesale sales tax on wine by more than 50%, from 20% to 31%,

PETITION.PARA: discriminates against the wine industry compared with other beverages;
discriminates against South Australia, which produces 70% of Australia's wine;
threatens the continuing existence of 150 smaller wineries and 500 related jobs;
destroys the capacity for a further $500 million, job-creating investment in the wine industry;
will result in lower grape prices for grapegrowers already burdened by the rural recession;
will severely damage the domestic market base for Australian wine which is so essential to its continuing export growth;

PARA.TAB: Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Senate will reject the increase in wholesale sales tax on wine.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Homeless Rate Benefits
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned shows that:
1.We are concerned that teenagers are able to leave home by obtaining young homeless rate benefits without adequate investigation.
2.We believe that the flawed nature of the guidelines governing eligibility for young homeless rate benefits is in some circumstances encouraging family breakdown.

3.With the number of young people receiving youth homeless rate benefits increasing by a factor of ten over the past six years, we consider that there are insufficient programs to help keep families together.
Your Petitioners ask that the Senate should:
Call on the Government to:
(a) review the guidelines for young homeless rate benefits; and
(b)show a greater commitment to programs which prevent family breakdown.

PETITION.TITLE: Chemical Registration
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

PARA.TAB: We the undersigned respectfully call upon the Federal Government to introduce legislation that will require the National Registration Authority to provide all available information on registered chemicals.

PETITION.TITLE: Stewarts Day Care Centre
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate assembled in parliament:

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned parents and friends of Stewarts Day Care Centre, 47-49 Benowa Road, Southport, 4215 in Queensland, draws to the attention of the Senate that the Federal Government is seeking to link accreditation to eligibility for Childcare Assistance and in the opinion of your petitioners this link will only lead to higher fees for parents and no guarantee for improvement in quality of care for children. We know that quality care cannot be legislated for—it comes from the heart. Please help us help our children.
Your petitioners therefore request the Senate to reject accreditation being linked to Childcare Assistance.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CRANE

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I present to the Senate the following petition, from 1,092 citizens, which is not in conformity with the standing orders as it is not in the correct form:

SPEECH.PARA: To the Honourable President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The Petition of the undersigned shows:
There is general dissatisfaction with the effectiveness of the legislation and industrial award provisions for occupational superannuation,
and

We the undersigned therefore respectfully request the Parliament of Australia to amend the Superannuation Guarantee Charge Legislation so as to place the responsibility for providing superannuated retirement benefits onto the person who will eventually receive the retirement benefit.
and further

We call upon the Parliament to convene as a matter of urgency a National Summit involving representatives from Trade Unions, Employer Organisations and State and Federal Parliament to develop a national strategy for an equitable mechanism to provide retirees with an adequate retirement income.
And your Petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate—
(a)notes, with concern:

TAB.TAB: (i)that the Federal Airports Corporation (FAC) has threatened off-airport car rental companies with revocation of their `authority to trade' at airports unless they sign `Alternative A' Rental Car Contract by 15 November 1993, and

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate requests the Government to:

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Contingent on the Senate, not later than discovery of formal business on Wednesday, 17 November 1993, not being presented with:

PARA.TAB: (a)an instrument revoking amendments 1 and 2 in the Schedule of amendments to the Nursing Homes Financial Arrangements Principles, contained in Principles NHP 4/1993; and
(b)a statement, on behalf of the Government, that:

TAB.TAB: (i)a copy of the instrument of revocation has been tabled in the House of Representatives, and

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: The annual report, as is usually the case with EPAC, is a useful document. It summarises the role of EPAC over the last year in terms of the forum it provides for the discussion and consideration of various matters of economic policy and economic planning in Australia. It plays a very useful role in that respect.

PARA.TAB: The report details the work in which the council has been involved in the last year. During that time it has undertaken and participated in some very important work on issues of national importance, including the FitzGerald national savings review, the Hilmer competition policy review, the Treasury retirement incomes modelling task force and the Dr Michael Keating employment opportunities task force. As well, the council has been asked by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) to act as a sounding board for the ideas being developed by the employment opportunities task force.

What the report understandably fails to point out is that whilst the issues of competition, national savings and employment creation—the matters that it has been dealing with over the last year—are imperative to our nation's success, the present government has done nothing to act upon these reports and nothing substantively to resolve and tackle these national issues. We had a classic example of the lack of resolve by the government in terms of necessary reforms in the last 24 hours.

According to today's press reports, the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) was rolled yesterday on the issue of postal reform. The budget increased the deficit and, therefore, Australia's national debt rather than reducing it. This is despite all the fine rhetoric of the government in terms of its economic aspirations. Far from moving towards the reduction of deficits and the reduction of the national debt, the government's policies have moved in quite the opposite direction.

Despite Mr Keating's pledge on election night to get people back to work, Australia is still choking with an unemployment rate of 11.2 per cent. The government is very deeply divided over a wide range of major policy issues, the most important of which is economic policy. In the last few days we have seen a major split within the government between its two major economic ministers on the future direction of tax and expenditure policies in this country.

I remind the Senate of the now besieged and discredited statement of the Treasurer after the last election, when he said, `I emphasise that this will be achieved without resort to any new taxes.' That was a similar commitment to the one made by the Prime Minister late last year when he was blatantly attempting to buy votes prior to the last election.

In the last couple of days we have had major conflicting statements by the Treasurer and the Minister for Finance (Mr Willis) over future tax rises. It is only a week ago that the Minister for Finance said that the deficit strategy may involve some revenue increases, though the government would be very cautious about introducing any substantial tax increases. He made it quite clear that it was a prospect in the government's mind to increase taxes, yet the Treasurer, Mr Dawkins, said on the other hand that the government was opposed to future tax increases and that these would not occur.

Despite the fine work of organisations such as EPAC, when a government is as divided over major policy issues and the fundamental direction of economic policy as this government is, it is no wonder the economy is in the state that it is in. I hope that the Economic Planning Advisory Council will be able to do more to get the government back on line over the next year.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone Sen A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: It is particularly relevant at this time to be looking at this report since the government is saying, `Well, the recession is over and we are coming out of the worst of it.' It is relevant to actually look at what has happened as a consequence of this government's mismanagement of the economy. I recommend this report to anybody who is interested in seeing the consequences of economic mismanagement. It is a very well prepared report, there is a wide range of information available and it is easily identified by the casually interested reader.

PARA.TAB: I draw attention to page 45 in the chapter dealing with the causes of bankruptcy. On that page there is a list of the major causes of bankruptcy for business bankrupts. Of the 11 causes listed—including lack of capital, lack of business ability, failure to keep proper books and so on—the one factor which stands out as having a much greater influence than any other on bankruptcy is economic conditions.

We all know who has the greatest capacity to influence economic conditions. I do not say for one minute that the government is responsible for everything that goes wrong in the nation in terms of the economy. No-one is so stupid to put that proposition. But the federal government has the greatest capacity to influence the economy. The consequence of this mismanagement is that more and more people have been going bankrupt.

In my state of South Australia bankruptcy has a particular effect on young South Australians. An age profile on page 50 gives an indication of the ages of people in business or not in business who have gone bankrupt. We see that this financial disaster affects the younger portion of the population far more than any other. The figures for the 25 to 34 age group—business people obviously—are very serious. I commend this report to the Senate and anybody who has a particular interest in seeing the consequences of this government's economic mismanagement.

TALK.START.PARA: —Like Senator Vanstone, I was particularly interested in the statistics on page 45 of this report damning as they are of the effects of the government's economic policy. The report says that 35.6 per cent of business bankruptcies are identified not by the bankrupts but by the official receivers and registered trustees as being caused by economic conditions and a further 15.7 per cent of bankruptcies have economic conditions as a contributing factor. So the government is definitely damned by the economic statistics that are contained in this report.

PARA.TAB: I wish to draw attention to a number of areas in the report, particularly the special investigations which have been undertaken by the Office of the Inspector-General and the investigations which have been made in relation to a number of named entities, for example the World Corp International Pty Ltd, World Corp International Pty Ltd (Consultancy), World Corp International (WA), Ascot Credit Assist Pty Ltd and National Assist, which is a division of World Corp International Pty Ltd (Consultancy).

The interesting thing about all of these entities is that they are corporations; therefore, they cannot be trustees of a person's estate either in bankruptcy or under part 10 of the act. These people are holding themselves out as consultants either to the bankrupts themselves or to the creditors. They are saying, `Let us come in and we will rearrange the debtors affairs, spare him from bankruptcy and benefit the creditors.'

I know from my experience, having worked in the field of insolvency, that in many cases these people fail to deliver on any of these promises. It is not as though this is a new phenomenon. Groups of people like these have been in practice in this field for some time. This report quite correctly says that a frequent consequence of their actions is that the debtors eventually end up bankrupt and with higher debts and greater hardship than before.

I think this goes to show that there are always vultures and people in society who are willing to prey on those who are unable, for whatever reason, to extricate themselves out of the mess in which they find themselves. For example, the report says that frequently these groups utilise court listings or mercantile gazettes to establish the name, address and details of debtors and then go to them with a proposal. That is worse than ambulance chasing.

I know there are legitimate practitioners who work in this area. But a legitimate practitioner should almost invariably be either a solicitor, who has the power to take control of a person's assets under section 188 of the act, or a registered practitioner and a trustee. They are the appropriate people who should be offering this service. It is not for private companies to make these sorts of arrangements. That would be highly dubious and highly immoral.

The other aspect I want to draw to the attention of the Senate relates to the operation of section 305 of the act. Section 305 is very important because the official receiver requires trustees, upon lodgment of their annual accounts, to pay a percentage of the total realisations. That goes into a fund which is then made available to trustees and official receivers to fund speculative actions under section 305.

It is interesting that the average amount paid out is in the vicinity of $108,000. However, one per cent of the annual realisations of $18 million is about $180,000. So it would appear on first reading—and I may be totally wrong—that substantially more is going into the fund than is being used or made available to trustees to meet the costs of an action. That concerns me because these moneys are utilised to fund investigations into highly dubious estates—for example, the estate of Mr Skase, the estate of Dr Edelsten which, from recollection, was subject to a section 305 application, and numerous others. In fact, I prepared many of them myself. At this point I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: If one read this report one would never realise that this was the worst year ever in the history of the Civil Aviation Authority or any of its predecessors. I will just touch lightly on some of the significant `achievements' of this authority during the last year. We saw, first of all, the collapse of a major contract—the TAAATS contract. We saw an independent review into that contract which found against the CAA. In effect, it found considerable maladministration and incompetence; so much so that the government directed the CAA to start again from scratch with a clean sheet of paper and run the whole exercise properly, and that is still in train.

PARA.TAB: We saw the resignation of the chief executive officer, Mr Baldwin, who mismanaged the whole process so badly that he had to go. He and his henchman, Dr Edwards, departed to the country that they came from. But apparently along the way they each left with a six figure sum as compensation for their mismanagement. One can look in vain in this report to find any entry in the balance sheets for the notional `compensation' paid to them for the non-completion of their appointments. Then we had the resignation of the chairman of the CAA. He was allowed to resign without any censure for the mismanagement of his part in the TAAATS contract. We have seen the disaffection of the aviation industry reach greater heights than we have ever seen before. We have seen disaffection within the parliament with the Civil Aviation Authority.

Apparently a large number of answers given to the first Senate estimates inquiry this year were incorrect. I well remember being on an aircraft flying to Brisbane the Friday morning after the hearing and reading about all these allegations of incorrect information being given to a Senate committee. That is absolutely inexcusable; we cannot have that from senior public servants.

I was not able to get to the second Senate estimates committee hearing, which was held last night. A marathon effort was put in by Senator Ian MacDonald, but in the part I saw at least one very misleading statement was given by a senior CAA officer to the Senate committee. I will deal with that in due course later this week and put the facts before the parliament.

We see a continuation of the gross abuse of power by the Civil Aviation Authority in a regulatory field. I spoke about this repeatedly when amendments to the Civil Aviation Act were before us. I was always assured by Senator Collins that the officers of the CAA would never abuse the great powers that the parliament has given it—literally powers to kick in someone's door without a warrant, seize documents, harass people and summarily remove licences from them. But we have seen gross abuse of powers time and time again over the last 12 months. This gross abuse of power has a major effect on people in the industry. It also has a bad effect on the reputation of the CAA. There are a lot of decent people in the CAA. A lot of them do not do what they should do—that is, firmly exercise authority—because they do not want to be lumped in with the few abusive characters who are in the regulatory authority.

We have seen people taken to court when in many cases all that is required is a fatherly talk to them to put them right on where they are going wrong. The CAA has a habit of picking on the rabbits—the small people; the individuals. It does not go after the really bad operators in the industry who stand up to it and offer to fight it in court. I think the cost of legal action that the CAA is involved in—I was pleased to see that Senator Macdonald asked for a figure on that last night—would be astronomical.

Senator Macdonald instanced the case of the pilot who, in a mercy operation, flew a pregnant woman from the floods in Longreach and who, as a consequence, spent three years in court. I have heard of a case in Queensland where the CAA tried to sue someone for dropping oranges on someone else's house, and it lost that case. The summary withdrawal of licences and the denial of people's livelihood is endless. Then we had the great debacle of the airspace mismanagement on 11 November. We had senior officials of the CAA going on television, ridiculing their critics and saying that the CAA would go ahead. Now they have backed down. There are advertisements in the paper every day.

The CAA is very important to Australia. It is going through a very bad period but the public and the parliament's patience is now almost totally exhausted with its incompetence. It has to get its act together and do so quickly.

TALK.START.PARA: —I note what the chairman of the Civil Aviation Authority said about safety regulations in his review in the report which was tabled today. As my colleague Senator MacGibbon has mentioned, the Senate estimates committee sat quite late last night in its second round of hearings into matters involving the CAA, specifically matters relating to safety matters.

PARA.TAB: As I indicated last night at the estimates committee meeting, I am at somewhat of a disadvantage in inquiring about matters of safety relating to the CAA because I do not have the technical experience or background to understand all the terms and implications. But I can say that there has been an increasing swell of opinion in recent times about concern for safety in the skies over Australia. My colleague Senator MacGibbon has raised that on many occasions.

I inquired into safety aspects at the original hearings of the Senate estimates committee, particularly because of my interest in the crash of the aircraft at Young in June this year. As a result of those original inquiries, certain information was given to me. Subsequent to that inquiry, it was suggested to me by many independent observers that the answers that I had been given were not quite factual. There was no suggestion that there was a deliberate attempt to mislead the Senate, but rather suggestions of incompetence and simply not knowing the situation and not knowing the job.

We received some information last night. I was given some categorical assurances by officers and by the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Collins). I regret to say that it has been suggested to me this morning that those assurances are not quite accurate. I do not make judgments at this time, but they are matters that we are pursuing. Should that turn out to be the case, the Senate will hear a lot more about it. I did ask some questions. Bearing in mind that this matter is sub judice, I was not too specific about the crash at Young. I asked for information about whether Monarch Airlines had sought assistance from the CAA and whether that assistance had been given or refused.

I asked about planned surveillance of regional airline operations in New South Wales and for assurances that surveillance would be carried out. I asked some questions about whether an officer of the CAA was aware before the crash that the autopilot had been removed from that aircraft. I was given answers and I accept them as they stand at this particular time, but it has been suggested to me that there may need to be follow-up questioning on some of those matters; the suggestion being, again, that perhaps I have not been given—can I say in the politest words—the full story.

I was also interested to hear that in recent times there have been four inquiries at different levels into the safety of the airline system in Australia. Information is to come to me on just how many inquiries into safety there have been over the years. It was suggested to me by Senator Collins that this proves how conscious the CAA is of safety matters. Of course, there is another interpretation—and this is the concern that is raised with me by people in the know and in the industry—that while there have been many inquiries into air safety nothing is ever really done to implement the recommendations of those particular inquiries. We will be looking at that a fraction further when I get the results of the information from the Senate estimates committee.

I simply raise again, in talking to this report, questions of air safety in Australia. I should also mention the case in Longreach that was briefly referred to by my colleague Senator MacGibbon where a man was prosecuted for apparently flying without a licence to pick up a woman in dire need of urgent medical treatment in a flood. Senator MacGibbon mentioned the facts, but he did not mention that the matter went to a trial by jury and the pilot defended himself and was acquitted. (Time expired)

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Transport and Communications)

TALK.START.PARA: —In brief response, and I intend to give a full response, to some of the nonsense that has been delivered here again this afternoon by Senator MacGibbon and Senator Ian Macdonald: Senator MacGibbon, who unfortunately did not attend the estimates committee meeting last night—as he acknowledged—should have. If he had attended the estimates committee meeting last night, he would have been in possession of a minute from the Bureau of Air Safety Investigation—sent to me at my request—providing clarification of these statements that have been given to the estimates committee which were allegedly grossly incorrect, appallingly wrong and so on.

PARA.TAB: I might add that the Bureau of Air Safety Investigation is an organisation that is not only highly professional and independent of the Civil Aviation Authority, but also in a real sense can be seen to be the watchdog of the CAA, particularly if incidents are involved. Senator MacGibbon, of course, has not read that document and he should. As I said last night, it is a question of debating how many angels can dance on the head of a pin.

TALK.START.PARA: —You have misquoted me; I will come at you on that.
—Senator MacGibbon had his turn and I did not interrupt him.
—Because you weren't here.

—That is correct, but I came down here very quickly. Senator MacGibbon constantly has this aura, this atmosphere, of authority about him but it is always wrongly based. Nobody will forget—Senator Schacht and I certainly will not—the famous Senate Select Committee on Certain Aspects of the Airline Pilots' Dispute where Senator MacGibbon delivered a tirade of allegedly authoritative material which turned out to be garbage when it was analysed.

PARA.TAB: I will respond to his earlier attack on the CAA—he has a 20-year history of attacking the CAA and its predecessors and so this is not a recent phenomenon.For example, Senator MacGibbon carried on at length during the matters of public interest debate in the last sitting week. He talked about the appalling new procedures that the CAA had introduced with briefing for pilots. He made an assertion—totally without foundation, as I subsequently discovered—that there are now only two operators to cover the whole of Australia in terms of pilots getting briefings over the new computerised system. I am not a pilot and I am not an engineer. I am, as I described myself last night, a professional passenger and nothing else, but because I am used to Senator MacGibbon's garbage, I immediately checked it out. There are, in fact, 16 operators, not two.

I might add that I availed myself of the codes to access the system and put in a putative flight plan from Alice Springs to Darwin. It took me five seconds to access the system—we timed it. In less than five minutes I had a full hard copy print-out of every piece of information that I would have needed for that flight available on my fax machine.

Further to that—Senator MacGibbon might be interested in this although he never is because 90 per cent of what he says turns out to be factual garbage—I then rang the 008 number which is also provided and had a very interesting talk with the CAA operator who looks after all of those computer banks. He was obviously a long-term CAA employee. When I told him about some of the allegations that Senator MacGibbon had raised, he laughed and said, `What utter rubbish'. The cold, hard facts are that in the so-called good old days, which Senator MacGibbon referred to, even with the briefing officers, the majority of pilots still got their briefs over the telephone. The huge advantage of this system is that one gets hard copy briefs on access by dialling a phone number.

TALK.START.PARA: —If you own a fax.

—These days the cheapest reasonable aircraft that one can buy costs about $50,000 and that would be bottom line, and it costs $300 to get a second-hand fax machine. I bought one. Pilots do own fax machines because of the enormous convenience that it gives them. It means that they do not need to go near a briefing office.

PARA.TAB: The operator said to me, `The one disadvantage of this automatic system, the one sad thing about it for me, is that in looking after this computer system I'm doing a job that was formerly done by 200 people. But the pilots are delighted with it. It gives them better information than they ever had before. It is instantly accessible whenever they want it at any time before the flight without the need to go anywhere to get it'. As distinct from Senator MacGibbon's assertions that one would have to wait half a day to get on the phone because there are only two operators, it took me five seconds to access the system and the pilots love it. (Time expired)

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Transport and Communications)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I seek leave to make a personal explanation, as I claim to have been misrepresented.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —To my total astonishment, Senator MacGibbon has just said—and the public record will show it—that he had never made representations to me in respect of the issues I raised. Because I do not want to delay the Senate, I will give just one example of a number, but one that demonstrates that is totally wrong. I cannot use the word `lie', of course, as it is unparliamentary.

PARA.TAB: I am genuinely horrified because, frankly, I thought my relationship with Senator MacGibbon was better than this. I have religiously pursued every complaint he has ever made to me about the CAA and I am the first one to kick the CAA in the tail if there is something wrong. Senator MacGibbon approached me and complained bitterly on one occasion about a Queensland pilot who was being prosecuted by the CAA for dangerous flying. On this occasion—as I always do—I found out the circumstances of the case where the CAA had outrageously prosecuted this bloke. He flew an aircraft across the tops of the heads of a number of people on horseback who were mustering cattle. They were the ones who made the complaint. The only issue between the CAA's version of events and this fellow's was that he claimed he had not been closer than 10 feet above the ground and the CAA claimed that he had flown within six feet of the ground.

That was a classic case where I chased it up after Senator MacGibbon had complained about the outrageous behaviour of the CAA. If the CAA does not prosecute under those circumstances, it should give the game away. I point out one fundamental issue that has been ignored by Senator MacGibbon and, indeed, Senator Ian Macdonald, even though it was pointed out to him last night: the CAA does not conduct these prosecutions. All it does is give the available material to the Director of Public Prosecutions, and the DPP makes the decision about whether or not the prosecution should proceed—not the Civil Aviation Authority.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I seek leave to make a statement as I claim to have been misrepresented once more.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have never made an appeal on the grounds that it was not dangerous flying. I did not know what charge the department had laid. I was concerned because of the entrapment. PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Colston)—On behalf of the President and in accordance with the provisions of the Audit Act 1901, I present the Auditor-General's report No. 9 of 1993-94: Efficiency Audit—Community Cultural, Recreational and Sporting Facilities Program.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell Sen I.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: On 11 September 1990, when I was attending my first estimates committee hearing—it seems like a long time ago—I spent some time going through the community cultural, recreational and sporting facilities program. At that time, while I was waiting for Senator Michael Baume who was doing his normal assiduous job of going through this program, I did some calculations to try to figure out where money, particularly in my home state of Western Australia, was going in relation to these grants.

PARA.TAB: Firstly, I was interested to find out how these grants were determined and what sorts of criteria were used to find where the money should go; and, secondly, I was interested to find out where the grants had gone. I noticed that many of the suburbs that they related to were in what I knew were marginal Labor seats, so I got my calculator out and found that most of the money was going into marginal Labor seats. In that year leading up to September 1990, of just under $600,000 spent in Western Australia, something like 85 per cent went into marginal Labor seats. This concerned me at the time.

I note from the Hansard that when I confronted Senator Richardson, who was the minister responsible immediately prior to the 1990 election, and asked him whether or not it was interesting to note that most of the money had gone into marginal Labor seats, he said:

SPEECH.PARA: I would not know whether that is a correct figure or not. That would not have been a consideration.

With this background it is interesting to see that the Auditor-General having done a significant study into the program which, I remind the Senate, has seen in the order of $60.3 million appropriated over the past five years, and a thorough analysis of how these grants are issued—the departmental advice on which the minister relies to make the decisions as to where the money goes, any follow-up to see if the money is spent correctly and whether or not the objectives of the program are met—the result of this audit report No. 9 for 1993-94 is an uncategorical disaster for the program and the way it is administered. Specifically, the responsibility for this disaster needs to be sheeted home particularly to the current minister, Ros Kelly, and one would imagine some blame would have to be put on the head of Senator Richardson as the minister responsible prior to Minister Kelly.

PARA.TAB: Having only just flipped through the report, it is worth noting a few of the comments made by the Auditor-General and some of the statistics. The Senate should know that, firstly, when these applications for grants come in from community groups and other people, the department goes through a categorisation process as to how the applications for funding stack up. They are categorised as being category 1, category 2 or category 3.

Under the period of review, the Auditor-General found that category 1 grants received only nine per cent of the funding and category 3 grants received 11 per cent of the funding. The importance of this is that category 1 grants are described as:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . well documented with a clearly demonstrated community need satisfying all other selection criteria'—
in other words, the top rung of applications that clearly serve the interests of the program. Those in category 3 are described by the department as:
. . . lacking in relevant information, for which community need has not been adequately demonstrated and many other selection criteria not satisfied, including evidence of other funding sources—

in other words, the absolute bottom of the pile. The interesting thing to note from this report, of course, is that these category 3 projects receive more funding than the category 1 projects. So on that criterion alone—and I am not saying it is the only criteria for judging whether a project is good or not—it is interesting to note that the minister has approved an enormous number of projects that are just badly documented and lacking any relevance to the selection criteria.

PARA.TAB: The Auditor-General notes that the statement made to me by Senator Richardson on 11 September 1990 was indeed correct, that the final decisions are made by the minister with some reference to departmental advice. The only advice is a categorisation; they end up with a series of grants in front of them and they make a selection. Basically decisions are made by the minister and personal advisers within the minister's staff.

It is interesting to note that the Auditor-General has also spent more time going into my original allegation. That came from the fact that I figured that in that particular year 85 per cent of the money in Western Australia had gone to marginal Labor seats, particularly the seats of Canning, Swan and Stirling, which it should be noted—and I did at that time—are well-established areas and suburbs of Perth which already have well-established sporting and cultural facilities. That is not to say they could not do with more, but the fact of the matter is that this program says the money should be going into new suburbs and areas of high unemployment to provide facilities where the need is greatest. Anyone who knows the seats of Canning, Swan or Stirling knows that most of the suburbs in those areas are well established with many good sporting facilities already.

I turn quickly to the analysis that the Auditor-General has done on where the money went in relation to the political seats. It is worth noting that at the time of the study Labor held 53 per cent of the seats in the House of Representatives. It may have gone up slightly since then, but for this argument that is irrelevant. During the period of this study the Labor Party held 53 per cent of the seats in the House of Representatives and those seats received 73 per cent of the grants and 66 per cent by value. The report states:

SPEECH.PARA: .on average, the total value of grants to a Labor held seat was $257,000 and to a Coalition held seat $141,000, and
.on average, the total value of grants to a marginal Labor held seat was $326,000 and to a marginal Coalition held seat $163,000.
This shows that there is enormous disparity.

PARA.TAB: The Auditor-General also provides a very handy graph, which we do not need to incorporate because it is in the report if anyone is interested. It shows quite graphically the figures spent in the year 1992-93 divided between Labor and coalition seats. It is interesting that in my home state of Western Australia no money was spent in any coalition seats and that indeed the quantum of money spent in Western Australia was nearly as high as it was in Victoria. Clearly Western Australia was a problem for the government in the last election.

As one would expect—I am sure that the minister would expect it—I would say that this whole program has become a political pork barrel; the money is shunted quite unashamedly into the seats where the marginal Labor members need to increase their popularity with the locals in the lead-up to the next election. The Auditor-General, of course, could not go so far as to say those sorts of things. On this subject the Auditor-General says:

SPEECH.PARA: ANAO's analysis does not demonstrate one way or the other that projects are approved on party political grounds. It may be that Labor held seats are those where the need for facilities is greatest. If this were the case, proper documentation of the reasons for decisions would be able to satisfy any questions concerning the selection of approved grants.
I think the very fact that the Auditor-General should even raise this question shows that there is an enormous doubt.

PARA.TAB: A one-sentence summary of what the Auditor-General report says about this is that the documentation is entirely lacking; the decision making process is not clear. It is quite clear that the minister makes the decisions and that there is very little way of auditing whether or not this program performs efficiently. But the reality of the matter is that most of the money ends up going into marginal Labor seats, so it is quite appropriate for the opposition to charge that the way in which this has been executed over the last few years amounts to a quite corrupt political pork barrel.

One of the other bad things about it is that there is no actual assessment of whether the facilities that are funded actually meet the needs. There is no follow-up. In fact, the Auditor-General points out that no financial appraisal takes place even for projects where up to a quarter of a million dollars is being spent at a time. One case study that the Auditor-General cited shows that $100,000 was spent in one year and that supplementary funding of $250,000 was sought for the next year and that was approved.

The case study that I refer to is on page 15 of the report. It was a joint project between two councils. As I said, $100,000 was given in 1991-92. A further quarter of a million dollars was given in 1992-93. Clearly, a member of parliament made a promise during the March 1993 election campaign. The report states:

SPEECH.PARA: In March 1993 the Government made an election promise of an additional $1m for the project. The Department has put forward options to honour the Government's promise resulting in a separate appropriation for this purpose.
I find all this quite disturbing and I think the minister really does need to make a formal response to the allegations made in this report.

PARA.TAB: Finally, one of the other disturbing aspects raised by this report is the fact that many of the funds available under this program are not spent in the year that they are allocated. That is not unusual. In fact, I alluded to it back on 11 September 1990 in an estimates discussion. But one of the concerns is that, if there was clear evidence of using this program as a political pork barrel, which the Auditor-General has alluded to, if one were to be a smart political operator, as many of the people in the New South Wales Labor Right are regarded by the media and many others, and had a few million dollars—and in this case $2.7 million was rolled over between 1991-92 and the following year and then a further $9 million was rolled over the year after that leading into the election year—it would actually be quite advantageous, if one were going to pump 77 per cent of the funding into marginal Labor held seats, to roll as much money as possible into the last year so one could go around making a big fellow of oneself in the election year. This, unfortunately, is exactly what has happened.

In addition to this rolling over of funds, we have also seen an additional $18.75 million on projects earmarked under the One Nation program pumped into this program as well. I remind the Senate that this program has no follow-up or evaluation as to whether or not the funds have been spent in a way that actually achieves the goals of the program. I think the goals of the program are worthy. I think to develop sporting and cultural facilities at a community level is something that money should be put into.

I know that a large number of community organisations are desperate for funds. They have chook raffles and fetes and do an enormous amount to raise money to create cultural and sporting facilities which communities need. There are many cases where that demonstrated need, I think, deserves some Commonwealth, state and local government assistance. But there needs to be cooperation and coordination between the three tiers of government. Again, the Auditor-General points out that in almost all of these cases there is no coordination or cooperation whatsoever. The left hand is not talking to the right hand. In fact, a case study in this report shows that three different Commonwealth grants were going into the one project and this department did not know about the other two. That seems quite alarming to me.

The minister, in her initial response to the Auditor-General's criticisms, has said that the Commonwealth government does not want to get involved in these consultations or further evaluation because it will make administration time and costs higher and it will slow down the program. I suggest that in this case it might be a good idea to slow the process down a little to make sure that the Australian taxpayer is getting value for money.

I had my doubts back on 11 September 1990, as a naive senator going to my first estimates committee hearing. It is sad but interesting to see that the Auditor-General has confirmed all of my worst fears, almost some three years to the day later, through this damning report. We expect to see a full explanation from the minister about what she proposes to do to overcome the glaring inadequacies and what I claim has become a corrupt, political pork barrel in this program. I expect that she should respond to us as quickly as possible.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald Sen I.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —My colleague Senator Campbell has very carefully, in a very limited time, surveyed the very important findings of the Auditor-General's report into this particular program. I will try not to repeat what Senator Campbell has said, but I do urge honourable senators to carefully consider and analyse the graphs contained on pages 13 and 15 of the report.

PARA.TAB: I think the graphs clearly demonstrate the concerns that Senator Campbell raised at his first Senate estimates committee hearing, as he says—that is, that this program is nothing but a political pork barrel by the Labor Party. In fact, the Auditor-General's report is a damming report on that particular aspect. As Senator Campbell has mentioned, it raises a number of very grave concerns about the purposes of this program and the political implications.

When the Auditor-General is game and courageous enough to write these sorts of reports, it is no wonder that the ANAO is being starved for funds by the current government, and made to use most of its funds to pay a huge and inflated rent to the Australian Labor Party for its premises without having sufficient funds to adequately cover all of its requirements and the roles that it is asked to perform. As I say, having seen this report, it is no wonder that the Labor Party is trying to starve the ANAO at its source.
My colleague has mentioned the political bias and the report by the Auditor-General in response to that. As Senator Campbell said, the report states:

SPEECH.PARA: ANAO's analysis does not demonstrate one way or the other that projects are approved on party political grounds. It may be that Labor held seats are those where the need for facilities is greatest. If this were the case, proper documentation of the reasons for decisions would be able to satisfy any questions concerning the selection of approved grants. At the present time documentation is simply not available to answer such questions.

It is pretty obvious that the Labor Party is not interested in having proper documentation, because it would expose even more vividly the political pork-barrelling that goes on with these grants. It is interesting also to quote from the report in relation to the role of the department—the independent Public Service. The report says:

The Department does not believe that it has a significant role in the decision making process. Departmental officers also argued that the categorisation process was not material to the decision making process which takes place in the Minister's office. It pointed to the fact that the Minister made decisions that did not always accord with the categories allocated by the Department. The categories, therefore, had no bearing on the final outcome.

The department is saying that, in spite of its recommendation and suggestions, the minister is not interested. One can only wonder—and one does not have to wonder very much—what is the minister's criterion in making grants. They are made for political purposes.

PARA.TAB: The report goes on to mention that the application form is poorly designed and the applicant is not required to state what is expected to be achieved by the project and who is going to benefit or by when. This makes it difficult for the Auditor-General to monitor outcomes.

The report also goes on to say that the states believe that greater overall benefit could be achieved from available Commonwealth funds if projects were selected in consultation with the states and local authorities. If the Commonwealth government were interested in making fair and equitable grants with these funds, local governments would certainly be in the best position to advise and assist.

Local authorities know their areas and they understand such things as which sporting or cultural facilities and recreational programs do need assistance and which are the most used. They are on the ground—they understand these things; they know the histories—but they are not even consulted. It is all done from the minister's office way down here in Canberra—not with any interest in what is right, I would suggest, but in the interest of how many votes the Labor Party could get from an appropriate and timely presentation of a cheque in a marginal electorate.
The report goes on to highlight that the program has unclear objectives. It says:

SPEECH.PARA: What the program is trying to achieve is not entirely clear. There is some discrepancy between the objectives of the program as stated in the program guidelines sent to applicants and those stated in the Program Performance Statements.
The uncertainty surrounding the objectives of the program is further complicated when an additional $18.75m was allocated to the program from funds originally earmarked for the `One Nation' program.

We all know that the One Nation program—and this is being confirmed more and more as time goes on and as we look back in history—was simply one big buy by the Labor Party to get votes for an election which it knew was going to be difficult and which most of the Labor Party people themselves thought they were going to lose. The One Nation program, as history has shown, is simply a big vote buying exercise by the Labor Party. The report says:
According to the Treasurer's press release at the time, the major thrust of the re-allocation of the `One Nation' funds was to quickly spend additional funds and deliver rapid job growth.

That seems odd and unusual for a community cultural, recreational and sporting facilities program. So the objectives are unclear. I suggest there is not much doubt about the clarity of the Labor Party's objective in this program, which is to buy votes in marginal electorates. If any further confirmation is required from this report, I suggest that honourable senators look at this further quotation from the report:
The Department has attempted to tighten up the guidelines and administration of the program on several occasions but Ministers have generally not accepted the departmental recommendations.
Of course, the ministers would not be interested. The department would want them to do it fairly and squarely but the minister is only interested in the vote buying aspect. The report goes on to say:
The Minister has advised that she always has regard to departmental advice but does not always follow that advice.
That is interesting. It continues:
In this case ANAO believes this has contributed to administrative and effectiveness difficulties.

The ANAO, as is its way, sends a draft report to the department and to the minister for comment. The response by the secretary to the department can only be described as equivocal and it really does not buy into the subject at all. The responses from the minister are quite interesting, though. The minister says that she believes that `the audit had gone well outside its own guidelines'. There we are: shoot the messenger—if you do not like the message then criticise the messenger. The minister is saying, `They weren't supposed to be looking into these things'. I can understand that the minister would be concerned that the audit office had looked into these claims of political bias. And so it goes. It is a report which goes to the whole question of fairness and of this government's propriety in its dealings.

PARA.TAB: By way of conclusion I will refer to the community cultural, recreational and sporting facilities program operations that are set out in diagram form on page 8, which makes for interesting reading. The applications are received, acknowledged and categorised by the department—although the minister takes no notice. They are then sent to the minister's office. Grants are selected by the minister; the department is advised; and submissions are prepared by the department for formal approval by the minister.

When the applications are successful, the minister advises the applicants. Then the process goes on and the grant is eventually paid—usually by a Labor Party flunkey at the electorate level. However, when the applications are unsuccessful, who is it that advises them? It is not the minister and not the Labor Party local member; the department wears the odium of advising unsuccessful applicants.

I urge honourable senators to carefully look at this report. It is, like many of the reports coming from the Auditor-General at this time, damning of the Labor Party and the way it uses public funds to buy votes at election time. It is a report that I believe should be read and understood by all senators and, I would hope, by members of the wider community.

TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Transport and Communications)

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to refer briefly to a statement that Senator Ian Macdonald made a few moments ago in his address which is factual nonsense. Senator Macdonald made an assertion that the considerable One Nation funds that were expended by this government were expended for party pork-barrelling and partisan reasons.

PARA.TAB: As one of the ministers involved in the strategic planning for the expenditure of those funds, a great deal of them in the portfolio of transport and communications, I wish to correct the record and point out to Senator Ian Macdonald, as I am sure he well knows, that the statement is just nonsense.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is partly true.

—Senator Campbell might be interested to know where the majority of the funds are going in this financial year. The One Nation funding was designed strategically to provide this country, for the first time in its history, with a standard gauge rail link, under a single interstate rail operator, from Brisbane to Perth, linking all of the major capital cities of Australia—Sydney, Melbourne, Adelaide and across to Perth. In addition, it was also designed to provide the strategic links necessary with the port infrastructure to connect with that rail line. The decisions had nothing whatever to do with party considerations, despite the careless use of the truth by Senator Ian Macdonald.

The assertions are absolutely false and deserve to be identified as such.

In order to correct the record once again, as a number of coalition senators have a careless disregard for the truth, I will take the opportunity while I am on my feet to table page 5 from my Hansard pinks of 28 October 1993. TALK.START.PARA: —In accordance with section 118 of the Commonwealth Banks Act 1959, on behalf of the President I present the annual report of the Commonwealth Bank of Australia and the financial statements of the Commonwealth Development Bank of Australia, together with the Auditor-General's report for the year ended 30 June 1993.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the documents.

SPEECH.PARA: The Commonwealth Bank of Australia annual report is a very comprehensive document. I do not want to address the detail in it at this stage, but I will make a few points about the ownership of the Commonwealth Bank. The Commonwealth Bank was one of the first government business enterprises to be partially privatised. That was done in 1990 or 1991 when the government agreed to privatise the bank to the tune of 30 per cent. The government has subsequently moved a step towards further privatisation with an additional 19 per cent to be sold.

PARA.TAB: The privatisation of the Commonwealth Bank has proved to be, I think, a resounding success. For the first 30 per cent privatised, almost 200,000 ordinary Australians decided to invest in the bank. Most of them have made a very handsome return on their shares. The shares have almost doubled in value since their listing in 1991. That listing, along with the likes of GIO and Woolworths, has encouraged many more Australians to take up direct share ownership than had formerly been the case.

The coalition welcomes such a development. It was and remains a major plank of coalition policy to privatise most, if not all, of the enterprises still owned by the government, of which there are many. Privatisation has a range of benefits. In particular, the more that Australians take a direct interest in the shares of their workplaces and national companies, the better. It brings Australians closer to understanding firms and the workings of business and it gives them a very important stake and, therefore, incentive in their future.

It has a considerable related advantage in removing the `them' and `us' attitude for the categorisation of people that some trade unions in particular, but also members of the Labor Party, have insisted on promoting for very many years. That is absolute nonsense and it is quite contrary to the egalitarian nature of our nation. The privatisation of government owned enterprises is very important in that respect, even aside from the generally enormous improvements in efficiency and competition that the privatisation process brings.

One can only hope that this government will move further to exit its 51 per cent remaining interest in the Commonwealth Bank. Unfortunately, there is a major ideological hang-up within the Labor Party on this matter, although one can hold out some hope for gradual education in that process.

I remember two or three years ago when privatisation to the tune of 30 per cent was mooted and introduced. There was never going to be any further privatisation under this government, so the government said, and that was enshrined in legislation. We see that, basically, financial expediency and the inability of the government to rein in its own expenditure and to get its budget in order were the prime motivators for the additional 19 per cent privatisation that has occurred in recent months. Nevertheless, the point is that there has been that further privatisation.

We are now down to 51 per cent government ownership and I would urge the government to consider going further and indeed exiting completely from its ownership of the Commonwealth Bank. There is no justification at all for the Australian taxpayer to continue to hold an interest in this bank or, for that matter, in most other government business enterprises. Government owned enterprises should be privatised so that all Australians can decide for themselves whether they wish to invest in these companies. Australians can build their own investment nest eggs and, in the process, add to national savings and individual financial independence.

Privatisation and contracting out are examples of, as I said, this government's failure to grasp economic reform. The government has been stifled on this issue as it has with such other key areas as industrial relations, tax reform and other micro-economic reforms. The government must surely take notice of the success of privatisation, not just from the fiscal point of view but also, as I have intimated, from the point of view of the national significance of the other reforms that are necessary—industrial relations reform and reform to encourage savings and investment in this country—if we are to develop the increasingly efficient and internationally competitive nation. We must achieve this if we are ever to have any hope of generating sufficient economic growth in this country to start tackling our horrendous and tragic level of unemployment and if we ever going to start the process of rebuilding living standards in this country.

I welcome the Commonwealth Bank annual report. I believe that it sets a shining example to us all to look at that further task that is very important for us in rebuilding confidence in our economy, in involving each and every Australian in the economy and providing incentives for them to do so, and in that way improving not just their own situation but, more importantly, or at least as importantly—because the two cannot be separated—the wellbeing of the nation as a whole. I seek leave to continue my remarks at a later stage.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.
