But now, Fosters, the successors to Elders' meat involvement, seems to have forgotten its concern and promises given in 1990, that the 45 per cent share remain with Australian interests. It is a shame that Fosters has not followed through with its 1990 commitment to the Australian interests.

Meat processing is dominated by small numbers of processors and large numbers of producers. It is an industry that has a large capital start-up requirement and is heavily regulated, which discourages new entrants. According to ABARE, it also has the smallest profit margins of any food processing—being half of beverages processors.

The future for the Australian industry lies in value adding and increased exports. However, the concentration and size of companies controlling a major proportion of the market discourages the significant entry of Australian interests into the much needed value adding downstream activities, such as packaging, distribution and retailing.

Australia has a beef industry on the verge of increasing its sales. There is the liberalisation of trade to Japan, good sales prospects into Korea, anticipated increased entry into the EC and trade liberalisation should the GATT Uruguay Round be successful. The AMLRDC and the AMLC 1990-91 reports estimate a potential increase in the market of $200 million by 1994. These are the rosy future prospects for the Australian industry which Australian producers through investment in their own Australian industry should be encouraged to be involved in. It should also be in the government's interest that the long-term future for Australian farmers is assured and solidly based.

The farmers investment trust, or any other domestic interest for that matter, should not be prevented from the opportunity to invest in AMH. To this end, I call on the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Senator Sherry, the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) and the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) not to make the Australian primary industry a victim of timing. Unfortunately, the investment trust is not yet up and running strongly enough to make a bid, yet by March next year it will be ready.

I support the passage of the Australian Meat and Live-stock (Quotas) Amendment Bill but, at the same time, I call on the Treasurer and the government to delay the FIRB decision on the sale of Fosters shareholding in AMH to ConAgra by a few months. A small delay would allow the Australian industry a chance for involvement in the vital next value adding step. It would allow Australian producers control over their industry beyond the farm gate—a process which has been strongly recommended and promoted by the government, its advisers and the industry itself.
Debate (on motion by Senator Woodley) adjourned.

TALK.START.PARA: —Earlier today the Deputy President informed the Senate of the death on 10 November 1993 of former President of the Senate the Hon. Justin Hilary O'Byrne AO, senator for the state of Tasmania from 1946 to 1981.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Acting Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate expresses its deep regret at the death, on Wednesday, 10 November 1993, of the Honourable Justin Hilary O'Byrne AO, Senator for the State of Tasmania from 1946 to 1981 and President of the Senate from 1974 to 1976, places on record its appreciation of his long and meritorious public service and tenders its profound sympathy to his family in their bereavement.

SPEECH.PARA: Justin O'Byrne was born on 1 June 1912 in Launceston, Tasmania, and was educated at St Patrick's College. He lived a full life. At the age of 18 he left home and ventured north to Queensland in search of work. He did a number of things, including droving, fencing and bullock driving.

PARA.TAB: In 1940 he enlisted in the RAAF, becoming a member of the First Australian Fighter Squadron. He flew patrols over the English Channel and the North Sea and took part in operations over France. It was on one of those operations over France in 1941 that his aircraft was shot down and he was captured by the occupying German forces. Justin ended up in the infamous Stalag Luft III prison camp. The courage and tenacity of the men there was made known to the world after the war through such movies as The Wooden Horse and The Great Escape. He spent three years and nine months as a prisoner of war and returned home in 1945 having attained the rank of flight lieutenant. Justin was a great storyteller and would tell of the years spent plotting escapes from the prison and holding political discussions to alleviate the boredom.

One of the aircraft that Justin flew during the war, a Spitfire, has been on display in the Australian War Memorial since 1956. The plaque bears Justin's name and the names of two of his comrades. This stands as just one of the permanent reminders of the participation of Australian pilots in the war and the contributions they made for their country in lands far from their own.

In 1956 he stood for and won a seat in this chamber representing his home state of Tasmania, beginning a political career that was to last through 34 years, nine governors-general and eight prime ministers—not a bad record. At the time of his election he was the youngest senator in this place.

Justin served on numerous committees, including the standing orders committee, the public works committee and the committee on the new and permanent Parliament House, just to name a few. He also served as temporary chairman of committees from 1949 to 1961. He spent 10 years as the opposition whip and then a short period as government whip before his election in 1974 to the office of President of the Senate, the official title that went with his unofficial title of father of the Senate.

Justin presided over the Senate during one of the most tumultuous and still controversial periods in Australian politics. The fact that there was not one dissent from his rulings, nor any vote of no confidence, is a testament to his performance and the high regard in which he was held by those on both sides of the chamber.

A self-described inveterate interjector, he said he often had to bite his tongue while sitting in the chair. As those who knew him would realise, this must have taken a great deal of self-control. He managed to maintain the dignity of his position at all times. As a senator he was vigorous in debate, and his quick wit and humorous antics brought relief to the sometimes dull proceedings in the Senate, but it also got him suspended on one occasion. He was invariably good for a laugh or a joke or a good story.
Throughout his career in this place he advocated equality and social justice for all Australians. In his maiden speech he said:

We must never lose sight of the splendid vision of our destiny. Australia's destiny envisages the establishment, the complete establishment, of the rights of man, including equality of opportunity for all.

SPEECH.PARA: Justin did not lose sight of his vision for Australia and fought hard to make it a reality. He spent almost his entire life in the service of the Australian people. He was a remarkable man of courage, determination and goodwill. In 1984 he was awarded an Order of Australia in recognition of his service in politics and government. Justin O'Byrne was an Australian of whom we can all be proud. He will be sadly missed. On behalf of the government, I extend to his wife, Anne, and family our most sincere sympathy in their bereavement.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of opposition senators, I join with the Acting Leader of the Government in the Senate in expressing our regret at the recent death of former President of the Senate the Hon. Justin O'Byrne at the age of 81.

PARA.TAB: I regret that I did not know the late former Senator Justin O'Byrne. It is interesting that the year I was born was the year he came into the Senate and that he left the Senate at the time that I came into the Senate. I notice that when he came into the Senate he was the youngest senator and when I came into the Senate I was certainly the youngest senator on our side. I also notice that we both served as parliamentary advisers to the United Nations at one stage of our respective senatorial careers. So we have some things in common.

As was said by Senator Ray, Justin O'Byrne was born in Tasmania in 1912 and educated in Launceston. He clearly had a much harder life in his early years than I did—leaving Tasmania, as was said, when he was just 18 years of age, during the Great Depression; working through Queensland bullock driving and fencing for some 10 years; and then serving his nation by joining the RAAF as a pilot in 1940. He obviously showed great courage in that period. He was an original member of 452 Fighter Squadron and, as was also said, he was shot down over France in 1941. He spent the next 3 1/2 years as a prisoner of war in Germany and eventually returned to Australia in 1945.

The following year he was elected as a Labor senator for Tasmania. He remained in the Senate for 34 years, until his retirement in 1981—the second longest continuous incumbency, I understand, in the Senate's history. As he noted in his final speech, he had spent half his lifetime in the Senate—a terrifying thought! Obviously, in such a long career in the Senate, there was ample opportunity for committee service. His contribution, I am advised, was outstanding. It included many years on the Senate Standing Committee on Standing Orders and nearly 12 years on the Joint Statutory Committee on Public Works.

In addition to committee service, Justin O'Byrne was opposition whip in the Senate from 1962 to 1972 and government whip for the next two years. No doubt the highlight of his parliamentary career, however, came with his election to the high office of President of the Senate in 1974—a position he held for two years during some of the most turbulent times this chamber has ever seen.

As Senator Ray said, during all Justin O'Byrne's years in the parliament he was noted for his concern for the welfare of ordinary Australians—what we now often refer to as social justice—and also for his sense of humour. I am advised that his capacity to liven a party or even a dull debate by breaking into verse was legendary. He retired from the Senate, as I said, in 1981 after a long and distinguished career which was recognised by the award of the Order of Australia in 1984. On behalf of opposition senators, I extend our sincere condolences to his widow, Anne, and his children.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to give the support of the Australian Democrats to this condolence motion for former President of the Senate, Justin O'Byrne. Justin O'Byrne was President of the Senate from 1974 to 1976 and was a senator for Tasmania for more than 30 years. He not only had a remarkable career as a senator, but he also had an extraordinary life, one which encompassed and reflected a period of significant change in Australian society.

PARA.TAB: Born in Launceston in 1912, he was a participant in and a witness to many great events in Australian social and political life. He was a pilot with the RAAF, was shot down over France during the Second World War and was a prisoner of war in Germany for more than three years. He was elected to the Senate immediately after the war, was the opposition whip in the Senate for more than 10 years and the government whip for 16 months prior to being elected President of the Senate in July 1974.

As a senator he sat through the terms of eight Prime Ministers, from Chifley to Fraser. He sat with the first woman elected to the Australian Senate and his term as Senate President included the end of the Whitlam government. He was one of the old school of Labor Party politicians, committed to social justice and a fair deal for Australian workers. Justin O'Byrne served his country with great honour and distinction and I am sure he will be sadly missed by his colleagues, family and friends. On behalf of the Australian Democrats, I extend sympathy to Mr O'Byrne's wife and family.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to associate the National Party in the Senate with the condolence motion moved by the acting leader of the government, Senator Robert Ray. Today I had the honour of representing the National Party at the state funeral for the Hon. Justin O'Byrne, held in Launceston. The Church of Apostles was overflowing with mourners paying their last respects to a man that they held in high regard. Many hundreds—I would not like to put a figure on it, but the church was overflowing—came to pay their respects to this remarkable man, who died at 81 after dedicating 40 years of his life in service to the Australian people, firstly as a RAAF fighter pilot during the Second World War and then as a long serving senator for Tasmania.

PARA.TAB: Justin O'Byrne represented the people of Tasmania in the Senate for over 34 years, a great achievement and a near record. During his eight terms in parliament he received a first-hand view of the shifting fortunes of various governments as they rose and fell around him. He saw eight Prime Ministers come and go from Chifley in the late 1940s to Fraser in the early 1980s.

Justin O'Byrne was educated at St Patrick's College in Launceston. He left Tasmania at the age of 18 to go north to Queensland in search of work. During the depression years he worked on the land in a variety of jobs: drover, fencer, bullock driver, tank sinker and station overseer. When I was in Launceston today one of the federal members of parliament down there provided me with a local article which described Justin O'Byrne as a `road' scholar, saying that he had learnt a lot on the road.

Justin O'Byrne took flying lessons under the empire training scheme and subsequently served as a RAAF fighter pilot during World War II. He took part in the defence of London during the blitz before being shot down over France in 1941. Justin O'Byrne was detained as a prisoner of war in various German prison camps, being sent to the notorious Stalag Luft III camp for fighter pilots, where he spent the remainder of the war. He was a courageous and a defiant prisoner. He spent his incarceration planning escapes, digging tunnels and keeping morale up among his fellow prisoners. He helped plan two legendary escapes which I think became famous.

Mr O'Byrne was able to put his traumatic POW experience behind him and not long after his repatriation to Australia he was elected as senator for Tasmania in 1946. Through his long career in the Senate, Mr O'Byrne served on many committees including defence, resources, war gratuity and public works. After 10 years as opposition whip, Mr O'Byrne became government whip in the Senate in 1972, a position he held for two years.

In 1974 his hard work, basic decency and integrity were recognised by his parliamentary peers when he was elected to the position of President of the Senate. He held this position with distinction for two years, not an easy job when we reflect on what a place the Senate was at that time. For the remainder of his time in the Senate, Mr O'Byrne continued his hard work to promote the interests of the people in Tasmania.

He retired from the Senate in 1981 at the age of 69. Even at that age he continued to be involved in the local community, serving as a justice of the peace. Mr O'Byrne was a great Australian who made an enormous contribution to public life, fighting for his country and working tirelessly for the people of Tasmania. I am sure all honourable senators will join with me in extending sympathy to Mrs O'Byrne, Mr O'Byrne's family and their many friends.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a privilege to have known Justin O'Byrne. He was particularly supportive of and helpful to me when I was first in this parliament as the member for Denison from 1972 to 1975. Of course, he had already been here for 25 years at that time. I thought it was pretty amazing for anybody to be in this place for that length of time, but he continued for a further nine years. I greatly valued the advice and the stories he would tell about the history of this place and the events in which he had participated. As has already been mentioned, he was a great story teller.

PARA.TAB: Justin O'Byrne was thrilled at our coming back into government in 1972 after 23 years in opposition. One of the sad things I remember, having lunch with him on the day of the first caucus meeting in December 1972, was his getting a message from one of the scrutineers leading him to believe that he had been elected to cabinet, only to have that dashed an hour or two later when the preferences were fully distributed.

He continued as Labor's Senate whip for that first period of the Whitlam government and it was in mid-1974 that he achieved the presidency, a position in which he excelled and of which he was proud. Of course, no-one has ever been certain of whose that one vote was that helped him to achieve the position of President in the ballot in the Senate chamber in the old Parliament House in July 1974. There have been lots of rumours as to who it might have been, but I do not think anybody is absolutely certain. I think it was an excellent outcome that that one vote changed sides.

As I said to Justin O'Byrne's family after the funeral in Launceston this afternoon, I am actually still finding it difficult to believe that he is no longer with us. He had always been around and I think I assumed that he always would be. He was a person who was really, even at the age of 81, very much young at heart. I think it is hard to believe that he was actually 81 when he died.

I think one of the troubles with the Senate these days is that there is not enough singing. I think that is the big difference between the Senate now and the Senate in the days when people like Justin O'Byrne were in it. Justin was always willing to lead some singing or to play the harmonica. He loved music and I particularly remember that there was lots of it at the huge function at Launceston's Albert Hall after he retired—a significant event in Launceston's history which will live in my memory.

Justin O'Byrne's stories and jokes were sometimes corny, but he was well loved and popular as a senator here and in Tasmania, and in the years since 1981 when he retired and I effectively replaced him here. As Tom Uren said today in the eulogy in the funeral service, Justin was immensely proud of his family, the achievements of young Justin, of Helene and of Hilary, and especially the achievements in so many facets of public life of his wife, Anne. I know they will feel their loss particularly deeply because of the nature of the man.

Justin O'Byrne was consistent in striving for peace and justice in this world. He held strong views, but he could remain friendly with all of those who disagreed with him. I think he was a great representative of Tasmania. He was strongly committed to the Labor Party's ideal and I will certainly miss him deeply.

TALK.START.PARA: —I too would like to be associated with this condolence motion. I too had an opportunity to attend the funeral today. It clearly showed the respect that the people of Tasmania have for the work that Justin did as a representative over a very long period. The O'Byrne family have been very well and favourably known, and this was reflected at the very large funeral that we went to today.

PARA.TAB: I have known Justin since 1946. I remember, when I was a lad of about 17 or 18, meeting him at almost every polling booth I went to one day in the electorate of Bass, talking to him and following up a conversation as we went. We would both leave and we would both meet in the next place. What I remember is that, even at that stage and under those circumstances, by the time we got to the next booth he had a new story. Of course, in 1946 it was a winner takes all election. There were six Labor senators and no Liberals. Justin was a Labor senator during the period between 1947 and 1950. While I have never been close to Justin, I have had very much of a passing association with him ever since that time.

The funeral today was significant in that so many of Justin's true friends were able to be there. I thought it was a very fitting reminder to so many people that, in this game of politics, you know who your real friends are. I saw many of Justin's friends there today. We all know who is close and who is not. I thought it was very moving that so many of his real friends were there. Most of them, of course, are at his age and stage of life and it is no longer easy for them to move about at the drop of a hat to be in various places.

Like everyone else who was associated with him, I think we have to remember the stories he told. We have to remember the way that Thursday nights in the old Parliament House were singsong nights. We need to remember that in this game of politics, you are worth what your principles will carry you through to. Whether we agree with one another's principles or not is immaterial, compared with whether we adhere to them. I would certainly say that Justin always adhered to the principles that he believed he was part of. I always admired him for that.

My next greatest memory of Justin is during the late 1940s and early 1950s. The members of the O'Byrne family were substantially older than I am but certainly, wherever there was a party on, there were a few O'Byrnes. They were always great starters at a good party. The people of Launceston of my age will certainly remember the way the O'Byrne family were always there, always participating and always the life and soul of the party.

Through those years we regarded Justin as being the typical bachelor, but sooner or later it caught up with him. In Anne I would have to say that he married a great partner, one who participated fully in the life that Justin had set for himself. I extend my very sincere condolences to Anne and the family in the knowledge that the people of Launceston in particular, and the people of Tasmania in general, feel for them very much at this time. I appreciate the opportunity that I had to attend the funeral and I appreciate the opportunity to speak to the motion.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I wish to be associated with the condolence motion which is before the chamber due to the passing of our former colleague, the Hon. Justin O'Byrne. I join with other senators who have spoken in extending my sincere condolences to Justin's family and close friends.

PARA.TAB: Some senators will have known Justin longer than I did, especially those from Justin's home state of Tasmania. My association with Justin, however, began after my election to the Senate in 1975. I recall that when I was waiting at a motel for transport to take me to Parliament House for my first day of sitting, a young lady who was staying at the same place remarked to me that it would be a sad day. Actually, I thought it was anything but a sad occasion because I had first stood for the Senate in 1970, then again in 1974 and, having been passed over by the Queensland Parliament for a casual vacancy in August and September 1975, I was beginning to wonder whether I should have opted for an academic career instead. So I was compelled to ask why the day would not be memorable.

The young lady replied that the senator for whom she worked—she referred to him as her boss—was about to lose his job. She was, of course, referring to Justin and his position as President of the Senate. Later in the day, when Condor Laucke assumed the presidency of the Senate, Justin handled the situation with consummate grace and his congratulations to the new president were absolutely sincere.

Over the years which followed our first meeting, a firm friendship developed between Justin and me, even though I was about 26 years his junior and he had already seen 28 years of service in the Senate before I entered the parliament. There are probably countless warm stories which can be told about Justin, because he was such a fine raconteur, especially at the dinner table in the old Parliament House. Quite a few times I heard the story of how he was compelled to bail out over enemy held territory. His hands had been scalded by escaping engine oil and, if I remember correctly, because of damage to his aircraft, he had to turn it upside down to bail out. I used to be fascinated at how he described his surprise at how small his parachute appeared to be when he looked up. He also mentioned that after he bailed out he could see the white cliffs of Dover to the west but described how they disappeared from his view as he descended. I expect that he had wistful memories of those white cliffs during his three and a half years as a prisoner of war.

I cannot recall Justin speaking about his early years in the Senate when Ben Chifley was in office as Prime Minister. To me, contemporary memories of the Chifley government were associated with an era when I wore short pants to school. But in our midst here was a person who was actually serving in parliament before Labor's loss of government in 1949. With Justin's passing, very few members of that era still remain.

A cursory glance at the 1982 parliamentary handbook, the handbook in which Justin last appeared as a sitting senator, indicates the breadth of his parliamentary service, especially when one considers that the greater part of his 34 years as a senator were spent on the opposition benches. In 1972, however, he was again part of the governing party and his long and meritorious service was rewarded by his election to the presidency of the Senate in 1974.

Although Justin retired from the Senate in 1981, it was not uncommon for him to return to Canberra. Whenever he did, it was ever so pleasing to meet him once again. On one occasion, when I was chairing a Senate select committee in Launceston, I was surprised and delighted to see Justin—he was by then retired—sitting with those who had come to give evidence or listen to the comments of their fellow residents. It is the only time in my experience as a member of any committee that a former president was present at a public hearing. I would have thought that, after 34 years in the Senate, any activity would be preferable to spending a morning at a Senate committee hearing. But it was a measure of Justin's commitment to his local community that he came along to hear what was being said about agricultural and veterinary chemicals.

I was, quite naturally, saddened when I heard of Justin's death. But I had another regret in that I did not call on him when I was in Launceston in June this year. I considered doing so, but decided against it, thinking I should not invade the privacy of his home. We all pass on eventually, but it never occurred to me that I would not see Justin again. I believe that I had an unreal and unconscious perception that Justin O'Byrne and death were incompatible. Sadly, because I saw and spoke to Justin earlier this year, it did not mean that there would be further opportunities to renew our friendship some time later.

It is never easy for a family when it loses a loved one. However, I trust that Justin's good wife, Anne, and her family are to some extent comforted in their grief knowing that fond memories of Justin will dwell in the hearts of many people throughout Australia. Those memories will certainly remain with me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I join with my colleagues in offering condolences on the death of fellow Tasmanian, former Senator Justin O'Byrne. Although coming from opposite sides of the political fence, I must say that I felt honoured to have served with him in this chamber during the last three to four years of his very highly distinguished career of 34 years representing the state of Tasmania.

PARA.TAB: As we all know, Justin entered this chamber in 1946. He was the second longest serving member in the history of the Senate. For the last five years of his career, he was regarded as the father of both this chamber and the other place. His service to this chamber was recognised in 1984 when he was made an officer of the Order of Australia.

What was it that enabled Justin to be elected and re-elected for all those years? As a fellow Launcestonian and close neighbour I knew him and I can honestly say that, throughout his life, Justin had the characteristic of being able to attract and make friends with everybody he met, even those with whom he disagreed. He was a likeable fellow with a ready wit and sociable nature yet, at the same time, he had a keen sense of justice.

I remember well Justin's farewell that was held at the local civic centre in Launceston—the well-known Albert Hall—where over 1,000 people, including the former Prime Minister Gough Whitlam, turned out to farewell his distinguished career. I was the only Liberal politician to be invited to that occasion, and I considered it an honour. Justin displayed the familiar charisma on this occasion, yet, at the same time, that streak of larrikinism that made him so popular with the electorate was ever present.
Last Saturday, the obituaries in the local newspaper, the Examiner, restated this feeling with the words:

SPEECH.PARA: A laugh, a chat, a joke or two, that's how we will remember you.
These words are a good example of how so many people summed up Justin.

PARA.TAB: I note that in Justin's recorded comments on leaving the Senate he bemoaned the fact that parliamentarians in the 1980s were no longer `earthy people' and that at times parliament lacked humour and repartee, very necessary ingredients for breaking tension. But he practised this philosophy and, as a consequence, became a man of the people. He understood the philosophy and thoughts of the everyday person. His upbringing and training, his work before the 1930s and his wartime experiences prepared him for the role of being a friend of the people.

Justin was the seventh child of 10 children. Any person coming from such a background has an intense familiarisation with the problems that a family has to face, particularly at that time. On the other hand, his strong religious training at the local Catholic St Patrick's College gave him a sense of justice for all. In fact, Justin and I shared a common employer but at different times and stages of our career at the well-known Kelsall and Kemp textile plant.

It was during the depression years that Justin was forced to leave Tasmania and go droving, bullocking and fencing in Queensland. It was there that he joined the Australian Workers Union and thus had his Labor philosophies extended. A boyhood ambition was also realised at this time when he learned to fly under the empire training scheme.

With the announcement of war in 1939, Justin put his flying skills to use and became an Australian fighter squadron member. He was shot down during the aerial battles over France in 1941, spending three years and nine months in German prison camps, including the notorious Stalag Luft III camp, especially built to house captured allied pilots. Here he participated in a number of tunnel escapes for airmen. The famous wartime story, The Wooden Horse, was based on exploits in which he was involved.

I am told that it was during these years in the German concentration camps that he had time to talk with his fellow prisoners and the desire for a political life was created. Thus, in 1946, on his return from the war, Justin was elected to the Senate. At that point, he was the youngest member ever elected to the Senate.

On reading his first speech, the sense of justice and the desire to serve his fellow man shone through. Of interest are his comments in a speech on the estimates and budget delivered on 16 October 1947 when he said:

SPEECH.PARA: Only when we have courage, foresight, and a cause that is just, can we successfully embark on a policy that will assure to all decent people who work with their hands and brains at least the means of earning a livelihood and having sufficient food, clothing and shelter—a right which every citizen of a country such as this should inherit.
His wartime experience contributed to the fashioning of his political philosophies. In the same speech, he stated that among:

. . . the valuable lessons learned during the war, we realised that when man-power and machinery are concentrated on the achievement of great production that effort inevitably results in production of abundance. As a nation and as a member of the commonwealth of nations, we should apply that lesson now in times of peace; if we do not, we shall be the losers.
He hoped that serving in the Senate would be a way in which he could carry forward his hopes, ideas and aspirations for a better world.

PARA.TAB: It is interesting to note that Justin always made very positive comments, even about Liberal prime ministers. This says a lot about the character of the man that we are discussing in this condolence motion today. For example, he described Menzies as being outstanding, capable and articulate while Gordon had a `lot of innate ability'.

The highlight of Justin's long career, as mentioned by many other speakers here today, was his election to the high office of the President of the Senate in 1974. It is fitting that flags were flown at half mast over this building today. The election was unexpected as, when nominated, he did not have a majority of the votes to obtain the position. At the time, Senator Steele made the voting even, but a defection by one of the opposition senators gave it to him. This is again testimony to the fact that he was so well liked.

The newspaper reports at the time again homed in on this third generation Irish Australian and his ability to inject humour into all situations. The reports comment on his ability to liven up a dull Senate debate with light-hearted doggerels. Many felt that his presidency might be flippant and in stark contrast to the dignified and stately Sir Magnus Cormack. However, the newspapers were wrong. Justin O'Byrne conducted his presidency with dignity. Although the Labor Party was in the minority while he was in the president's chair, there was not one dissent from his rulings or a vote of no confidence.

Whatever side of the political fence Tasmanian politicians have been on, I think they have been able to contribute more than their fair share to the party organisation. Justin O'Byrne was a man first and a politician second. His cheerfulness, ready wit, positive outlook on life and regard for the everyday man will be sorely missed by both his family and friends. To his wife, Anne, always his right hand for most of his political career, his son Justin and his daughters Hilary and Helene, I extend for a second time my deepest sympathy.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —I join my colleagues in supporting Senator Robert Ray's motion of condolence for former Senator Justin O'Byrne. I do not often speak on condolence motions here. Many of the people who have come here have been known better by others—they have been closer to them and have worked with them—and I sometimes feel that it is a bit gratuitous to add one's comments. But on this occasion, it is somebody for whom I feel a very deep affection, developed over 20 years of friendship and association.

PARA.TAB: It struck me at the time—in retrospect, it strikes me even more strongly—that when I first met Justin O'Byrne he had already been in the Senate for 27 years, which seems in itself to be a terrible thought. I have been here for five. The thought that one might serve here for 27 years is beyond comprehension. But he then was nowhere near the end of his effective contribution as a senator.

Justin was on the national executive of the party. He had been in the Senate for 27 years and I was 25 years of age, so it was all a bit hard for me to come to grips with—this man, who did not seem old enough to have been in the Senate for 27 years, who had that impish humour about which so many people have spoken and who made sensible, worthwhile contributions to the debates, on that senior body of the Labor Party.

I knew Justin for 20 years after that. In a sense, my initial impressions were confirmed and reinforced continuously over 20 years of association. He was a man of great integrity. Others have spoken about that; I merely support it. He was a man of great humour; others have spoken about that. I suppose all those who knew him were once or twice the butt of that humour—not that he was a person who embarrassed others with his humour. He did sometimes tell a joke at our expense, but never with that sharp edge with which people sometimes misuse their humour. He sang the words of some songs that nobody but Justin had ever heard before; he always sang them in a very entertaining way, often with a bit of a message.

He also was a person of great commitment. I was always impressed by the fact that in his contributions there was always a core of the principle which underpinned the position that he was articulating. He tried to progress from that principle to the conclusion. I do not want to pretend that I always agreed with Justin O'Byrne. He would be stunned; if at any time when I had known him I got up and pretended that, he would have been the first to ridicule such a suggestion. We had some wonderful arguments, but I always respected the fact that he articulated his case from a position of principle, even when they were principles with which I did not agree. He always had the capacity to smile and to share a pleasant conversation after the disagreement. Sometimes they were pretty vigorously argued, particularly if you were able to do it behind closed doors.

He was a person who cared and who sought through his life to make a contribution to his country, to his state and for his family. I think he would be pleased if he thought—and I believe that it would be true to say—that he improved each of those through his efforts and his commitment.

I had the privilege on some occasions of staying at his home in Launceston when I visited that city. His friendship, warmth and humour and that of his family was something which I greatly appreciated. It is a memory which I will treasure. He was a very good friend and a great political supporter and source of encouragement, giving great consideration to important issues. I have already written to his wife and family expressing my sympathy. I welcome the opportunity to stand here this evening and put on the public record a formal recognition of those things which I conveyed privately to Anne and to the family.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to add my contribution to this condolence motion for former Senator Justin O'Byrne. I always found Justin a very affable and congenial colleague. As Senator Archer said, he was true to his ideals and to the Labor Party. He was probably the last of the true blue union type representatives that we have seen from the Labor Party. I always thought that he had a degree of detached objectivity about his approach to politics. He had an air about him that you often see in people who have had some pretty searing experiences in war; when they get into civilian life they probably find it difficult to see anything as being as serious as what they have been through in the past. Justin always had that about him.

PARA.TAB: At the outset of my career when I first came into this chamber I got up to speak on a bill. I was immediately ruled out of order. The ruling was quite correct according to the standing orders; I cannot remember what the point at error was. We were in government then and, characteristically, no-one on my side came to my help. Justin, who used to sit on the back bench on the other side of the chamber immediately recognised the difficulty I was in and he moved either that I be granted leave to speak or for the suspension of standing orders. I made my speech and I was eternally grateful for that act of charity to a new senator at that time. I often talked with Justin in the corridor; I did enjoy his company. I take this opportunity to extend my condolences to his family, friends and relatives.

TALK.START.PARA: —I very much wish to be associated with this motion of condolence for a late colleague, the Hon. Justin O'Byrne. From about the mid-1960s until his retirement from the Senate, Justin and I had the occasional disagreement on organisational questions of a political character. Notwithstanding that, when our paths crossed on various occasions in recent years, we would exchange greetings without raking over old coals.

PARA.TAB: It was a great privilege to be present with people from very diverse backgrounds at the funeral service for Justin O'Byrne today in the Church of the Apostles in Launceston. It was indeed a very moving ceremony, the hymns and prayers having been chosen by Justin's family and extended family. The penitential rite with its associated spiritual reconciliation purposes was of particular relevance so far as I was concerned.
I wish to take this opportunity to express my deepest sympathy to Justin's wife and to his children Helene, Hilary and young Justin, and to his extended family.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to associate myself with the motion before the chamber tonight. I was also able to attend the funeral today in Launceston and, as has been said already, it was a very moving ceremony. Reference has been made to Justin's singing; it therefore did not surprise me when the priest said today that, at the age of 12, he was singing in that particular church.

PARA.TAB: I first met Justin before I was elected to the Senate. I met him when he was the treasurer and the returning officer for the national executive of the ALP in 1973. A ballot was taking place with six of us standing for three positions. At the end of the meeting, somebody said to Justin, `How's the ballot going?'. He said, `I've counted it twice and I've got two different results so I think I'll take the ballot papers home tonight and count them properly'. Some of my supporters did not think that that was a particularly good idea, so the ballot was counted and I won by one vote. That was the very unlikely start to a friendship back in 1973.

The last time I saw Justin—except for when he attended Condor Lauke's funeral—he was sitting in my office and we sat back and laughed about that particular ballot and the situation that arose. I think it was one of Justin's strengths that he could always laugh about a particular situation.

It has been said that he served 34 years here in the Senate. If the party rules had allowed it, I think he would have stayed in here until the day he died, because he loved the place. When I first came here, as Senator Colston said, he had been here for 28 years. I think the amazing thing was that he retained his enthusiasm. Every day he would look through the red—the Senate business sheet—and see what papers were on it and what the debates were and he would tell people that they should get involved. I think all of us now sitting here would find that enthusiasm quite staggering, but he retained it until the day he left.

He was a great Australian character, and reference has been made to that tonight. He was a friend, and I had the opportunity to extend my condolences to Anne and his family today, and I do so again tonight. I ask all honourable senators to stand in silence to signify their assent to the motion.
Question resolved in the affirmative, honourable senators standing in their places.
Debate resumed.

DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN MEAT AND LIVE-STOCK (QUOTAS) AMENDMENT BILL 1993

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak only briefly tonight on the Australian Meat and Live-stock (Quotas) Amendment Bill 1993 on behalf of the Australian Democrats. The bill before us will extend the sunset clause contained in section 9 of the Australian Meat and Live-stock (Quotas) Act 1990 for a further three years; that is, until 28 December 1996.

PARA.TAB: The AMLC establishes quotas on the export of goods where restrictions are imposed, or are likely to be imposed, by an importing country or by Australia or, in the case of the export of live sheep or lambs, where the AMLC believes it is in the best interests of the industry to operate such quotas. At present, restrictions are being imposed on our exports of beef, mutton and goat meat to the United States and on the import of Australian beef, buffalo and sheep meat by the EC.

The Democrats acknowledge these restrictions and recognise the vitally important role the operation of a quota scheme plays in ensuring our reluctant conformity to these restrictions. With over $1 billion worth of beef exported to the US each year and the threat of an import quota being imposed on us under the US meat import law—a quota which could cost our beef exporters around $100 million—the importance of upholding our undertakings under voluntary restraint agreements is obvious. The Australian Democrats recognise the important role quotas play, and we will be supporting the bill.

I want to raise a couple of issues. Firstly, I support the sentiments expressed by Senator Boswell in his appeal to the government to allow time for the farmers investment trust to secure funds to enable it to purchase Elders shares in AMH. The Democrats have argued for, fought for and made the same appeal on many occasions for ownership of primary industry and other industries to be retained in Australian hands. We have made our regrets about the weakness of the Foreign Investment Review Board known on many occasions. It is our policy to support Australian ownership. So I support the appeal which Senator Boswell has made.

Another issue is also very important for the Democrats. One of the powers contained in the Australian Meat and Live-stock Act, which I would like to spend a little time on, is the power of the AMLC to regulate the live sheep trade with Saudi Arabia, if and when it is to recommence and if such regulation is required. Australia's live sheep trade to Saudi Arabia was suspended in 1991 to protect our industry's reputation and to uphold the government's animal welfare obligations. The Democrats welcomed the decision at that time.

The policy position of the Democrats regarding the export of live sheep is well known to everyone in this chamber. We believe that such trade on the whole is inhuman. That is a strange word to use in relation to sheep, but I think honourable senators know what I mean. It shows a blatant disregard for the welfare of the animals involved. Some honourable senators may respond by arguing that the welfare of the sheep has to be protected for them to be saleable at their destination. Taking this view though sees the animal's welfare from a commercial perspective only and is certainly not the approach the Democrats would want to take.

The specific issue I want to pick up is whether or not we need to be exporting as many live sheep as we are currently. The Democrats believe that the live sheep export trade is not only inhuman but we also question the economic value of the trade. In saying that, I acknowledge that often large numbers of live sheep are required by middle eastern countries for various Muslim festivals and that on these occasions we are able to charge a premium price for our sheep.

However, the Democrats take the view—and I notice that this line was also run by the Labor member for Paterson (Mr Horne) in the other place—that we should be exploring the possibility of negotiating arrangements with the countries to which we presently export live sheep so that the slaughter of those sheep is undertaken in Australia in accordance with Muslim requirements. I understand that on some occasions this occurs in Australia through a process known as hal-al slaughtering. The slaughter is conducted under the supervision or the approval of a Muslim official, and there are quite a number of abattoirs in Australia currently certified by AQIS to conduct such slaughtering. Clearly, if an animal is to be slaughtered, then from an animal welfare perspective it is far more desirable to have that done in Australia as it avoids subjecting the animals to the lengthy and arduous trip to Saudi Arabia. The benefits of slaughtering the animals in Australia are obvious often in terms of the enormous boost it would also provide to our domestic meat industry.

Our live sheep exports in the year ending June 1993 to countries such as Kuwait, Oman, Jordan and the United Arab Emirates, were worth about $119 million. Despite the suspension of our trade with Saudi Arabia we are still exporting over five million live sheep per year. If the trade were to recommence with Saudi Arabia we could expect this figure to increase to somewhere over six million sheep a year being exported from this country.

It seems to me that if we could encourage the development of a system whereby at least some of these sheep are slaughtered in Australia and carcasses exported, the benefits economically and in terms of jobs, particularly if our trade was to resume to Saudi Arabia, could be enormous. I urge the government and the AMLC to explore this further with the industry and with the nations involved in the live sheep trade.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the opposition and the Australian Democrats for their support of this legislation. I want to touch on only three matters very briefly in response to the speakers. Firstly, I will speak about the live sheep trade to Saudi Arabia and the particular problems we have had with the cessation of that trade over the last year or 18 months. There was some criticism earlier in the debate that we should be doing more to bring about the resumption of that trade.

PARA.TAB: The Australian government has been having close consultations with the live sheep industry and is actively trying to bring about the resumption of the live sheep trade with Saudi Arabia on a satisfactory basis. It should be noted that the live sheep exports to the Middle East region in fact increased over the last year since the cessation of the trade with Saudi Arabia. In 1990-91 some 2.87 million head of sheep, valued at $43.7 million, were exported. In 1991-92 that number increased to just over four million head, valued at $78.9 million—a 40 per cent increase in numbers and an 80 per cent increase in value. The government is very much aware of the importance of the live sheep trade to Australian producers and is continuing to concentrate its efforts on the development and expansion of this trade.

The second area of criticism from the opposition, which we hear fairly regularly and somewhat monotonously at times, relates to the alleged slow pace of waterfront reform. I do not want to go into the very detailed nature of the restructuring that has taken place on the waterfront, except to say that it has been very substantial. The number of people employed on the waterfront has dropped very considerably over the last decade and the government is continuing on the essential micro- and macro-economic reforms in the transport sector. Whilst in some areas the immediate cost reductions have not been evident, we have to remember that the cost of the changes to the waterfront is being amortised over a number of years and that the cost savings will become more and more apparent over the next year or two as that amortisation of the cost of restructuring is brought to an end.

I want to refer briefly to the third matter that was raised. Senator Boswell quite rightly raised the critical issue of value adding. He referred to the fairly poor—not poor in the sense of making a criticism, but poor in the sense of the Australian effort—direct involvement of our primary producers in value adding, particularly in the export market. We have not had great success in this area. This has been a very strong theme of the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Simon Crean. I know that changes are occurring in the value adding area.

In my capacity as chair of the citrus working group and the horticultural task force, it is a little sad to reflect that of the 100 major primary industry exporting companies in the world, not one is Australian. One of the critical problems that the National Farmers Federation has identified is the need for farmers to be more directly involved in that export sector.

Senator Boswell raised the issue of the Foreign Investment Review Board and the possible purchase by ConAgra of AMH and the 45 per cent stake-holding that Fosters currently wishes to sell. I certainly share Senator Boswell's concern for increased value adding and the need to give our primary producers the opportunity to be more directly involved in this sector.

Only yesterday I was talking to citrus growers in Griffith about the citrus working group's report on restructuring the industry. I also talked about the Sunkist organisation in the United States. Sunkist is a citrus export company which is owned by growers. Down the production scale, that export company commissions packing houses and growers to pack for it, to grow for it and then it exports on behalf of the growers, returning a dividend to the growers. It is a very successful organisation and it is certainly the type of organisation we hope to see develop more in Australia.

On behalf of the government, I certainly cannot give any indications or commitments about the direction of the Foreign Investment Review Board's decisions in respect of the possible takeover by ConAgra and the extension of its already significant involvement in the rural sector. I have obtained a copy of Senator Boswell's speech. I will be speaking to my minister, Simon Crean, and George Gear, the Assistant Treasurer, who I understand is responsible for this area, about the necessity to improve on the current value adding, particularly by Australian companies and Australian primary producers where that is possible. I will certainly be taking that issue up with the appropriate ministers.
Finally, I would like again to thank Senator Woodley, who spoke on behalf of the Democrats, for his contribution to this debate and his support of the legislation.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without amendment or debate.

DEBATE.TITLE: SUPERANNUATION (RESOLUTION OF COMPLAINTS) BILL 1993SUPERANNUATION (FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE FUNDING) LEVY BILL 1993SUPERANNUATION (ROLLED-OVER BENEFITS) LEVY BILL 1993SUPERANNUATION INDUSTRY (SUPERVISION) CONSEQUENTIAL AMENDMENTS BILL 1993SUPERANNUATION INDUSTRY (SUPERVISION) BILL 1993OCCUPATIONAL SUPERANNUATION STANDARDS AMENDMENT BILL 1993SUPERANNUATION SUPERVISORY LEVY AMENDMENT BILL 1993

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 6 October, 18 October, 19 October, and 28 September, on motions by Senator Bolkus, McMullan and Robert Ray:
That these bills be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight we have before us for debate a package of seven bills to give effect to the prudential arrangements for superannuation announced by the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) on 21 October 1992 in his statement entitled `Strengthening super security—new prudential arrangements for superannuation'. These bills and, in particular, the Superannuation Industry (Supervision) Bill, are some of the most significant legislation to come before the parliament in the life of this government. They represent the most detailed and far-reaching attempt in the history of superannuation in Australia to impose a common regulatory framework in the superannuation industry. They reflect the constructive approach of the committee system in the Senate where bipartisanship and teamwork have been above politics in determining a system of laws and rules for the good administrative practice in the national interest.

PARA.TAB: The measures will affect almost every superannuation fund in Australia, including approved deposit funds and pooled superannuation trusts. Superannuation funds take a number of forms, with the main categories being personal superannuation funds, industry based funds, individual enterprise schemes and government funded schemes. The need for increased supervision of the industry is highlighted by the volume of money under the control of the superannuation funds, the diverse range of funds operating, the Maxwell case in the UK and the introduction of the superannuation guarantee charge, which has removed the voluntary nature of superannuation funds for most employees. These issues underline the need for increased supervision.

If the government forces employers to contribute to superannuation on behalf of their employees—and often employees have no choice as to the fund into which the contributions are directed—employees are entitled to expect measures to exist which protect those funds that are set aside for their benefit. Broadly based superannuation arrangements have now been with us for six years. While still in its infancy in many ways, the superannuation industry is a rapidly growing collection of professionals and financial institutions. Money under control of superannuation funds currently stands at $169 billion. Superannuation funds are estimated to increase to between $300 billion and $600 billion by the year 2000.

I believe that superannuation in Australia is now on the threshold of adopting a regulatory regime and structure which is unique in the OECD world. To move to a single entity superannuation fund trust structure, involving codification of trustee responsibilities, is a development which overseas countries will observe with a great deal of interest. The Australian system of super fund regulation could well become the template for regulation in other countries. In this regard, it is worth noting that the Goode report in Britain has made a number of recommendations which are in keeping with certain SIS provisions.

Having said that, I am very surprised to read that the government believes that the reviews of superannuation should cease. The assurance of a hands-off approach to allow the industry to settle down after the SIS bills, apart from some finetuning, is not, I would say, a welcome comment. There are many unanswered policy questions which must be answered. Dr Fitzgerald, for example, has called for a final report since the government has promised each time it has unveiled major changes in the last five years that it would be the last change. To close down the debate on super policy would be a dangerous course of action. The reviews which have taken place in recent years have played a significant role in getting the superannuation industry to where it is today.

It cannot be forgotten that the superannuation industry is also becoming a great source of tax revenue. Last year, the 1992-93 year, the tax on superannuation funds reached $1.522 billion, an increase of 33.6 per cent on the previous year and a massive increase of 180 per cent on the 1990-91 year. Five years ago the tax just did not exist. The threefold layering of superannuation—at entry, in the fund and on exit—as practised in Australia, is a unique feature in this country. Other countries have only one or two superannuation taxes, not three.

The Senate Select Committee on Superannuation, which I have the privilege of chairing, tabled its ninth report on the SIS legislation in the last week of sitting. The committee received nearly 100 written submissions. It convened public hearings on the bills in Sydney, Melbourne and Canberra. In addition, informal meetings were arranged between the committee members and officers of the ISC at which amendments to improve the legislation were discussed. I thank the government and the members of the ISC for their participation. I think the end result is that we have a much better regime. It just shows that cooperation between the parliament and the executive can contribute to a better overall result.

While addressing many issues and making a number of recommendations, a number of these recommendations deal with areas of superannuation apart from the SIS bills, which I will not specifically refer to now. The committee has recommended amendments to the SIS bill, the Superannuation Industry (Supervision) Consequential Amendments Bill and the Superannuation (Resolution of Complaints) Bill.

The Superannuation Industry (Supervision) Bill is the central plank of the new policy platform. It contains provisions which will radically alter the way the superannuation funds operate. It is designed to increase the level of prudential protection provided to the superannuation industry, strengthen the security of superannuation savings, and increase the protection and rights of superannuation fund members. Given the magnitude of the proposed change, it was not surprising that the committee received 97 submissions and agreed to take evidence from more than 60 witnesses, representing the interests of superannuation providers, regulators and consumers.

Perhaps the most controversial aspect of the SIS legislation has been clause 64—formerly clause 63 of the SIS bill—which contained a blanket prohibition on superannuation funds acquiring assets from members or members' relatives. Of the submissions received by the committee, approximately one-half of them—particularly from the very small businesses—were concerned with the impact of this clause. The object of clause 64, which is designed to take effect from 27 May 1993, is to be an anti-avoidance measure to prevent superannuation fund members selling their assets to their superannuation fund in order to obtain certain cash benefits.

The majority of the written submissions addressing this clause focused on the following areas of concern: first, that the complete prohibition was too harsh as it discriminated against legitimate business transactions and small business activities; second, that it prevented people from funding their own superannuation and therefore particularly discriminated against the self-employed; third, that it failed to take into account the same types of investments held in different names; fourth, that it appears easy to avoid simply by interposing another entity between the superannuation fund and the member—we did ask the ISC to look at this to try to overcome this particular problem; and, finally, that it imposed a gaol sentence for breaches, which we believe is too severe.

The majority report of the committee has recommended that the following types of assets be allowed to be acquired from members or members' relatives: freehold or leasehold property which reflects true market value that is used wholly and exclusively in the business of the member or member's relatives. During the committee stage I intend to move an amendment to modify this particular provision so that for excluded funds, that is, fewer than five members, there will be no more than 40 per cent interest and for others, that is, more than five members, 25 per cent interest will apply as a means of putting in place a further prudential control to make sure that it could not be exploited to the detriment of anybody involved. Assets able to be acquired also included listed securities, which means shares, units, bonds or debentures, rights or options, or any other security listed for quotation in the official list of a stock exchange.

The committee further recommended that the sole purpose test be strengthened to ensure that any asset or assets included in the exemption provided under clause 64 acquired by the superannuation fund from a member or member's relative does not contravene the sole purpose test. Another major issue surrounding clause 64 is the penalty of two years gaol for a breach of the provision. When comparing the appropriateness of this penalty, one has to have regard to the severity and nature of the mischief that the provision is designed to prevent. In some circumstances, gaol may be appropriate but in other circumstances it is too harsh. The committee recommended that penalty points be introduced and that the time period be reduced to one year, and the final result of the opposition's amendment, which I foreshadow, will be to limit it to one year's gaol sentence because the crimes provisions provide that one year's gaol is equal to a 60 penalty points fine.

The constitutional power over superannuation and state public sector superannuation schemes was a problem. The Commonwealth does not have a single and exclusive constitutional head of power over superannuation. In its first report the committee recommended that the government explore the possibility of obtaining a referral by the states of their power over superannuation. The issues arising from the SIS legislation indicate that this is now a central issue. Accordingly, the committee has recommended that the government revisit the recommendations of its first report.

The referral of superannuation powers from the states to the Commonwealth was further highlighted in the application of the SIS legislation to state and territory public sector superannuation schemes. Following representations by the states and territories concerning the perceived infringement by the Commonwealth on state rights as a consequence of certain SIS provisions, the committee has recommended that the government negotiate with the states and territories to have their super schemes exempted from the SIS legislation. Clearly, if there was a referral by the states and territories of their power over superannuation to the Commonwealth, such exemptions would not be necessary.

The committee considered at length proposals to allow superannuation funds to have enhanced access to tax file numbers. I need not remind the Senate that TFNs and their use arouse a number of sensitivities about privacy. The committee heard compelling evidence about the need to use TFNs to allow the new eligible rollover funds to work efficiently. However, there was equally compelling evidence from the Privacy Commissioner on the need for caution in expanding the use of TFNs. The committee recommended—and I expect that the SIS bills will ultimately be amended accordingly—that superannuation funds be allowed to use TFNs for taxation and transfer of benefit purposes and that this provision take effect from the date that the bill receives royal assent.

The role of actuaries and auditors under the SIS bills is a matter which has not been the subject of intense or widespread media scrutiny or comment. Yet, after the watchdog activities of members, auditors and actuaries will be the first line of defence in detecting any wrongdoing by fund operators. The committee has recommended increased auditor protection to correspond with the increased responsibilities of auditors. In addition, it has again recommended that consideration be given to the establishment of a register of suitably qualified superannuation auditors.

One of the major focuses of the report was on the impact of the SIS legislation on public offer funds. These now account for $14 billion of super savings and are currently operated on a dual entity basis between the trustee and the fund manager. Arguably, the most significant change to the superannuation industry by the SIS legislation concerns the requirement that public offer funds cease to operate on this dual entity basis and move to a single responsible entity. This accords with the recommendations contained in two Australian Law Reform Commission reports. Obviously, such a single entity requirement represents a massive departure from the current operating structure, the magnitude of which is incalculable when one considers the membership and investments in public offer funds.

Although the committee fully supports the single entity approach, it is concerned at the lack of accompanying transitional arrangements for such change, particularly in the area of who should be appointed as the single responsible entity and how any conflict between the two entities should be resolved when it arises. From the written submissions and the evidence, it became clear that the government will need to monitor the transition process closely to ensure that unnecessary confusion and uncertainty does not occur. The last thing that super needs is 200,000 disaffected retirees who have money in a public offer fund.

The committee has maintained an interest in maximising the welfare of consumers under the new super regime. The committee recognised that if the new super system is to work it must have the support of the public. In order to get this support, consumers must have confidence in the integrity of every facet. Vigilance, by both government and the industry, is needed over the day-to-day operation of all super funds. The Superannuation Complaints Tribunal will be the vanguard of this initiative. The committee found that the tribunal should have a wide-ranging brief in all matters except medical evidence.

The committee also recommended that another layer of accountability be instituted. This will take the form of providing members with an independent advisory service which, initially, would be funded from consolidated revenue. The coalition intends to move a number of amendments which I will outline during the committee stage of the debate.

In conclusion, the Senate Select Committee on Superannuation has been involved with this package of bills since its appointment in 1991. To this end, in its first report it set out the parameters and in subsequent reports `fine-tuned' its approach to superannuation. This report is the culmination of work on the regulation of superannuation. During the process it became increasingly apparent that specialist committees have an important role to play in complex legislation such as the package of bills currently before us. It is also apparent that the new system of referral of bills to committees allows public and competing views to be taken into account in the passage of legislation.

Overwhelmingly, the superannuation committee worked in a non-partisan way in reporting on the bills. As Chairman, having succeeded Senator Sherry, I wish to give special thanks to Senator Sue West who was my deputy, Senator Bruce Childs, Senator Chris Evans, Senator Alan Ferguson and Senator Cheryl Kernot; the secretariat staff comprising Richard Gilbert, Krista Gerrard, Glenn Hunter and Cath Drinkwater; Gary Johns, for the work he did in his supporting role; and the ISC officers, including the Commissioner, Trevor Thomas the ISC policy officer, George Pooley and Donald Duvall.

The legislation is, as I have mentioned, a blueprint for other countries to set up superannuation regulation mechanisms. However, in closing I must issue a note of caution. The mere enactment of legislation to regulate superannuation funds does not guarantee security for members of funds. It is now the job of trustees, members and the Insurance and Superannuation Commission, as regulator, to hold the superannuation system together. The ISC, as the committee has said time and time again, needs to be pro-active, alert and an effective regulator. I believe it has done this exceedingly well today and I wish it well in the future under its capable leadership. These bills give the ISC that power and it is now its responsibility to discharge its newly established statutory obligations.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot Sen C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator KERNOT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —As we have heard, the Senate is currently debating seven bills which collectively establish a new system of prudential supervision of Australia's burgeoning superannuation system. The seven bills are the Superannuation Industry (Supervision) Bill, the Superannuation Industry (Resolution of Complaints) Bill, the Superannuation Industry (Supervision) Consequential Amendments Bill, the Occupational Superannuation Standards Amendment Bill, the Superannuation (Financial Assistance Funding) Levy Bill, the Superannuation Supervisory Levy Amendment Bill and the Superannuation (Rolled-Over Benefits) Levy Bill 1993.

PARA.TAB: These bills arise out of the need identified in the first report of the Senate Select Committee on Superannuation, entitled Safeguarding Super, for a better system of supervision and regulation of the superannuation industry. They also arise out of a commitment the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) gave the Australian Democrats when we agreed to pass the superannuation guarantee charge if, and only if, appropriate prudential supervision legislation were passed by this parliament. The Treasurer said he would do so; it has been a long time between the SGC being enacted and our debating these bills today—an election campaign has intervened—but I am pleased that we are taking the steps we are this evening.

Collectively, this package before the chamber marks one of the most important legislative packages this year. It provides a proper system of prudential supervision and a simple disputes resolution process for superannuation funds which already account for more than $169 billion in assets and a membership of 70 per cent of the Australian work force. I think it is fair that the Democrats can take some credit in that, after 10 years of regular change to superannuation—usually the old legislation by press release—the Democrats moved in early 1991 to establish the Senate Select Committee on Superannuation. In its two years of operation, the committee has established a strong reputation for pro-active and imaginative dealings with the wide array of difficult issues in the superannuation industry.

I want to pay credit to the work of the committee members over the last two years and the two chairs, Senator Nick Sherry—I find it amazing that the committee chair is now the parliamentary secretary assisting this evening in the passage of this legislation—and Senator John Watson, both of whom have contributed significantly to a broadly tripartite approach to committee work. I also pay tribute to the immensely dedicated, conscientious and capable secretariat led by Richard Gilbert. It is with some regret that I leave the committee's membership—

TALK.START.PARA: —Temporarily.

—Temporarily, Senator Watson hopes. I have a lot to do these days. This committee has demonstrated what an effective watchdog and policy initiator a well run and pro-active parliamentary committee can be.

PARA.TAB: These SIS bills, as we call them, have been the subject of extensive public debate since their tabling last year. The Senate Select Committee on Superannuation has also held hearings on the bills. It proposed a range of amendments in its ninth report, which Senator Watson has outlined, and most of these amendments have been accepted by the government.

The first bill, the Superannuation Industry (Supervision) Bill, is, in our view, the most important of the seven SIS bills. It codifies the protection and rights of superannuation fund members, it increases the security of their savings and details black law standards for the conduct of the superannuation industry. It is one thing to compel people to put their money in; the other half of the equation of responsibility for us is to make sure that, because of appropriate prudential supervision, that money is there when people need to draw on it. The bill also expands the powers and the role of the Insurance and Superannuation Commission, establishing a single pro-active industry regulator.

Matters encompassed in this bill include the constitution, powers and types of superannuation funds; the roles and responsibilities of trustees, managers, custodians and employers; arrangements governing investments, assets and reserves of superannuation funds; the treatment of fund surpluses and unclaimed benefits; the obligations of auditors and actuaries; and provisions to protect fund members from losses incurred through fraud or theft. As we can see, it is extremely comprehensive. The bill replaces many provisions of the Occupational Superannuation Standards Act of 1987 which are to be repealed.

The second bill, the Superannuation Industry (Resolution and Complaints) Bill, will require funds to become more accountable to their members by giving access to a low cost dispute resolution mechanism. If disputes or grievances cannot be settled within the fund, members shall have a right to review by a new Superannuation Complaints Tribunal.

The third bill, the Superannuation Industry (Supervision) Consequential Amendments Bill 1993, in conjunction with the Superannuation Supervisory Levy Amendment Bill, amends the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936, the Supervisory Levy Act 1991 and other acts following the repeal of sections of the Occupational Superannuation Standards Act. Consequently, the Bankruptcy Act 1966 is amended to better protect superannuation and life insurance moneys in the event of bankruptcy.

The next bill, the Superannuation (Financial Assistance Funding) Levy Bill, in conjunction with the Superannuation (Rolled-Over Benefits) Levy Bill, provides for the imposition of levies on certain superannuation funds for the purposes of recouping the cost of maintenance by the ISC of a register of certain rolled-over benefits. The government estimates that the additional resources needed by the ISC to administer the act will be $4.83 million in 1993-94. This will be collected under this new levy.

Regulations to be issued under part 19 of the SIS bill will require disclosure of fees, charges and commissions relating to superannuation. This is an issue that the Democrats and others have been particularly concerned about. This was covered by the sixth report of this select committee. I take the opportunity to urge the ISC to consult widely in framing these regulations to ensure that the interests of consumers are fully protected.

Notwithstanding the additional action yet to be taken, the position of consumers vis-a-vis the funds will improve dramatically under the legislation. However, I must make the observation that, with seven new bills and possibly 1,000 new regulations to add to the morass of law governing superannuation, the likelihood that consumers will be fully aware of their rights is becoming increasingly remote. Despite the efforts of consumer groups, unions and superannuants associations, there is still effectively no single body to which fund members can turn for advice.

For these reasons, the Democrats have called on the government to support the establishment and funding of independent community based superannuation legal and information centres. These centres should follow the trailblazing success of the consumer credit legal centres, which have already proved their worth with settlements for consumers set to total more than $5 million this year. To ensure that the benefit of the service is extended to all states, consumer groups estimate a set-up cost of something like $666,000 for the service.

Although this goes further than the Senate committee report recommendation, I really would urge the government to consider undertaking to provide such funding. I intend to move an amendment to require the minister to provide access to independent advice. I will also move an amendment to clause 16 of the resolution of complaints bill to achieve this.
