I will also move an amendment to clause 23 of the tribunal bill to expand the right to representation before the tribunal to include complainants with a limited ability to speak, read or write English or where the tribunal would consider it necessary in the interests of fairness.

A further consumer issue of concern to the Democrats has been the stated intention of the government to exclude complaints over disability claims from the jurisdiction of the Superannuation Complaints Tribunal. The Senate committee has taken evidence of problems which consumers have had obtaining payouts on disability claims from some superannuation funds. Documented stories of claims taking many months to process and of trustees accepting the advice of the insurer without any proper consideration abound.

The stress that such treatment adds to individuals already suffering from physical and financial loss is worthy of our attention. Although the Senate committee has recommended a partial expansion of the tribunal's jurisdiction to cover procedural fairness and disability claims, I would still urge the government to go further and to provide full access to the tribunal even on medical grounds. Inclusion of complaints on such medical grounds has been successfully handled by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal and the Veterans' Review Board. I think one can argue that limitations on jurisdiction are likely to cause significant disputation and confusion over the years to come.

The SIS bills contain a number of new rules governing the investments to be made or not made by superannuation funds. Part 8 provides a range of rules governing the level of in-house assets funds will be permitted to have. These rules should help to avoid a repeat of a Robert Maxwell style run-down of employee superannuation funds by an employer. Part 7 of the bill also prohibits lending of assets to members of superannuation funds and the buying of assets by the fund from members of the fund. This latter provision in clause 64 has probably become the most controversial aspect of the bill and most of the submissions to the Senate select committee dealt with this provision.

On the one hand, the government has argued that clause 64 will close a significant tax avoidance provision whereby members transfer assets into superannuation at a concessional tax rate. The arrangements are used primarily by the self-employed who already account for about $2 billion of the $5 billion the government forgoes in superannuation taxation concessions. The government has argued that the provision will ensure that superannuation funds are preserved and used solely for the accumulation of retirement income.

On the other hand, small business groups, the Law Council and the accountants association have argued that the government is seeking to crack a walnut with a sledgehammer. In particular, the Democrats are concerned that the clause, as it was originally drafted, could adversely affect smaller superannuation funds. There appeared to be an assumption that members of small funds were incapable of running their own investment funds without engaging in tax avoidance; in other words, tax avoidance was their primary motivation.

The Senate committee was critical of clause 64, and a majority proposed that an exemption should be made available for certain marketable securities and for business freehold or leasehold property leased wholly and exclusively for the purpose of a business. Personal property of a member used for private purposes should remain excluded. I will wait to hear the government's arguments.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have modified that.

—I know that the opposition has modified it. Subject to the debate yet to come, I indicate that the Democrats are likely to support Senator Watson's amendment which will allow for small funds to acquire these assets subject to a maximum level and set by reference to the size of the fund and the type of membership. Such purposes will also be subject to the requirement of the sole purpose test in clause 58 and to the provision of the exchange being at market value.

PARA.TAB: I could not leave this debate without talking about our continued disappointment in relation to the rules governing investment by superannuation funds and our disappointment at the reluctance of the government and the opposition to countenance some small direction of investment. If one looks at what has already been raised by the superannuation guarantee charge, one sees that total funds in superannuation rose to $169 billion by June of this year. These are in funds controlled predominantly by a small number of large institutions. Of that $169 billion, some $26 billion was invested overseas.

I know of our call to look at that, and that the committee's first report said it would review it after three years. Time is ticking on. I am pleased to see, though, that the institutions, through the Australian investment managers group, have started to exercise considerable collective clout on the stock market. As Jennifer Hewitt noted in a recent Financial Review article:

SPEECH.PARA: It all means that even small shifts in institutional thinking have the potential to give a powerful kick to the market because of the immense value of their investments.
I am pleased to note that this is being acknowledged.

PARA.TAB: The Democrats have always argued that as superannuation funds are to be our major pool of capital, a small percentage of that money should be required to be invested in the national interest. We are not talking about the notion of picking winners; we are talking about the fact that there are ways in which we can do this. It can be done for the benefit of the nation as a whole, and those people who are willing to take this longer term risk ought to have the opportunity of doing so.

Savings in the hands of trustees are governed by a rationale which is totally different from that contemplated by free market theory. Fundamentally, because of fiduciary duties made even clearer by these SIS bills, trustees are in the business of risk aversion rather than wealth maximisation. This is demonstrated in the holdings of superannuation funds, with 55 per cent basically in blue chip stock and almost 40 per cent in cash and interest bearing deposits. There is no nationalism—no national interest—about risk aversion. I think it is a worry that at a time when many dynamic small Australian businesses cannot get access to capital for love or money there is almost $26 billion in assets invested overseas. The Australian Democrats have called in the past—and we repeat the call—for the establishment of a national development fund, made up of just one per cent of the assets of superannuation funds, to provide venture capital for Australian firms. We have also called for restrictions on the amount that can be invested overseas. With such a massive pool, given a major boost by compulsory superannuation contributions, members of the Australian public have a right to expect that at least a small proportion of their funds will be invested in developing the nation's future. It is not true to say that people would automatically lose out, because the benefits of anything which adds to overall economic development are shared by all of us.

It is pleasing to note that the government has belatedly realised the importance of the big institutions in the Australian stock market and that the Joint Statutory Committee on Corporations and Securities is to inquire into the role of institutional investors and their impact on capital markets and corporate regulation. That should be an interesting inquiry. Perhaps we can already predict what some of its findings will be. I commend this very important package of seven bills to the chamber.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ferguson Sen A.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak to this package of superannuation bills, which for the most part will be of great benefit to our ever-growing superannuation industry. I support my colleague Senator Watson and the comments that he made in speaking to these bills both as a Liberal senator and as Chairman of the Select Committee on Superannuation.

PARA.TAB: I guess it is fair to say that most consumers will not even be aware of the superannuation industry supervision bills—that probably is one of the problems that Senator Kernot was alluding to in her contribution—but I am sure that they will appreciate that through these bills their funds will be safer and the industry will be placed under far more stringent control.

As a member of the committee which looked at these bills so thoroughly, I am pleased that so many of the recommendations that have been made have been agreed to or certainly are under consideration by the government. Of the recommendations that were made, a vast majority have been accepted and a couple were considered to be unnecessary. There really were only three major areas of concern at the end of the day. I hope that the amendments that have been circulated by Senator Watson will satisfy the government's wishes in regard to these three major areas of concern. I think that is a very good result.

The importance of committees in bringing about these changes to legislation is not often commented on in this chamber. I would like to place on record my belief that the exhaustive process that the committee has gone through has been very worth while, particularly in this case. One of the witnesses who appeared before the committee certainly endorses this view. During our public hearing in Melbourne, Mr John Fraser, director of John R. Fraser Pty Ltd, said:

SPEECH.PARA: We little thought when we sent our original submission in August that we would have the opportunity to expand on our thoughts. It is extremely pleasing to see that the top level of government extends the courtesy and consideration to people such as me, because we believe that we are pretty small time.

I think that only highlights the effectiveness of this committee and many other committees in giving the opportunity to average Australians, no matter how small their businesses may be, to at least put their point of view before a Senate committee.

PARA.TAB: Having said that, I would like to draw the Senate's attention to my major area of concern—clause 64. Under this clause the government is seeking to prohibit funds from intentionally acquiring assets from members or their relatives and from providing any other financial assistance to members; attempting to resolve the sole purpose test, which is to determine whether a super fund is operating solely as a fund to provide retirement benefits; and aiming to prevent abuses of current legislation where members sell personal assets such as houses, boats, cars, et cetera, to super funds. This legislation proposes a penalty of two years gaol for breaching this clause.

Of all the issues raised during the hearings and in most of the evidence that we received, this was the most controversial, the most troublesome and, I believe, the most difficult to come up with a meaningful resolution for. While I hope that the compromise amendment will satisfy the government's requests, I would like to point out that there are still several problems raised by this clause, not the least of which, as evidence would suggest, is that perhaps it can be legally circumvented.

The committee found that there should be a relaxation of the blanket ban on funds acquiring assets from members and members' relatives; that funds should be allowed to acquire at market value leasehold or freehold property that is used wholly and exclusively in the business of a member or a member's relative; that funds should be allowed to purchase certain strictly defined marketable securities; and that the penalty should be a maximum of 200 penalty points—that is, $20,000—and/or 12 months in gaol.

Those decisions of the committee were taken only after a lot of discussion and deliberation. I am sure Senator Chris Evans, who is in the chamber, will remember that there was a considerable amount of discussion on these issues, and it was probably the only area where there was any disagreement of any major proportion in the committee.

The proposed amendment has been drafted so that, if the asset is classified as `business real property', the acquisition of that property, together with any other business real property previously acquired, does not exceed 40 per cent of the total value of assets of the fund for excluded superannuation funds, and 25 per cent of the total value of the assets of the fund for other types of funds where there are employee members. I believe that the situation that we arrived at after all the discussions took place was very reasonable.

As a result, if this amendment is passed, a member of a superannuation fund or a member's relative will be able to sell assets to super funds only under limited circumstances. I personally think there are valid arguments that the definition of assets should be wider, but I can live with the compromise that we have reached.

The problem lies in the fact that, as far as I can see, these same limits will not be applied if members sell their assets to someone else's fund or if they sell their asset to another company which then onsells the asset to the fund. Because of this, the amendments will be meaningless to the people who have figured out some way of getting around those regulations.

Let us say that Senator Chris Evans and I both had our own superannuation funds. Under the SIS legislation, I would be prevented from selling my commercial property bought for investment purposes, investment art works, insurance policies or unlisted securities to my fund. Senator Evans would be prevented from selling his similar investments to his super fund. But under this legislation I can sell my investments to his fund or he can sell his to my fund, provided we are not engaging in any anti-avoidance measures.

TALK.START.PARA: —You wouldn't want my investments.

—I would watch them very carefully. I think this is pretty clearly a nonsensical situation. Equally ridiculous is the situation where, under the amended SIS legislation, fund members and their relatives will be forced into selling assets like investment property to a company, which can then sell the property to the fund in order for the member to gain access to cash.

PARA.TAB: All this does is add another personal company to the equation, at a cost to the fund member because of the added costs involved in going through another party—extra stamp duty fees, costs of selling, et cetera. For what purpose? It will only put more money in the pockets of brokers and state commissioners for stamp duty.

We are here to make laws for the benefit of Australian people and I personally cannot see the benefit to the Australian people of their not being able to sell that property to their super fund when they can sell it to a company which then sells it to their super fund, or when they can sell it to somebody else's fund.
During evidence given to the committee, Mr Ian Kincaid, the director of Supermaster Investments, after outlining a situations I have just described, said:

SPEECH.PARA: I think for once you have got to get a step ahead of some of the lawyers and the smarties around and get back to the very basics. What are we trying to prevent? We are trying to prevent, firstly, bodgie investments going into super and, secondly, this happening at unreal prices. These are the only two issues.

PARA.TAB: Unfortunately, these issues would only begin to be addressed in relation to members and their relatives. Any other Tom, Dick or Harry—I suppose in these days I had better say Sue, Jane or Mary for that matter—can sell assets which satisfy the sole purpose test to super funds. I would like to quote from Mr Fraser's evidence to the committee. He said that the only beneficiaries of clause 64 will be `life offices, banks, additional cost collectors, dodgy promoters who will quickly find alternatives to rip-off the superannuation system. I really believe that'. They were Mr Fraser's words when he was giving evidence to the committee.

Many suggestions were made to the committee about better ways of handling this issue. One of those suggestions, from the Trustee Companies Association, was that the trustee be permitted to acquire assets from the member or relative of a member where the trustee is satisfied that the investment complies with the covenant prescribed by section 49(2)(f) and is acquired for a price certified as a fair market price by a valuer appointed by the trustee and independent of the member.

Mr Geoffrey Doyle from Priestly and Morris suggested that a prohibited asset be defined as the principal place of residence, motor vehicles or a listed personal-use asset as defined under section 160B(2)(a) of the Income Tax Assessment Act. So plenty of suggestions were given to us as to the way we should go about it. Hunt and Hunt submitted to the committee that the clause should control the type of asset which a trustee might invest in, instead of the identity of the vendor, and that the identity of the vendor ought not to be significant as long as the investment is appropriate, commercial and at arm's length.

I move on to the second issue which I was concerned about—penalties in relation to a breach of clause 64. I am pleased that the amendment circulated by Senator Watson recommends the reduction from two years to 12 months, because I do not believe that the public would want a person who sold his or her own home to a superannuation fund, for instance, as a breach of those guidelines, to receive the same sentence that might be applied to someone who committed a serious violent crime. With the way penalties are going in our courts these days, it is quite possible that the auditor could get two years gaol under this legislation for a breach of the penalty but that a guy who shoots the auditor for doing it might finish up serving only the same amount of time.

In conclusion, I would like to place on record that, following the release of the committee's recommendations, the committee has been criticised strongly by the chairman of the Australian Society of Certified Practising Accountants, Mr Robert Brown, for not going far enough. He said clause 64 is `unnecessary, ineffective, unprincipled and farcical'. However, as I have stated, I am pleased with the agreements that have been reached, even if I personally may have hoped for more in some areas, particularly in relation to clause 64 and the definition and purchase of assets.

I hope that this legislation can be built on in the future. I will be keeping a watch on all these areas where the government has indicated that the committee's recommendations will be taken into consideration. In particular, I will obviously be keeping an eye on what happens with regard to clause 64. I support the committee report, together with the amendments that have been circulated by Senator Watson, and I certainly support the thrust of these bills and what the government is trying to achieve in making sure that we have adequate—

TALK.START.PARA: —And keeping the cost down.

—Yes, but in making sure also that we have adequate prudential controls over the industry. Having been involved in the industry for some seven years, I am certainly personally aware of many of the things that needed to be put right, particularly in the supervision area and particularly with regard to prudential controls. I certainly commend to the Senate the bills and the amendments that have been circulated in Senator Watson's name.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak to the superannuation bills because I wish to point out to the government that there are some matters in relation to superannuation that it has not yet dealt with and that I regard as urgent. These seven bills, as has already been stated, strengthen and codify the prudential standards for superannuation funds. I do not think anybody who has spoken or participated in this debate doubts the need for this or fails to support it.

PARA.TAB: But, in spite of the number of bills that have gone through the parliament since the Labor government came into operation—there have been something like 80 pieces of legislation in 10 or so years that have dealt with superannuation—I do not think that the government has really come to terms with the fact that retirement income is a very important issue in our community.

The government does not yet seem to have recognised that the quite rapid ageing of the population into the years of the next century will have a significant impact on a lot of people. There will be fewer taxpayers than at present; there will be more people beyond working age. There is, I think, an urgent need to deal with retirement income policy in a realistic fashion, particularly for women, who so far have been virtually ignored by Labor's policies. I am not suggesting for a minute that the government has not done anything at all, but it has not dealt with half the population.

The figures indicate the considerable increase in the amount of money that has gone into superannuation funds—from $32.6 billion in 1983 to $140 billion in 1992. With the superannuation guarantee charge, that amount will rise significantly. So it is absolutely essential to deal with the management of the funds—to see that that is done properly, that there is little risk of funds failing and members' money being lost, and that there is a minimum risk of fraud, misappropriation or things of that nature.

The Select Committee on Superannuation, whose report Safeguarding super has been quoted tonight, stated that it was `conscious that increases in superannuation savings will inevitably attract operators who will seek to use superannuation moneys for their own use'. That is pretty strong stuff and it is important that the government has responded, I think, with the legislation we have before us tonight.

Previously, the legislation sought to regulate indirectly. This package of bills regulates more directly. But it is the other areas that I mentioned that still need to be pointed out. There are three in particular. The first I refer to is the fees and charges which are being charged by superannuation funds at the present time which erode the value of super. It certainly does so for those who are part-time workers, of whom women form a considerable section.

The second is the inability of anybody who has been out of paid employment for more than two years to pay into a super fund. Again, significantly, it is women who fall into that category. I can see absolutely no rational explanation for why that should continue, why we cannot devise rules for superannuation which enable it to continue beyond a period of two years so that one could start paying in again in the future, why one cannot have a superannuation fund that remains intact when one changes employers. Every time someone changes an employer, what has been paid in becomes virtually worthless because the amount that that person receives back when that happens is so little, as I have mentioned previously when I have spoken on these issues. It can be done if one has the will to do it.

Another aspect I want to mention is that superannuation is dealt with in Family Court proceedings following the breakdown of a marriage. Certainly superannuation is taken into account as property—but not as superannuation, not as retirement income. I do not think that the Labor Party recognises superannuation for its own value and importance. Indeed, some of the legislation that has been brought before us suggests that the government has looked at superannuation more as a means of revenue raising or as part of a wages package in the context of industrial bargaining—not as retirement income for its own intrinsic value. I think it is time we confronted the very unfair treatment for women in particular that occurs as a result.

Women receive lower wages than men. Either they are still not getting equal pay for work of equal value, or they are not getting the opportunity to do work which pays the same wage rate as that received by men. Two-thirds of women earn average incomes below $21,000, while the average income for the same number of men is above $21,000. As I said, either women are not getting paid or they are not getting the opportunity to participate. As a consequence, they get a smaller benefit at retirement.

Australian women constitute the majority of the aged population and they will continue to do so. That is clear. For that reason, they are being disadvantaged as they get to an age beyond which they are able to work and increase their own income. The traditional male patterns of work which seem to be still the basis of superannuation do not favour women and do not give them an opportunity to participate. Superannuation is based on people being virtually in one job for the full 40-odd years of their working life, in full-time employment, coming to retirement age and then moving into superannuation. A lot of women now are doing that, but they are a very small proportion of the total. With a bit of imagination, with a bit of will to include women in superannuation schemes, this could be changed. I believe it will be a long time before most women fall into the male work pattern, which is the basis of superannuation at the present time.

I mentioned being out of the work force for more than two years. As I conceded, it is not just a female question, but frequently that is the case. Why can a superannuation scheme not be individual to a person so that during your working life your employer can pay into it what should be paid while you are employed; so that you can contribute to your own superannuation scheme from such savings as you may be able to contribute during your working life; so that you may be able to pay into your own superannuation scheme money that you come by, perhaps by way of an inheritance or a lucky day at the races. In many instances in a divorce settlement there are cases where a woman receives a certain amount of money and she may well be better advised to place that sum of money into her own personal superannuation scheme than to deal with it in any other way. That is not so in all cases, but in many instances that may in fact give her much better retirement income in the longer term.

There are about two million women who are not in the paid work force who are totally denied access to superannuation because the basis of superannuation is that you have to be in paid employment. There is no reason why there cannot be retirement income schemes of the same kind we are talking about tonight for somebody who is not in paid employment for the whole of her life, perhaps not in paid employment for very much of her life, schemes that give heer access to retirement income of the kind that she will need.

Superannuation in the context of the Family Court has been dealt with in other places and I will not go into it in detail tonight. I merely remind the Senate, and in particular the government, that in many instances the female partner in a divorce does not have superannuation. When we take into account the value of superannuation at the time of divorce as an item of property, it does not indicate its true value in the longer term. It does not ensure that the other party in fact has superannuation in the longer run. I think it is time for the government to deal with that aspect and I hope it will do so before too long.

I was going to quote from the Law Reform Commission recommendation. Perhaps rather than my reading out the section dealing with women and superannuation, the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Senator Sherry), who is at the table, may agree that those sections of the Law Reform Commission report be incorporated in Hansard. I rely on them in support of my argument for that purpose. I seek leave to incorporate those pages in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The pages read as follows—

Extent to which superannuation taken into account. Superannuation entitlements were available to a significant number of respondents in the survey of Family Court cases. For example, in the sample of applications for approval of s 87 agreements, 45% of men and 15% of women were said to have these entitlements.(24) The Australian Institute of Family Studies survey, summarised in chapter 6, disclosed that, amongst younger couples, just over 50% of husbands and 8% of wives were members of superannuation schemes; and that amongst older couples just under 50% of husbands and 16-19% of wives were members of such schemes.(25) However, both studies demonstrated that superannuation is often ignored and, when not ignored, is not taken into account in any clear or consistent way. The Australian Institute of Family Studies research showed that in many cases, even amongst the older respondents, superannuation was not taken into account in property division. It was taken into account in only 46% of possible cases according to the older men and 39% of possible cases according to older women. Amongst younger couples, it was taken into account in only 38% of possible cases according to men and 20% of possible cases according to women.(26) Where superannuation had not been taken into account three quarters of the survey respondents claimed that they had not received advice that superannuation was relevant.(27) This is despite the fact that, where the value ascribed to the superannuation is added to the general pool of property, superannuation ranks as a significant asset. The absence of superannuation and life insurance policies in the pool of available property pushes the average share of property currently going to wives down by about 10% according to women and by about 5% according to men, when taking the older and younger groups together. The inclusion of superannuation would therefore have a significant effect on the overall shares.(28)

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to refer to the unfair treatment of casual, part-time itinerant workers under the legislation as it presently exists, two million or 80 per cent of whom are women. I have referred previously to examples where a part-time worker virtually gets nothing out of superannuation. I gave the details previously of Jessica Mehta, who is a constituent of mine. She went to work for a company in Canberra from January of 1991 to May of 1991 working 20 hours a week on a casual, part-time basis. She has been doing this for some time; she has been in and out of jobs of this nature.

PARA.TAB: She did not even know that money was paid by her employer for superannuation under the superannuation guarantee levy. But in fact it was and, over the period I just mentioned, some $165 was paid to CANPLAN Multi-Industry Superannuation Plan 330, which was the superannuation fund that her employer paid into. Regrettably, an employer regards the levy virtually as a tax, which it is to the employer. The employer has no reason to take any interest or concern in what happens to the contribution that he or she is forced to make. Of course, the employee does not contribute at all. So off goes the money into some unseen superannuation fund which does with it pretty much as it seems to like.

After Mrs Mehta left this period of employment, in fact nearly 12 months later, she received a cheque for $34.69. The employer, as I said, had paid $165 and a bit more. The super fund had deducted $137.30 by way of charges. She got $34.69. That has nothing to do with retirement income policy. It has nothing to do with providing for people when they get to the end of their working lives. The outrageous charges and levies which operate mean that, for these sorts of people, there is almost nothing left at all. In a minute I will give honourable senators a couple of instances where there was nothing left at all.

The employees have no choice about where the money goes. In many instances, they do not even know that it has been paid on their behalf. In my opinion there is no sincerity in the government's policy of superannuation when it sets up a structure which totally ignores the needs of itinerant, casual, part-time people in the work force. These people fulfil a significant role. I wish to quote from a letter that was written by two people who work in the industry of harvesting fruit and vegetables during certain times of the year. The letter states in part:

SPEECH.PARA: Last year (1992-93) my husband and I worked for a number of people as harvest workers. At each new place of employment we were enrolled in a superannuation scheme of the employers choice—we were given no opportunity to discuss or choose a plan, in fact in nearly every case it was done without any consultation with us at all. As a result we were enrolled in four different plans, twice with the same company!

The letter goes on to point out exactly how much of it was gobbled up by the administration levies and taxes. They refer to the number of phone calls made and the reams of paper used before they received any information about what had happened to the money that the employer had paid into the employer's chosen plan. There was no reason why the employer should take any interest; to the employer, it was just a tax.

PARA.TAB: Superannuation is not working for casual employees, part-time employees or itinerant employees. It is a massive waste of money that is doing nothing to benefit those whom, allegedly, it is supposed to benefit.

These two people worked at four different places. One job involved picking cherries and I am not quite sure what they were doing at the other three, but in each case the employer paid the money. In one instance, in the end, the wife got back $6.39 and the husband got $7.50. Each of them got back $88 from another employer and absolutely nothing from the other two, which were with the Australian farm superannuation plan.

I am prepared to concede that the government has attempted to legislate to make superannuation meaningful but, in my opinion, it is very significantly on the wrong track and not dealing with the needs of a very significant section of the work force. Until that need is met, those who, as a consequence, will be doomed to have nothing but the age pension when they retire will very likely be much worse off than they would be at present, given, as I stated at the beginning, that the number of taxpayers in the community will inevitably decline as the population ages, and people live much longer beyond working age than people have in the past and make demands on the system.

This could be easily rectified if the government set up a personal superannuation scheme for those who have turned 18, so that moneys could be paid in by the employer and the employee, and other moneys could be paid in by other people or as it becomes available. People who are out of the work force because they are unemployed for more than two years, as at present, or women who are out of the work force for five years while they have children and look after them while they are young, would find the money still available and not gobbled up with administration charges and levies, which is what presently happens. In the end, we would have a superannuation scheme which would be meaningful and worth while for this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have before us a raft of legislation designed to add some supervision and regulation to the superannuation industry. We think it is entirely appropriate, especially given the push to include people in superannuation funds to reduce their future reliance on the old age pension.

PARA.TAB: If anything, we feel the legislation does not go far enough. We see massive amounts of unfunded liabilities in superannuation funds. One Victorian public sector superannuation fund has been reported in the business press to hold $16 billion in unfunded liabilities. This is more than the maximum that the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) proposes to allow for the national debt. Parliamentary information service estimates of nationwide unfunded liabilities are at least $80 billion. Certainly it would be a problem for both workers and the government if some of these funds started to go down.

Our initial worry about the superannuation legislation package was that, if the government made a guarantee to members in respect of their superannuation, it might get into real trouble if, for example, the Victorian fund collapsed. We were reassured by government that the legislation would not cover the members in this case because the legislation covers fraud and clear mismanagement, but not commercial mishaps. The difference between mismanagement and commercial mishap is that one is the result of corrupt or highly dubious investment while the other is a result of permissible investment which in some way corresponds to industry norms. Most of the problems in Victoria occurred as a result of investing according to industry norms of the 1980s.

The first point I wish to make is that, if such bad investment leads to situations where the financial community reports major problems and very large funds are not covered, this legislation will not cover members very well or really guarantee the security of their government enforced superannuation money.

Another concern we had at the beginning involved how the government would take on a supervisory role if it chose to do so. There are many problems with government directly making investment decisions on so massive a scale. There is also the potential and some justification for the idea that the public should ensure that such publicly enforced savings are invested for the benefit of the community. But the reality depends on the integrity and goals of government.

We asked, therefore, what levels of supervision there might be and what criteria there would be for acceptable or unacceptable investment. The response was very laissez-faire. We were told that supervision would be minimal and attained through requiring auditors and others to report suspect practices. Along the lines of deregulationist ideology, the regulation of the industry would be minimal. Only practices that fell clearly outside industry norms or normal diversity would be questioned or picked up.

What is an industry norm? In some respects, it is reflected in clauses in the legislation. Investment should be `adequately diverse' and ensure maximum returns without creating insupportable risks. This translates into conventional investment strategies used in banks, insurance agencies and other big storehouses of money; that is, to play the global market in what has been described as casino capitalism. Some money goes into longer term stocks and bonds, but a fair bit of it goes into the potentially lucrative area of short-term finance and playing the stock market, the bond market and the currency market.

It should be noted here that this is a new phenomenon, having its roots in two changes: the deregulation of the global financial market, such as the London financial city in 1980; and the development and proliferation of communication and computer technology, which allowed investors to speculate globally at speed. It is worth noting that we are not talking about the speed of an investor on a direct line, but the speed of one computer speaking directly to another computer. That is what we are looking at with this amount of money in Australian investment funds. Our concern as Greens is that the direction of this funding is becoming more and more concentrated and that our participation in global financial deregulation and speculation is forming the basis of the Australian economy.

I suppose our major concern is that without access by consumers to information about superannuation investment portfolios, capital for sustainable industries within the country may not be made available. If the kind of regulations or lack of regulations in this very important industry lead away from the capacity for such ethical or more sustainable industries to access finance, it would be a great concern. The very least we can expect from government is the capacity for individual consumers to be able to access the information about where their investment funds are going.

We believe that the very minimum that should be available to consumers of compulsory superannuation funds is information about where that money is spent and invested. Therefore, if a large government or industry superannuation fund directed its resources towards industries which are perhaps socially unacceptable, even though they might be profitable, especially in the short term, people would be able to lobby either their fund managers or the company in the public arena for more options to be made available to them.

We are not suggesting that people could necessarily direct where their investment could go because not everybody is an investment manager. But we do say that it is extremely important that if one believes—and in this chamber, most people express the belief—that the market process is the way choices should be made, then one of the very first principles of the market is that people act after being in receipt of full information. The Greens would add that profitability is not the only basis upon which people make choices as consumers. If one even pretends to be interested in the market as a mechanism, one cannot disagree that the ability to find out where one's compulsory funds are being spent is a very important principle.

The issue of disclosure is central here. There is no way of knowing even whether a fund is ethical unless one knows the investment strategy and where one's money is going. We flagged putting forward an amendment to this measure to ensure that members and potential members of public issue entities and of funds people choose to belong to can not only ask for information but be entitled to receive information on where their portfolio is located. We have phrased our suggestion so that information is available on demand. It would not be a requirement that every fund provide that information for every member every year, which we realise would be impractical and very expensive, but on demand people would have the right to find out the portfolio of their prospective superannuation fund.

The existing section says that the commissioner may set regulations requiring disclosure. I am very grateful that the government is now suggesting that in the near future—that is, by early next year—there will be regulations that actually specify the ability of prospective members of superannuation funds to access this information. At the moment, the legislation itself does not guarantee disclosure for public sector funds or non-public sector offer employer sponsored funds. These are the funds which are not voluntary, the funds employees must join as a condition of employment. There is no freedom to respond according to conscience. The government did not at the time of drafting deem it necessary to allow people to know where their money was going.

We believe that all people should be ensured at least some basic option for choice and expression of their values in long-term investment of their moneys. If any government is serious about looking at a sustainable economic structure in the future, the source of funding is extremely important.

Clause 64 of the superannuation supervisory bill was a problem for us, as it was for many others. The consistently strong criticism should be taken as an indication that there are real problems with this section. We recognise the need to stop rorts. It seems clear that when trustees or fund managers arrange things so that they can obtain use value for holding an asset they are obtaining an improper benefit. We think that a lot of senators who have problems with this clause would agree with this principle. The disagreement on the bill is not about motives.

We feel that focusing on members rather than trustees appears to allow rorts to continue as long as they are not assets donated by or acquired from members. There needs to be some change to this. If it is possible for clause 64—which we believe currently is a legislative mess—to be improved, the Greens WA would consider supporting appropriate amendments which would seek to do so.

We support regulations which aim to supervise an industry which is capable of creating huge problems, due to its size and diversity and the nature of the current financially deregulated system in Australia. It was our concern that, in the bill's original form, there was a great opportunity to make sure that investment funds in Australia were not simply directed by the electronic financial market of the day into the concentrated hands of fewer and fewer large corporations. Consumers should have the ability to find out where their funds are going, especially in the case of compulsory funds. There has to be the basis for informed choice—whether it is for ethical reasons such as people not wishing to invest in the arms industry, not wishing to invest in destructive forest practices, or not wishing to invest perhaps in the tobacco industry. People at least have a choice and can make informed decisions on that basis.

By supporting the bill in general, we would like to ask that the government use this opportunity to make sure that funds in Australia made available through superannuation requirements are not used in a way that is detrimental to the future sustainable development of this country.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —In the few minutes that are available to me, I do not believe that I can do justice to all the points that have been made in this debate tonight. Generally, I would like to thank the various speakers for their contributions and to respond to a couple of points before we move to the committee stage to deal with the numerous amendments that we have before us.

PARA.TAB: Fundamentally, this government has made some very significant changes to superannuation retirement incomes in this country. On election to office in 1983 we realised that the then superannuation regime was largely confined to higher income earners in the public sector, who were overwhelmingly male workers. It covered less than 40 per cent of the work force.

We have an aging population. At the present time, one in 10 persons is over the age of 65; by the year 2020, one in five persons will be over the age of 65. We therefore identified a need to move to a largely self-funded superannuation retirement incomes policy over the next 30 years. In doing that we have enacted a range of provisions including such fundamental reforms as the superannuation guarantee charge. The fundamental reforms that the Labor government has made were driven significantly by the current Prime Minister (Mr Keating) when he was Treasurer. The two major social reforms that this government made over the last 10 years were in the area of Medicare and superannuation.

I thank Senator Watson for his contribution to the debate, particularly as the chairman of the Senate Select Committee on Superannuation. I thank Senator Kernot for her contributions, although we do not agree with the allocation of a small amount into a national interest fund. I think she mentioned the sum of one per cent. I cannot go into the reasons for that tonight because of time; they are many and varied and we have discussed them before. I thank Senator Ferguson for his contribution.

I cannot say that I thank Senator Reid for the number of points she made in her contribution. All I can suggest is that she have some discussions with Senator Watson. The points she made are not necessarily valid in the overall context of superannuation. Time does not permit me to rebut the contribution she made this evening.

Finally, we will deal with the issue of ethical investment in the committee stage when we get to the amendment that Senator Margetts is proposing. For the record, I quite explicitly state that it is the government's intention to proceed with the requirements to allow a fund member to ask for and require a superannuation fund to provide full information on the investment portfolio of that fund as well as all other important matters relating to the fund. The government realises that this is a critical element of the new superannuation regulatory regime in that informed consumers can instigate—
Debate interrupted.
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Herron)—Order! It being 10.30 p.m., I put the question:
That the Senate do now adjourn.
Question resolved in the negative.
Debate resumed.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —The government is committed to ensuring a democratic information process to fund members. This shows that the government is firmly of the view that we need a much more participatory and informative superannuation regime than we currently have. Many of the measures, such as half yearly statements, members reports and information of that type have been acknowledged by the government as being very important and have already been initiated by this government.

PARA.TAB: So the issue of increased democratisation of superannuation is quite critical. It is highlighted by the fact that 50 per cent of trustees are members of the fund; that is, the work force of the fund. We want workers to know what is going on with their superannuation. These sorts of requirements have been specified in the regulations in the past and will be specified in the regulations arising from this legislation where they have not already been specified before.

The government will not be accepting the amendment relating to ethical investment, but I will deal with that when we get into committee. I thank the Senate Select Committee on Superannuation and the Chairman, Senator Watson, for the report. The vast majority of the amendments that we will be moving in committee tonight reflect the very careful scrutiny that the committee carried out in relation to this legislation.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bills read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that Senator Margetts has an amendment. I am not sure which bill it relates to, but I think it is important that we know that before we proceed.

—We want to make sure that there is a firm commitment from the government to ensure that consumers of superannuation, which is all of us, are able to find out into which fund their moneys are compulsorily going. Because we are a small party and because of the timing of the legislation and the nature of the discussions today, other parties have not had a chance to look at our amendment. The government has made a firm commitment that there will be a regulation to this effect by early next year. I am going to keep the government to this promise. (Quorum formed)

PROCTEXT.PARA: SUPERANNUATION (RESOLUTION OF COMPLAINTS) BILL 1993

PARA.TAB: The Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Clause 14, page 6, after subclause (4) insert the following subclause:

PARA.TAB: "(4A)The Tribunal cannot deal with a complaint about a trustee's decision if:
(a)the complaint is about a benefit that was paid before the commencement of this Act; and
(b)the benefit was paid, in whole or in part, to a person other than the complainant.".

SPEECH.PARA: The basic reason for this amendment is that the opposition does not want to hold up the payments that are going to be made by trustees to beneficiaries where there is likely to be any element of dispute, otherwise this could result in a double jeopardy after the tribunal has been constituted. These issues could be brought before the tribunal after the act comes into fruition and thereby create a double jeopardy for the trustees and for the fund. Therefore, I have much pleasure in moving the amendment which is in conformity with a number of submissions and oral presentations made to the committee.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —The government cannot support this amendment. We believe that the undesirable consequence of passing the amendment would be to prevent people from receiving the benefit that they would otherwise be entitled to, so we cannot support it.

—I am sorry to hear this because it will create a line of unpaid commitments until after 1 July. It is not in the interest of beneficiaries to have their payments held up for a further seven months. The government, by its action, has signalled to every trustee around Australia that there is a double jeopardy and that they would be foolish, if there is any element of doubt about the payment, to make a payment to a beneficiary before this bill comes into effect. There will be an immediate implication of withholding every payment that is due where there may be any element of doubt. A trustee just could not afford to take the risk either on account of himself or in the interests of the fund. It creates a double jeopardy situation.

PARA.TAB: When the tribunal comes into effect we will have a whole line of issues. I will give honourable senators a typical example. A bona fide payment may be made to a widow. The de facto comes along after 1 July, lodges a complaint with the tribunal and the tribunal says, `Yes, you have a case. You might be entitled to 50 per cent' or whatever the portion might be. The money was paid out in good faith and in full knowledge of the facts as they then existed. Then the tribunal comes along. The Liberal Party had problems about the tribunal because of the possibility that it could undermine the financial standing of the fund. With the government's move tonight, I believe that it has the capacity to undermine the financial standing of small funds. It has the capacity to delay the payments made to genuine beneficiaries in good faith and create a double jeopardy position. I think it is a retrograde action.

TALKER.NAME: Senator KERNOT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to ask the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Senator Sherry): what is the problem with this operating between now and 1 July? It is not a big deal, is it? The government wants to protect people. So why does the government think that is such a bad idea?

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that the person would be damaged by losing the right of appeal. That is the government's analysis of Senator Watson's amendment and we cannot support it.

—To be quite frank, I did not understand that response. I say to Senator Watson that I understood that this committee debate would take place tomorrow. I expected to get some expert opinion about this particular matter from a person who is an expert in the sphere of superannuation.
—The condolence didn't go on for so long and they dropped another bill in favour of this one.

—We are past the time for putting the question that the Senate do now adjourn. I was not told anything about the negation of the adjournment until it had taken place. I do not think that is the way to run the business of the Senate. If the opposition has agreed to that, that is not the way to act, and it is certainly not the way to act if the opposition wants people to understand properly its amendments to the legislation.
—Put it forward as it comes through.

—Yes, people should put it forward as it comes forward within the terms of the standing orders and not come to some arrangement with the government at the death knock to negate the adjournment. I was certainly under the impression that this bill would be considered in its committee stage tomorrow. Under those circumstances, I did not ring this particular expert, which I would have done had I known that this matter was going to be discussed at the committee stage.

PARA.TAB: Having said that, I am still not sure what the minister's response was in respect of the question that was raised by Senator Kernot. Frankly, I do not see, on the face of it, why the government is opposed to this measure.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is before the act comes into play.
—That is what I am asking and I think that is what Senator Kernot asked.
—We don't want benefits withheld or trustees would be obliged to withhold them.

—Yes, but Senator Kernot asked a very valid question, having regard to what Senator Watson said, about why the government is opposed to that. I cannot see why it is, but there may be some other technical reason of which I am not aware and about which I am not in a position at the moment to get expert advice.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —There are a couple of matters I wish to respond to. All I can add to the explanation so far in respect of this matter is that all other complainants can proceed before the tribunal. There is a particular class of complainants who are excluded.

PARA.TAB: In respect of the other matters that Senator Harradine raised, I do not think it is reasonable that he could conclude that we would not get to the committee stage of this legislation tonight. The government certainly did not give him any indication that we would be proceeding with these bills through the committee stage tomorrow, as I am informed. The second point I want to make is that I know that the decision to negate the adjournment was taken very late—about five to 10 minutes prior to 10.30 p.m. Senator Harradine's office was rung and he was uncontactable. That was the procedure that was followed.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was perfectly logical for anyone to conclude that the second reading debate would not finish by half past 10. The fact is that the second reading debate did not finish at half past 10. I am now told that a few minutes before putting the question that the Senate do now adjourn, the arrangement was made by the opposition. My office was not contacted and no message was left. My office has an answering machine for when my staff are not there and it is cleared regularly. I had five messages on that answering machine between 9.30 and 10.30, all of which were answered. It has been admitted to me that the call was made only two or three minutes before the normal time for the adjournment debate. That is not a proper way to run this place. It is not a proper way of ensuring that legislation gets the adequate attention of all the members of this Senate.

PARA.TAB: As I said before, having regard to the list of speakers, it was appropriate to conclude that the second reading debate would not finish by half past 10. I am not in a position to obtain an expert opinion on this or any other amendment in respect of these particular measures. The reason is that there was an arrangement made between parties without regard to what I or, presumably, people in other than the major parties felt about the matter or the arrangements that they might have made.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will be very brief because I understand what Senator Reid will probably be doing. I can tell Senator Harradine that the comments I made earlier stand. We attempted to contact him. Certainly, the arrangements were made just prior to 10.30 p.m. I have admitted that. I was involved in those arrangements. I was not involved in contacting his office, but I understand that attempts were made to contact him. As Senator Harradine rightly points out, the legislation is important. However, he will well realise the problems we can run into at this time of year if we do not adopt the procedure of negating the adjournment on occasions. On this occasion it was felt necessary that, in order to ensure that we have a smooth run of legislation, that should be the procedure followed.

PARA.TAB: Progress reported.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tierney Sen J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise tonight to pay tribute to a remarkable woman, Mrs Helen Robinson OAM. Recently, I had the honour of launching a book which records her achievements. The foreword to Lorna Howlett's remarkable biography of Helen Robinson encapsulates her contribution. She says:

PARA.TAB: Helen Robinson is a person whose life personifies the Australian ideals;

SPEECH.PARA: —strongly independent and full of determination in pursuing her ideals,
—yet ever compassionate in her selfless work for the genuine needs of others.

PARA.TAB: Her reputation has been earned through a lifetime of service in the interests of the aged, sick and countless other charitable causes which will ensure that her efforts will never be forgotten.

The book on her life will serve as a valuable, permanent reminder to future generation of not only her pivotal role in making ventures like the Mayflower Retirement Village a reality, but also the many other achievements of this exceptional individual.
The Helen Robinson story is one of:

SPEECH.PARA: —selfless dedication,
—strong Christian beliefs,
—prayer for what can only be described as miracles, and
—absolute faith in God's inspiration.

Lorna Howlett's book makes clear the contribution Helen Robinson has made to so many lives. Lorna draws on the many experiences that Helen has had including her nursing work with her husband, John, in Nauru and the inner suburbs of Sydney; the establishment of the Mayflower retirement homes; and her overseas trips. Her greatest achievement is the establishment of the Mayflower Retirement Village and hospice in Gerringong. It is a remarkable achievement and the fulfilment of one of Helen's dreams.

PARA.TAB: In the biography, Lorna tells the story of Helen visiting a cold, bleak, abandoned, old Methodist church in Waterloo in Sydney at the age of 17 and making her promise to God to help the aged in our society. Helen can now look at the results of this vision that she and her husband John had inspired and know that her girlhood dream has been answered. Thankfully, the work that Helen has undertaken has not gone unnoticed. In 1979 she was awarded the New South Wales female citizen of the year and in 1984 she was awarded the Order of Australia Medal for her work in aged care. Helen Robinson's tenacity, dedication and vision is best summarised in the book by an extract from a letter of support for Helen's OAM nomination. The extract reads:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the Gerringong Mayfield Retirement Village complex now stands as a result of the vision and driving force of Helen Robinson and I have observed from the inception of this project how her incredible faith and personal energy has encouraged others to overcome the obstacles which sometimes seemed insurmountable.

Lorna Howlett's biography of Helen Robinson is a book that I can recommend to everyone. There are so many inspirational stories in this book. Stories such as the terrifying cyclone on Nauru and the heartbreaking tragedy of the Vietnamese boy, Duc, show why we can learn from the strength that Helen has shown throughout her life.

PARA.TAB: Certainly, there are very few people who can claim to have achieved all they have dreamt of in life. According to the biographer, other than an interest in helping aged people, Helen has had three personal desires which in her very limited leisure time she allowed herself to dream about. These desires were to speak in the House of Commons, to open a shop and to take a course in speech and drama. It is to Helen's credit that she can say she achieved all three dreams. At the age of 81, she completed a course in speech and drama through a London school earlier this year. She did open a shop and she addressed a meeting in the British Houses of Parliament building. Although she did not actually speak in the parliament, tonight she is being spoken about in the Australian parliament.

I recommend this book to everyone here as an inspiration for our own lives. I would especially like to thank her biographer, Lorna Howlett, for allowing us to know Helen Robinson more intimately through her book so that we may be inspired by the Helen Robinson story.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

The following answers to questions were circulated:

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Development Cooperation and Pacific Island Affairs, upon notice, on 18 August 1993:

PARA.TAB: (1) Are any Australian development cooperation funds being provided to the Burmese State Law and Order Restoration Council (SLORC) or to non-Government organisations (NGOs) whose operations are based in Rangoon.
(2) Will the Minister ensure that no Australian International Development Assistance Bureau funding be provided to the SLORC or NGOs based in Rangoon.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Development Cooperation and Pacific Island Affairs has provided the following response to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) No. Currently there are no development cooperation funds being channelled to the SLORC or to activities in Burma of NGOs based in Rangoon.

(2) The Minister for Development Cooperation and Pacific Island Affairs, Mr Bilney and I recently reaffirmed Australia's position not to resume bilateral development assistance in Burma until there is substantial progress towards the restoration of democracy and an improvement in human rights.

We did agree, however, to the implementation of a limited indirect humanitarian aid program to address the HIV/AIDS situation within Burma, implemented through NGOs and UN agencies and starting at $200,000 in 1993/94.

Our decisions were based on a review of Australia's policy response to the situation in Burma undertaken by the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade and AIDAB. The review fully considered events occurring within Burma, including the deteriorating social and economic situation adversely affecting vulnerable groups and the range of views expressed by various interest groups.
Australia continues to monitor events in Burma in an effort to ensure that Australia's policy response remains appropriate to the situation in Burma.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Development Cooperation and Pacific Island Affairs, upon notice, on 8 September 1993:

PARA.TAB: (1) What assessment has the Australian Government made of the operations of the Grameen Bank of Bangladesh?
(2) Has the Government considered contributing to the Grameen Trust which has been set up in association with the operations of the Grameen Bank?

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Development Cooperation and Pacific Island Affairs has provided me with the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) The Government is aware of the Grameen Bank program in Bangladesh, and the significant impact it has had on the lives of its borrowers, both in terms of raising incomes and giving many people, especially women, opportunities for leadership roles they previously lacked. Beginning in a single village in 1976, the Bank now provides loans to over a million borrowers. Loan sizes are typically less than $100 and are provided for small enterprises in areas such as trading, shopkeeping and handicraft manufacture. A number of independent reviews have confirmed that the activities of the Bank have had a significant impact on the poor in those areas in which it has been active, with incomes of borrowers increasing by between 30% and 50% on average, with corresponding improvements in other indicators of welfare. Loan repayment rates exceed 95%.

The Bank has received substantial support from international and bilateral donor agencies, such as the International Fund for Agricultural Development, Sweden, Norway and Canada. Its effectiveness in reaching the poor is well documented.

(2) Over the past few years, there have been several attempts to replicate the Grameen Bank approach (GBA) in other countries, some of which have been supported by the Grameen Trust. Micro-enterprise development programs using other approaches are also gaining in popularity internationally. Currently, the Grameen Trust is promoting an ambitious proposal to expand GBA replication programs, and it has sought donor funding of US$ 100 million from bilateral donor agencies world-wide, including Australia.

The potential for small-scale credit schemes to assist the poor has been recognised by the Government, and the Australian aid program has been involved in such programs in a small way for several years. The Government is currently considering whether there is scope for increasing support for small-scale credit schemes through its aid program, both to alleviate poverty and to encourage private initiative. The request for support of the Grameen Trust, and other possible initiatives, will be considered in this context weighing other competing priorities for aid budget resources.

As a key part of this process of assessing the potential of small scale credit schemes, the Australian International Development Assistance Bureau (AIDAB), is hosting a workshop on the topic of micro-enterprise development on 11 and 12 November this year. The workshop will bring together small-scale credit and business development practitioners, non-government organisations and academics from Australia and developing countries to consider the role of micro-enterprise development in poverty programs and to identify the advantages and disadvantages of the various approaches to such development. The results of the workshop will provide an important input into the Government's consideration of what part support of small scale credit schemes will play in Australia's aid program in future.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 21 September 1993:

PARA.TAB: (1) What is the content of the AAT video which was produced for the Department by Vitascope, Mosman, NSW, for $16,834?
(2) What is the purpose of this video?
(3) How many copies of the video were produced?
(4) To what extent has this video been used?

TALK.START.PARA: —The Attorney-General has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) I am advised that the video contains a visual presentation of the way applications to the Tribunal are processed through the system. The presentation includes a collage of conference scenarios including face to face and telephone conferences, and conferences where there is a need for language speaking and hearing interpreters. The video then takes the viewer through the formal hearing process and a short segment shows the procedure in the hearing room. The viewers are guided through the video by a presenter. The video runs for a total of 10 minutes and 50 seconds.

The video was produced at a total cost of $50,000 by Vitascope Productions for the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. Three progressive payments (March 1993—$16,500, April 1993—$16,834 and June 1993—$16,667) were made. The Attorney-General's Department was not involved with the production of the video.

(2) I am advised that the purpose of the video is to inform the community of the manner in which the Tribunal reviews decisions. It is part of an outreach program to provide unrepresented applicants with information to enable them to understand their responsibilities and to properly present the evidence needed by the Tribunal to make a decision.
(3) I am advised that initially 100 copies of the video were made and that it is expected that the number will increase as orders are placed.

(4) I am advised that the video has been used in the outreach program mentioned in the response to Question (2),—to provide unrepresented applicants with sufficient information to enable them to present appropriate evidence to the Tribunal. There is no charge for the use of the video and it may be viewed in the Tribunal's registries or loaned out. The video is also used in Access and Equity administrative review information sessions to community groups, which include non-English speaking groups. Copies of the video are also being placed in university and State libraries.

A national awareness campaign is to be commenced shortly to inform potential users of the Tribunal of the availability of the video. It is expected that Welfare Rights Centres, Legal Rights Centres, ethnic community groups and government agencies will be given the opportunity of obtaining a copy of the video.

Subject to further investigation the video will be subtitled into selected languages. The estimated cost of subtitling is $2,500. A possibility also exists for the video to be used by SBS television and other television networks.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Transport and Communications, upon notice, on 21 September 1993:

PARA.TAB: With reference to section 182(2) of the Queensland Marine Act which exempts Queensland licensed coastal pilots from personal liability in pecuniary damages:
(1) How does the Commonwealth propose to deal with the present situation with respect to the liability of pilots to be sued personally for damages.
(2) Will exemption be granted in accordance with the provisions of the Queensland legislation or will pilots be exposed to charges of personal liability.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) Most of the Queensland coastal pilots hold licences which were issued by the Queensland authorities. These licences are recognised under transitional arrangements by the Australian Maritime Safety Authority (AMSA) which assumed responsibility for Queensland and Torres Strait pilot licensing on 1 July 1993. The pilots continue to be protected by the liability exclusions of the Queensland Marine Act.
The Government has introduced in this session legislation to amend the Navigation Act which will allow for regulations to be made for dealing with the issue of pilot liability.
(2) Before any regulations are made, AMSA will consult widely as to what form any liability exclusion should take.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Transport and Communications, upon notice, on 21 September 1993:

PARA.TAB: Did the Australian Maritime Safety Authority write to the International Maritime Organisation (IMO) seeking their views on command time for coastal pilots; if so, what was the response from IMO.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: Yes. AMSA contacted the International Maritime Organisation (IMO) on 28 April 1993 to establish whether there was any IMO recommendation that coastal pilots have command experience.

The IMO Secretariat replied that there were no IMO requirements or recommendations regarding command time for pilots; such requirements were instead a matter for determination by "competent authorities" within individual States.

The IMO Secretariat also conveyed information which it had received from the International Marine Pilots Association (IMPA) to the effect that licensing practice by "competent authorities" required a pilot to hold a master's certificate and to have had at least 10 to 15 years sea-going service. The IMO added that it was its understanding that the experience requirement specified by "competent authorities" related to bridge rather than command experience.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

(i) No

(ii) The Department has provided information on the Act to relevant groups, including health lobby groups, and State and Territory Health and Sport Departments. asked the Minister representing the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories, upon notice, on 5 October 1993:

PARA.TAB: (1) Under what criteria, with what funding, and against what evaluation standards is the Federal Government's program to test Diesohol in buses in the Australian Capital Territory being undertaken.

(2) Did a local service station in Hobart recently begin a trial supplying an ethanol/unleaded petrol mix to customers with pre-1986 cars; if so, what research has been undertaken in regard to, and level of satisfaction with, the performance of their vehicles; if not, will the proprietor be contacted about the success of the trial.

(3) What Federal Government funding opportunities are available to provide one storage tank, one petrol bowser and a supply of ethanol to a service station in Hobart for a period of one year in order to complete the trial.
(4) What limits or impediments exist to exempting ethanol from excise tax when it is to be used as motor vehicle fuel.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) The technical trial of the fuel Diesohol in the Australian Capital Territory's Internal Omnibus Network (ACTION) is being funded under the Commonwealth's Climate Change Program because Diesohol has the potential to reduce greenhouse gas emissions. Diesohol represents a new development in fuel blends containing ethanol, a renewable fuel. The trial is being evaluated by the peer reviewers for the trial, Society of Automotive Engineers and DASFleet.

(2) Yes. However, the Commonwealth Government is not involved in the trial and is not funding research into customer reaction. My Department has been in contact with the Skyline Service Station in Hobart, where the trial was held, and they reported a high level of customer satisfaction.

(3) The Commonwealth Government currently has no specific plans to fund the Hobart trial. As part of the Government's Budget initiatives on reducing lead in petrol, funds are to be provided ($1.69 million in 1993-94 and $2.25 million in 1994-95) for development of ethanol as a fuel, with part of this funding to be directed to field trials of the use of ethanol blends in vehicles.

(4) None. The Commonwealth currently assesses ethanol used as motor vehicle fuel as excise exempt. This is in keeping with the Government's 1992 commitment to a five-year guarantee of the excise-free status of alternative transport fuels, with at least one-year's notification of any intention to change that status.
