TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Housing, Local Government and Community Services, upon notice, on 6 October 1993:

PARA.TAB: (1) Of the 14 nursing homes in receivership during the 1992-93 financial year, how many are: (a) in Victoria; and (b) private as opposed to `non profit' nursing homes.
(2) To the knowledge of the department, what percentage of private nursing homes in Victoria are in receivership or liquidation.
(3) Which State recorded the highest nursing home costs in the Arthur Andersen survey.
(4) What evidence is there of a direct link between the results of the Arthur Andersen survey into nursing home costs and nursing home receiverships in Victoria.
(5) Is the Department aware of the number of proprietors of nursing homes that become formally bankrupt; if so, please provide figures for the last five years.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Housing, Local Government and Community Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) Of the 14 nursing homes in receivership during the 1992-93 financial year, 7 were in Victoria and all 14 were private nursing homes.

(2) To the Department's knowledge 1.4% of private nursing homes in Victoria are currently in receivership or liquidation. During the 1992-93 financial year 3.4% of private nursing homes in Victoria were in receivership or liquidation.

(3) The results of the survey showed that in the private sector, nursing home costs were highest in Victoria if Return On Investment (ROI) factors are included. ROI factors include interest on capital borrowing, rent, depreciation and items of profit distribution including dividends to shareholders. Excluding ROI factors, New South Wales private sector homes had the highest costs.

The Arthur Andersen survey distinguished between the Voluntary and Private sectors. In the Voluntary sector, Victoria had the highest nursing home costs. The survey identified that in all States the Voluntary sector recorded the highest average expenditure.
(4) Due to the small number of homes in receivership it is difficult to establish a link between the Arthur Andersen survey and homes in receivership.

(5) The Department is made aware of bankruptcies through contact with proprietors or receivers/agents. The Department does not have records of proprietors that have been declared bankrupt in the last five years.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education and Training, upon notice, on 7 October 1993:

PARA.TAB: (1) Why are young people from New Zealand who are studying in Australia being denied Medicare benefits as from 1 July 1993 when the reciprocal health agreement between New Zealand and Australia to bring this new regulation into effect has not yet been signed.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Employment, Education and Training has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) All overseas students in Australia, including students from New Zealand, are outside the Medicare arrangements. By Government decision, from 1 July 1993 all overseas students studying in Australia are required to contribute to Overseas Students Health Cover (OSHC). The Reciprocal Health Care Agreement (RHCA) between Australia and New Zealand which was introduced in April 1986 does not require amendment to give effect to this decision. New Zealand students are being enrolled in OSHC.

(2) On 10 December 1992 the Deputy Prime Minister and the then Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services, the Hon. Brian Howe, and the then Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, the Hon. Senator Button, and the then Minister for Trade and Overseas Development, the Hon. John Kerin announced in a joint press conference that from 1 July 1993 all overseas students would be insured under the OSHC arrangements. Pamphlets on the OSHC arrangements are available in Medibank offices. There is a Memorandum of Understanding (MOU) between the Department of Health, Housing, Local Government and Community Services, Australian International Development Assistance Bureau, the Department of Employment, Education and Training and the Health Insurance Commission involved in the provision of OSHC. This MOU is currently being amended to clarify the status of New Zealand students as being eligible for OSHC.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 7 October 1993:

PARA.TAB: With reference to the `60 Minutes' program on 3 October 1993 which dealt with criticisms of the youth homeless allowance:
(1) Is the Government concerned by criticisms of the rules governing the allowance, particularly those made by an officer of the department.
(2) Is the Government concerned that the allowance is acting as an incentive for children to leave home.
(3) Will the Government undertake a review of the youth homeless allowance given the problems highlighted by the `60 Minutes' program.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Social Security has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) No officer of the Department of Social Security was interviewed on the `60 Minutes' program on 3 October 1993. The Government takes seriously any public criticism of programs for which it is responsible and gives consideration to them in the on-going administration of the program.

(2) Young Homeless Allowance is only paid after a strict assessment process. The allowance is not granted unless the young person's claims can be verified. All claims for Young Homeless Allowance require the involvement of a Social Security social worker and must be approved by a senior officer of the Department.

(3) The 1993-94 Budget includes new Social Security services for young people. Ten Youth Service Units will be located in areas of high concentration of young people. As part of the introduction of the Youth Service Units, administrative procedures relating to income support payments to young people will be reviewed. The review will result in changes to the guidelines concerning Young Homeless Allowance.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 12 October 1993:

PARA.TAB: (1) What is the cost of the total refurbishment of the Australian International Development Assistance Bureau offices.
(2) What are the reasons for this refurbishment.
(3) What amount of space has been gained.
(4) How much has been spent on moving the Director's Office.
(5) Is this office now larger; if so, by how much.
(6) What is the rationale for moving the Director's office.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) From May 1993 onwards, some areas of AIDAB's Central Office are being re-arranged and some refurbishing undertaken. This works program is to be completed in November this year. The costs of this exercise to 19 October have been $140,199; total costs are estimated to be around $170,000.

(2) Over 1993-94, AIDAB needs to accommodate an increase of 12-14 staff in its PNG Branch, following on from Government decisions to change the direction of the PNG program from budget support to programmed aid over the next few years.

Efforts with the Australian Property Group to secure some additional space elsewhere in AIDAB House from other tenants, have so far been unsuccessful. Accordingly the Bureau has had to pursue alternative solutions by re-organising and refurbishing parts of its existing accommodation usage throughout the building for greater effectiveness.
Several areas of AIDAB's Central Office were directly involved in this program, including the Office of the Director General.

This program has also provided the opportunity to co-locate the previously dispersed Program Development and Review Branch, and to place the Public Affairs Section in co-location with the Bureau's Ministerial and Parliamentary Liaison units.

(3) No net additional space was gained, as this program was from the outset necessarily a zero-sum exercise. However the re-organisation of some layouts for improved space usage has released enough space within the same overall AIDAB allocation to accommodate the additional 12-14 staff for PNG Branch in 1993/94. This involves an area of approximately 110 m(2).
(4) The portion of the overall costs involved in relocating the Office of AIDAB's Director General, including creation of a new small conference room, was $39,042.
Offset against this outlay however, AIDAB was able to fully re-use elsewhere in these works some $6,800 worth of office building materials released through the dismantling of the former Office.

(5) The previous space occupied by the Office of the Director General was 121.9m(2). This included the usual provision for appropriate support staff and facilities. The Office complex in its new site takes up 99.6m(2).

(6) As noted in response to Question 2, the primary objective was to achieve sufficient released space to allow for the accommodation of extra PNG Branch staffing. As well, the necessary relocation of some sections provided the opportunity to improve operational efficiency, for example by consolidating the previously-dispersed Program Development and Review Branch into one area. This particular improvement was achieved by directly exploiting the space previously occupied by the Director General's Office.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Department of Employment, Education and Training: Consultants

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, upon notice, on 19 October 1993.

PARA.TAB: With reference to the Federal Court judgement of 22 September 1993 (NG 353) in Repatriation Commission v. Hawkins:

(1) Pursuant to paragraph 5(12)(b) of the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986, will a period of "operational service" be now extended for veterans' entitlement purposes to include the journey to and from the operational area and the home port (last port of departure in Australia); if so, what steps will the Government take to facilitate the extension of veterans' entitlements to those concerned; if not, why not.

(2) Will the extended period of "operational service", that is, including the journey to and from Australia, be counted towards the award of the Vietnam Service Medal; if so, what steps will the Government take to give the award of the medal to those entitled to receive it as a consequence of this extension, if not, why not.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) Operational service for those members of the Australian Defence Force logistic and support units in Vietnam, as detailed in the instrument issued by the then Minister for Defence on 22 May 1986 deeming allotment for duty, will now be determined on the same basis as all other members who were allotted for duty in an operational area. This means that journeys from Australia to and from the operational area will be covered. Since 15 June 1993, my Department has been holding claims for pension which may have been affected by the outcome of the Hawkins case. These will now be determined in accordance with that decision and normal departmental procedures. Any member who had a claim determined prior to that date which may have been affected by the Hawkins decision should lodge a fresh claim with the Department of Veterans' Affairs. If the decision has already been appealed, and would have been accepted under the Hawkins decision, the Repatriation Commission will not contest the appeal. My Department has written to major ex-service organisations to inform their members of this and the requirement for fresh claims to be lodged.
(2) No. The only time counted towards Vietnam Service Medal is the time spent in the operational area of Vietnam.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Resources, upon notice, on 20 October 1993:

PARA.TAB: (1) What has been the cumulative production in Australia to December 1992 of: (a) crude oil; and (b) condensate.

(2) What are the present proven reserves (90 per cent confidence limit), probable reserves (50 per cent confidence limit) and inferred reserves yet to be discovered (10 per cent confidence limit) in Australia of: (a) crude oil; and (b) condensate.
(3) Of these proven, probable and inferred reserves for crude oil and condensate what percentage is located off-shore.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Resources has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) The cumulative production in Australia to December 1992 is estimated as 3528 million barrels of crude oil and 204 million barrels of condensate.

(2) The Bureau of Resource Sciences publishes remaining proven plus probable crude oil and condensate reserves for Australia at the 50 per cent confidence level. Proven reserves and inferred resources for identified fields are not published for Australia as a whole. The published reserves are divided into commercial and non-commercial reserves. Non-commercial reserves are technically recoverable reserves which have not yet been declared commercially viable.

The estimated remaining commercial proven and probable reserves as at 31 December 1991 are 1021 million barrels of crude oil and 594 million barrels of condensate. Non-commercial reserves as at 31 December 1991 are 852 million barrels of crude oil and 535 million barrels of condensate.

Crude oil resources in millions of barrels in undiscovered fields in the four most significant producing basins have been estimated by Drs Forman and Hinde of the Bureau of Resource Sciences in the recent publication "Oil and Gas Resources of Australia 1992" as follows:
These represent approximately 60% of estimated undiscovered resources at the average level.

(3) 79% of the remaining commercial proven and probable reserves of crude oil and 92% of the remaining commercial proven and probable reserves of condensate as at 31 December 1991 lie off-shore. Over 99% of the non-commercial proven and probable reserves of crude oil and 95% of the non-commercial proven and probable reserves of condensate lie off-shore. Combining commercial and non-commercial categories, 88% of the remaining proven and probable reserves of crude oil and 93% of the remaining proven and probable reserves of condensate lie off-shore in Commonwealth waters and States Territorial seas.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 6 September 1993 (Hansard page 920), Senator O'Chee asked me a question without notice concerning the effect of the Commonwealth Banks amendment Bill on the operations of the Commonwealth Development Bank (CDB). Specifically Senator O'Chee asked whether the bill would:

PARA.TAB: (i) have any implications for the CDB's role as a `lender of last resort'; or
(ii) reduce the access to supplementary finance of a farmer who had a first and second mortgage on the property.
In my response to the honourable senator's question, I undertook to check with the Treasurer whether there was any further material which was relevant to this matter.
The Treasurer has provided the following additional information in answer to the honourable senator's question:

The proposed amendments to the Commonwealth Banks Act will not lessen or remove the existing last recourse aspect or the CDB's function. Under its amended charter. the CDB will still only be permitted to provide finance where part or all of that finance is not otherwise available at reasonable terms and conditions. Rather, the amendments will strengthen the CDB in its commercial operations by ensuring that the CDB is not restricted to only considering the supplementary element in a

ANSWER.PARA: borrower's financial requirements. This will enable the CDB to match return and risk more effectively in respect of each customer. while retaining the CDB's traditional `last recourse' role.

PARA.TAB: It follows that the opportunity of a farmer with a first and second mortgage to obtain supplementary finance will not be diminished.

The CDB's traditional agency arrangements with some twelve commercial banks in Australia will not be disturbed. The CDB provides a range of services consistent with its charter, viz, term loans, equipment finance, equity finance, and advice to borrowers, and does not seek to displace a borrower's normal banking arrangements.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 7 September 1993 (Hansard page 1047), Senator Baume asked me a question without notice concerning the Prime Minister's personal financial arrangements. In particular, he asked whether or not the Commonwealth Bank had breached the superannuation regulations in making a loan to the Prime Minister.

PARA.TAB: In answering the honourable senator's question, I undertook to see whether the Commonwealth Bank wished to respond to the issue raised.

The Commonwealth Bank has advised that maintenance of confidentiality of customers' affairs is a basic tenet of banking and that, except in limited cases recognised by law, no bank is in a position to divulge information about its customers. The bank has also advised that it fully observes the requirements of the superannuation regulations.
